list.title: Question 1
list.content: What is the maximum number of electrons in the4p4p4psubshell?A.\hspace{1em}6B.\hspace{1em}10C.\hspace{1em}2D.\hspace{1em}8
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Forppp,lllis equal to 1. The number of electrons in a given subshell can be calculated using the formula:2(2l+1)=2((2)(1)+1)=62(2\,l + 1) = 2((2)(1) + 1) = 62(2l+1)=2((2)(1)+1)=6electronsThepppsubshell holds 3 orbitals. Each orbital can fit 2 electrons. Therefore,pppsubshell holds 6 electrons.

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Which equation represents condensation?A.BrX2(l)⟶BrX2(g)\hspace{1em}\ce{Br2}\textrm{(l)} \longrightarrow \ce{Br2}\textrm{(g)}BrX2​(l)⟶BrX2​(g)B.HX2O(g)⟶HX2O(l)\hspace{1em}\ce{H2O}\textrm{(g)} \longrightarrow \ce{H2O}\textrm{(l)}HX2​O(g)⟶HX2​O(l)C.COX2(s)⟶COX2(g)\hspace{1em}\ce{CO2}\textrm{(s)} \longrightarrow \ce{CO2}\textrm{(g)}COX2​(s)⟶COX2​(g)D.NaOH(aq)+HCl(aq)⟶NaCl(aq)+HX2O(l)\hspace{1em}\ce{NaOH}\textrm{(aq)} + \ce{HCl}\textrm{(aq)} \longrightarrow \ce{NaCl}\textrm{(aq)} + \ce{H2O}\textrm{(l)}NaOH(aq)+HCl(aq)⟶NaCl(aq)+HX2​O(l)
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Condensation occurs when a gas changes into a liquid.Students must distinguish changes in states of matter from chemical reactions (such as the neutralization reaction between sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid).This question is categorized as easy as students are only expected to identify changes in states of matter.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
What is the electron configuration of this orbital diagram?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e556344-f51d-45f9-8cc1-342ce8822130/images/aebba581-d5ec-4940-850d-7777dc859933/CH0262.png)

A.\hspace{1em}1s22s22p31s^2\,2s^2\,2p^31s22s22p3B.\hspace{1em}1s22p32s21s^2\,2p^3\,2s^21s22p32s2C.\hspace{1em}1s22s32p21s^2\,2s^3\,2p^21s22s32p2D.\hspace{1em}1s22s23s31s^2\,2s^2\,3s^31s22s23s3
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The orbital diagram shows two electrons in the1s1s1sorbital, two in the2s2s2sorbital, and three singly placed in the2p2p2porbitals. This adds up to seven electrons, which is the electron count for nitrogen in its ground state. According to the Aufbau principle, the 1s orbital is filled first, followed by2s,2s,2s,and then2p.2p.2p.The Pauli exclusion principle requires that each orbital holds no more than two electrons with opposite spin, and Hund's rule explains why the three2p2p2pelectrons occupy separate orbitals with parallel spins before any pairing occurs.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e556344-f51d-45f9-8cc1-342ce8822130/images/566bc402-15c8-4c3e-ad06-0370a9a3d480/CH0262ms.png)

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Which of the following statements doesnot\textbf{not}notconform to the definition of a mole?A.\hspace{1em}1 mole is the number of H2_{2}2​O molecules in 18.02 g of H2_{2}2​OB.\hspace{1em}1 mole of Fe has a mass equal to the relative atomic mass of Fe in gramsC.\hspace{1em}1 mole of any substance contains 6.02×\times×1023^{23}23particlesD.\hspace{1em}1 mole is the number of H2_{2}2​molecules in 1.01 g ofHX2\ce{H2}HX2​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:1 mole is the number ofHX2\ce{H_{2}}HX2​molecules in 2.02 g ofHX2\ce{H_{2}}HX2​. Choices A, B, and C all conform to the definition of a mole.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Which of the following subshells contains the highest energy?A.2s\hspace{1em}2s2sB.2p\hspace{1em}2p2pC.2d\hspace{1em}2d2dD.3d\hspace{1em}3d3d
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to Aufbau’s principle, the arrangement of subshell in increasing energy is1s2s2p3s3p4s3d4p1s\  2s\  2p\  3s\  3p\  4s\  3d\  4p1s2s2p3s3p4s3d4p.Therefore, options A and B are both incorrect.Option C is incorrect because2d2d2ddoes not exist.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Which of the following systems represents a homogeneous mixture?A.\hspace{1.em}Oil floating on waterB.\hspace{1.em}Salt dissolved in water at25∘C25{\,}^\circ\textrm{C}25∘CC.\hspace{1.em}Ice cubes in liquid waterD.\hspace{1.em}Sand mixed with iron filings
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​A homogeneous mixture has uniform composition and properties throughout, with components mixed at the molecular level. Salt dissolved in water forms a solution where sodium and chloride ions are uniformly distributed among water molecules, creating a single phase with consistent properties. Oil and water form separate layers (heterogeneous), ice and liquid water exist as different phases (heterogeneous), and sand with iron filings shows visible distinct components (heterogeneous). The key distinction is whether the mixture appears uniform at the molecular level.

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Which of the following is an example of a mixture?A.\hspace{1em}SucroseB.\hspace{1em}Distilled waterC.\hspace{1em}SeawaterD.\hspace{1em}Sodium chloride
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Seawater is a mixture of water and salts. Sucrose, distilled water, and sodium chloride are all examples of compounds.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Which of the following is a characteristic of liquids?A.\hspace{1em}Their particles vibrate about fixed positions.B.\hspace{1em}They can be compressed easily.C.\hspace{1em}They take up the shape of the container they are in.D.\hspace{1em}The particles move freely and quickly in all directions.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Liquids have an indefinite shape (take the shape of the container) but have a definite volume (are incompressible).

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Which of the following statements isfalse?I.\hspace{1em}Electrons have greater mass than protons and neutronsII.\hspace{1em}Protons and neutrons are in the nucleusIII.\hspace{1em}Protons and electrons are charged subatomic particlesIV.\hspace{1em}Electrons are located outside the nucleusA.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and IV onlyC.\hspace{1em}II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I only
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Electrons have negligible mass.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: What is the term for the region where there is the highest probability of finding an electron?A.\hspace{1em}OrbitalB.\hspace{1em}NucleusC.\hspace{1em}Orbital diagramD.\hspace{1em}Orbit
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice B is incorrect because electrons are not located in the nucleus. Choice C is incorrect because an orbital diagram is just a representation of electrons in an orbital. Choice D is incorrect because electrons do not have a fixed orbita around the nucleus in the quantum mechanical model. Choice A is the correct answer: orbitals are areas/ regions in space where the probability of finding an electron is very high.

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Which of the following is the correct electron configuration of a typical sodium ion?A.\hspace{1em}[Ne]3s1\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^1[Ne]3s1B.\hspace{1em}[Ne]3s2\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^2[Ne]3s2C.\hspace{1em}[Ne]\ce{[Ne]}[Ne]D.\hspace{1em}[Ne]2s1\ce{[Ne]}\, 2s^1[Ne]2s1
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The atomic number of sodium is 11. Its electron configuration follows the Aufbau principle, filling the electron sublevels from lowest to highest energy.Na\ce{Na}Na:1s22s22p63s11s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^11s22s22p63s1This can be rewritten in noble gas or shorthand notation by observing that the noble gas neon has the same core electron filling(Ne:1s22s22p6)(\ce{Ne}:\, 1s^2 2s^2 2p^6)(Ne:1s22s22p6).  The electron configuration of neutral sodium can be rewritten asNa\ce{Na}Na:[Ne]3s1\ [\ce{Ne}]\,3s^1[Ne]3s1The atom loses one electron to become a stable ion with a charge of 1+ (10 electrons). The removed electron is from the valence shell (the3s3s3selectron).  The electron configuration of sodium ion isNaX+\ce{Na^+}NaX+:[Ne]\ [\ce{Ne}][Ne]Alternatively, notice that sodium ion is isoelectronic with neon so mush share its electron configuration.

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Which of the following methods is used to separate a solid from a liquid in a heterogeneous mixture?A.\hspace{1em}DistillationB.\hspace{1em}FiltrationC.\hspace{1em}CrystallisationD.\hspace{1em}Sublimation
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:An insoluble solid can be separated from a liquid by means of filtration. Distillation is used to separate homogeneous liquid mixtures (solid soluble in a liquid or two miscible liquids) with different boiling points. Sublimation is a technique for separating mixtures with volatile components that can undergo sublimation. Crystallisation is a separation technique that uses solubility properties to separate a solid from a solution.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: The nuclear symbol for an isotope of iodine isX53125X2532125I\ce{^{125}_{53}I}X53125​X2532125​I. Which of the following is correct about the isotope?Atomic NumberMass NumberNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electrons\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}53125537253\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}53125725353\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}12553537272\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}12553535372
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/42307e35-8608-4db2-8772-65b60ebe1e65/images/67b4491b-77e7-4bdb-ab9a-3bfc9f01f1dd/2.1-48.png)

The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons. For a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons.

list.title: Question 14
list.content: For a fixed mass of gas at a constant temperature, what happens to the volume if the pressure of the gas is doubled?A.\hspace{1em}Volume will remain the sameB.\hspace{1em}Volume will doubleC.\hspace{1em}Volume will be halvedD.\hspace{1em}Volume will increase exponentially
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:One of the laws of gases states that, for a fixed amount of gas held at a constant temperature, the volume of a gas is inversely proportional to its pressure.

list.title: Question 15
list.content: The atom of an element Q has an atomic number of 27 and a mass number of 60. Which of the following statements is true about the subatomic particles of the atom of element Q?I.\hspace{1em}Atom of element Q has 27 electrons and 60 protonsII.\hspace{1em}Atom of element Q has 27 protons and 27 electronsIII.\hspace{1em}Atom of element Q has 27 electrons and 60 neutronsIV.\hspace{1em}Atom of element Q has 27 protons and 33 neutronsA.\hspace{1em}I and IV onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and IV onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The atomic number is the number of protons. The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons. For a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: A liquid has a boiling point of−185∘C-185 ^\circ\mathrm{C}−185∘C. What is this temperature in Kelvin?A.\hspace{1em}88 KB.\hspace{1em}−88-88−88KC.\hspace{1em}458 KD.\hspace{1em}−458-458−458K
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Add273273273to the temperature in Celsius to convert it to Kelvin.−185∘C+273=88K-185^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 88\, \mathrm{K}−185∘C+273=88K. The rest of the choices are incorrect.

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Which of the following conditions makes gases deviate from ideal behavior?A.\hspace{1em}High pressure and high temperatureB.\hspace{1em}Low pressure and low temperatureC.\hspace{1em}High pressure and low temperatureD.\hspace{1em}Low pressure and high temperature
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At high pressures and very low temperatures, the inter-particle forces strengthen, spaces between particles decrease causing the deviation from ideal gas behaviourPVnRT\dfrac{PV}{nRT}nRTPV​> 1.

list.title: Question 18
list.content: Which compound has the largest molar mass?A.\hspace{1em}FeSOX4\ce{FeSO4}FeSOX4​B.\hspace{1em}KX2CrX2OX7\ce{K2Cr2O7}KX2​CrX2​OX7​C.\hspace{1em}KMnOX4\ce{KMnO4}KMnOX4​D.\hspace{1em}(NHX4)X3POX4\ce{(NH4)3PO4}(NHX4​)X3​POX4​

list.title: Question 19
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice A is incorrect because the orbital diagram does not satisfy Hund's rule wherein all orbitals must be singly occupied before pairing.Choice B is incorrect because Pauli's Exclusion principle is not obeyed by having two electrons with the same spin in one orbital.Choice C is correct because, according to Hund's rule, the orbitals must be half-filled first before pairing, and the paired orbital must have electrons in an opposite spin.Choice D is incorrect because the2s2s2sorbital must be filled first before filling the 2p orbital, as illustrated by Aufbau's Principle.

list.title: Question 20
list.content: Which of the below gives the correct electron configuration of aCrX3+\ce{Cr^3+}CrX3+ion?A.[Ar]4s13d2\hspace{1em}\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^1 3d^2[Ar]4s13d2B.[Ar]4s23d1\hspace{1em}\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^2 3d^1[Ar]4s23d1C.[Ar]3d3\hspace{1em}\ce{[Ar]}\, 3d^3[Ar]3d3D.[Ar]3d4\hspace{1em}\ce{[Ar]}\, 3d^4[Ar]3d4
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Electron configuration of theCr\ce{Cr}Cratom is[Ar]4s13d5\ce{[Ar]\,} 4s^1\,3d^5[Ar]4s13d5.
The loss of onesand twodelectrons results in[Ar]3d3\ce{[Ar]}\, 3d^3[Ar]3d3configuration.

list.title: Question 21
list.content: Which of the following is not a physical property of an isotope of an element with fewer neutrons in its atom?A.\hspace{1em}Lower massB.\hspace{1em}Faster rate of diffusionC.\hspace{1em}Higher densityD.\hspace{1em}Lower melting and boiling points
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Isotopes with fewer neutrons will have a lower density

list.title: Question 22
list.content: Isoelectronic species are atoms or ions with the same number of electrons. Which of the following are isoelectronic species?I.AlX3+\ce{Al^3+}AlX3+II.MgX2+\ce{Mg^2+}MgX2+III.OX2−\ce{O^2-}OX2−A.\hspace{1em}I and IIB.\hspace{1em}II and IIIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The correct answer is that all three species are isoelectronic. Isoelectronic species have the same number of electrons despite being different elements or ions. Aluminum in its neutral state has 13 electrons, but when it loses three electrons to formAlX3+,\ce{Al^{3+}},AlX3+,it has 10 remaining electrons. Magnesium has 12 electrons when neutral, and when it loses two to formMgX2+,\ce{Mg^{2+}},MgX2+,it also has 10 electrons. Oxygen, on the other hand, has 8 electrons in its neutral state, but when it gains two to formOX2−,\ce{O^{2-}},OX2−,it reaches a total of 10 electrons. Since all three ions have ten electrons, they are isoelectronic.

list.title: Question 23
list.content: Which equation represents the second ionization energy forCu\ce{Cu}Cu?A.CuX2+(g)→CuX3+(g)+eX−\hspace{1em}\ce{Cu^{2+}(g) -> Cu^{3+}(g) + e^-}CuX2+(g)​CuX3+(g)+eX−B.CuX+(g)→CuX2+(g)+eX−\hspace{1em}\ce{Cu^+(g) -> Cu^{2+}(g) + e^-}CuX+(g)​CuX2+(g)+eX−C.CuX2+(g)+eX−→CuX+(g)\hspace{1em}\ce{Cu^{2+}(g) + e^- -> Cu^+(g)}CuX2+(g)+eX−​CuX+(g)D.Cu(g)→2eX−+CuX2+(g)\hspace{1em}\ce{Cu(g) -> 2 e^- + Cu^{2+}(g)}Cu(g)​2eX−+CuX2+(g)
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Second ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of singly positive gaseous ions.

list.title: Question 24
list.content: Which of the following statements is true?A.\hspace{1em}The empirical formula shows only the type of each atom in a molecule.B.\hspace{1em}The molecular formula is always the same as the empirical formula.C.\hspace{1em}Organic molecules often have different empirical and molecular formulas.D.\hspace{1em}The empirical formula is always greater than the molecular formula.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The empirical formula shows the simplest whole-number ratio of elements in a compound. The empirical formula can sometimes be the same as the molecular formula. Choices A, B, and D are all false statements.

list.title: Question 25
list.content: Cobalt is an important cofactor that often inhibits enzyme activity involved in cellular respiration, such as catalase.Using the complete electron configuration, determine the electron configuration ofCoX2+.\ce{Co^2+}.CoX2+.[1]Draw the orbital diagram of the3d3d3delectrons ofCo\ce{Co}Co.[1]

list.title: Question 26
list.content: The isotopes of carbonX12X2212C\ce{^{12}C}X12​X2212​CandX13X2213C\ce{^{13}C}X13​X2213​C:I.\hspace{1em}have the same atomic numberII.\hspace{1em}have the same physical propertiesIII.\hspace{1em}have the same chemical propertiesA.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons that differ only in terms of their physical properties.

list.title: Question 27
list.content: Which of the following requires a chemical reaction to be separated into simpler substances?A.\hspace{1em}Homogeneous mixturesB.\hspace{1em}Heterogeneous mixturesC.\hspace{1em}AlloysD.\hspace{1em}Compounds
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Mixtures, including alloys, can be separated by physical methods like filtration, evaporation, or distillation. Compounds must be chemically separated.

list.title: Question 28
list.content: How many electrons are there inX1735X217235ClX−\ce{^{35}_{17}Cl^-}X1735​X217235​ClX−?A.\hspace{1em}17B.\hspace{1em}18C.\hspace{1em}35D.\hspace{1em}36
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The atomic number is 17, hence there are 17 protons and 17 electrons in the atom (since atom is neutral). The ion with a charge of (1-) means that the atom has gained 1 electron and therefore, contains 18 electrons.

list.title: Question 29
list.content: Which statements about the hydrogen emission spectrum are correct?I.The lines converge at higher energiesII.The lines converge at higher frequenciesIII.The lines converge at higher wavelengthsA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The lines converge as energy levels increase (increased distance from the nucleus).Higher energies result in higher frequencies.

list.title: Question 30
list.content: Which of the following correctly classifiesSX8\ce{S8}SX8​and water?A.SX8\hspace{1em}\ce{S8}SX8​and water are both compounds.B.SX8\hspace{1em}\ce{S8}SX8​and water are both elements.C.SX8\hspace{1em}\ce{S8}SX8​is a compound, and water is an element.D.SX8\hspace{1em}\ce{S8}SX8​is an element, and water is a compound.
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​SX8\ce{S8}SX8​is an element because it consists of only sulfur atoms bonded together. Even though it has multiple atoms, all of them are sulfur, so it's not a compound–\text{--}–it's just a molecular form of an element (one of sulfur's allotropes), in the same way diatomicHX2\ce{H2}HX2​is an element.WaterHX2O\ce{H2O}HX2​Ois a compound because it contains two different elements (hydrogen and oxygen) chemically bonded together in a fixed ratio of2:1.2:1.2:1.This fixed ratio is what makes water a compound rather than a mixture.

list.title: Question 31

list.title: Question 32
list.content: Calculate the number of moles in20.520.520.5grams of sodium phosphate (NaX3POX4\ce{Na3PO4}NaX3​POX4​).A.\hspace{1em}0.125 molB.\hspace{1em}1.25 molC.\hspace{1em}12.5 molD.\hspace{1em}125 mol
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The molar mass of sodium phosphate is 163.94 g mol−1^{-1}−1. Divide the mass (20.5 g) of sodium phosphate by the molar mass to calculate the number of moles of the compound. The rest of the choices are incorrect.

list.title: Question 33
list.content: The following table shows the number of subatomic particles present in five species.SpeciesNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsR888S8810T9108U101010V101210Which two species are isotopes of the same element?A.\hspace{1em}R and SB.\hspace{1em}S and TC.\hspace{1em}T and UD.\hspace{1em}U and V
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Isotopes have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.Species R and S have the same number of protons but also the same number of neutrons so cannot be isotopes. S is an anion of element R.Species T is the only species in the table with 9 protons so cannot have an isotope with another species in the table because it is a different element.This leaves speciesU and Vwhich both have the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons so they are isotopes.

The first electron is lost from the3s3s3sorbital; thus, the ground state electron configuration for the first ion formed is1s22s22p6.1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6.1s22s22p6.

list.title: Question 35
list.content: Which of the following statements aboutX2351X223251V\ce{^{51}_{23}V}X2351​X223251​Vare correct?I.It has 23 protonsII.It has 51 nucleonsIII.It has a condensed electron configuration of [Ne]4s23d34s^2\,3d^34s23d3A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Vanadium has an atomic number of 23 therefore statement I is true. It also has a mass number of 51, therefore statement II is also true as nucleons include both protons and neutrons. Statement III is false as the closest noble gas is Ar, not Ne. The correct condensed electron configuration would be [Ar]4s23d34s^2\,3d^34s23d3. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

list.title: Question 36
list.content: Hydrogen exhibits two emission lines,D1D1D1andD2D2D2.D1D1D1has a wavelength of656nm656 \textrm{\ nm}656nmandD2D2D2has a frequency of6.17×1014s−16.17\times 10^{14}\textrm{\ s}^{-1}6.17×1014s−1.Calculate the frequency of theD1D1D1emission line of hydrogen.[1]Calculate the wavelength of theD2D2D2emission line of hydrogen.[1]Compare the two emission lines, and using the IB Chemistry data booklet, suggest which of the emission lines is most likely to be red.[2]

list.title: Question 37
list.content: Which statement about ionization energies isincorrect\textbf{incorrect}incorrect?A.\hspace{1em}First ionization energies are always higher than second ionization energiesB.\hspace{1em}It represents the energy required to remove electronsC.\hspace{1em}The general trend is that first ionization energies increase across a periodD.\hspace{1em}The general trend is that first ionization energies decrease down a group
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Second ionization energies are higher than the first as the electrons are being removed from a positive ion resulting in a stronger electrostatic attraction.First ionization energies do increase across a period due to increasing nuclear charge.First ionization energies also decrease down a group due to increased shielding (number of shells).

list.title: Question 38
list.content: What happens to an atom if it loses two electrons?A.\hspace{1em}It becomes a positively charged cation with a charge of2+.2+.2+.B.\hspace{1em}It becomes a positively charged anion with a charge of2+.2+.2+.C.\hspace{1em}It becomes a negatively charged anion with a charge of2−.2-.2−.D.\hspace{1em}It becomes a negatively charged cation with a charge of2−.2-.2−.
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​When an atom loses two electrons, it becomes a positively charged cation with a charge of2+.2+.2+.Atoms are electrically neutral when they have equal numbers of protons and electrons. However, when electrons are removed, the balance shifts, leaving more positively charged protons than negatively charged electrons. The result is the formation of a cation, or positively charged ion. Since two electrons are lost, the charge on the resulting ion is2+,2+,2+,indicating that the number of protons exceeds the number of electrons by two.

list.title: Question 39
list.content: An atom has the nuclear symbolX1735X217235X.\ce{^{35}_{17}X}.X1735​X217235​X.Which statement is correct?A.\hspace{1em}It has 17 protons, 17 neutrons, and 17 electrons.B.\hspace{1em}It has 17 protons, 18 neutrons, and 17 electrons.C.\hspace{1em}It has 17 protons, 18 neutrons, and 18 electrons.D.\hspace{1em}It has 18 protons, 17 neutrons, and 17 electrons.
list.markScheme: B`Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​When identifying a isotope, the chemical symbol is written alsoXZAX2Z2AX\ce{_Z^A X}XZA​X2Z2A​XwhereZZZis the atomic number, or number of protons andAAAis the mass number, thes sum of the number of protons and neutrons.In the isotopeX1735X217235X,\ce{^{35}_{17}X},X1735​X217235​X,the atomic number is 17.  There are 17 protons in the nucleus. The mass number is 35. This is the sum of protons and neutrons. To find the number of neutrons, subtract the atomic number from the mass number:35−17=1835 - 17 = 1835−17=18neutrons. Since this is a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons, meaning it also has 17 electrons.

list.title: Question 40
list.content: Which of the following substances would have the lowest mass?A.\hspace{1em}2.50 molesHX2O\ce{H2O}HX2​OB.\hspace{1em}2.50 molesCHX4\ce{CH4}CHX4​C.\hspace{1em}2.00 molesSOX2\ce{SO2}SOX2​D.\hspace{1em}2.00 molesCOX2\ce{CO2}COX2​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:m(CHX4)=n×M=(2.50mol)(16.05gmol−1)=40.1g\ce{m(CH_4)} = n \times M = (2.50\,\text{mol})(16.05\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 40.1\,\text{g}m(CHX4​)=n×M=(2.50mol)(16.05gmol−1)=40.1gThe other compounds would have a greater mass.m(HX2O)=(2.50mol)(18.02gmol−1)=45.05g\ce{m(H2O)} = (2.50\,\text{mol})(18.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 45.05\,\text{g}m(HX2​O)=(2.50mol)(18.02gmol−1)=45.05gm(SOX2)=(2.00moles)(64.07gmol−1)=128.14g\ce{m(SO2)} = (2.00\,\text{moles})(64.07\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = 128.14\,\text{g}m(SOX2​)=(2.00moles)(64.07gmol−1)=128.14gm(COX2)=(2.00moles)(44.01gmol−1)=88.02g\ce{m(CO2)} = (2.00\,\text{moles})(44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =88.02\,\text{g}m(COX2​)=(2.00moles)(44.01gmol−1)=88.02g

list.title: Question 41
list.content: State the full electron configurations of anN\ce{N}Natom andO\ce{O}Oatom.[2]Draw the orbital diagrams for anN\ce{N}Natom andO\ce{O}Oatom.[2]Compare and explain the difference between the first ionization energy of oxygen and nitrogen.[3]

list.title: Question 42
list.content: What will happen to the frequency of moving light particles if the wavelength is doubled, assuming the velocity is constant?A.\hspace{1em}The frequency will be doubledB.\hspace{1em}The frequency will decrease by halfC.\hspace{1em}The frequency will not be affectedD.\hspace{1em}The frequency will increase by four
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:There is an inverse relationship between frequency and wavelength. If the wavelength is doubled, the frequency will decrease by half. Therefore, Choices A, C, and D are all incorrect.

list.title: Question 43
list.content: Which of the following statement(s) is (are) true?I.The emission spectra are produced from a release of energy of excited electronsII.No two electrons in one atom have the same set of quantum numbersIII.The electrons in an orbital must have an opposite spinA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement I is true because emission spectra are produced when photons are released from excited electrons returning to lower energy levels.Statement II is true because this is Pauli's Exclusion principle.Statement III is also true because it is included in Pauli's Exclusion principle.

list.title: Question 44
list.content: Bromine has 2 stable isotopes: bromine-79 and bromine-81. What is the relative atomic mass of bromine (Br)?IsotopeRelative AbundanceAtomic Mass79^{79}79Br50.69%78.9281^{81}81Br49.31%80.92A.\hspace{1em}78.5B.\hspace{1em}80.1C.\hspace{1em}81.2D.\hspace{1em}79.9
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Relative atomic mass ofBr=(0.5069)(78.92)+(0.4931)(80.92)=79.Br = (0.5069)(78.92) + (0.4931)(80.92) = 79.Br=(0.5069)(78.92)+(0.4931)(80.92)=79.9. The rest of the choices are incorrect relative atomic masses of bromine.Alternative Method‾\underline{\textrm{Alternative Method}}Alternative Method​:79^{79}79Br atomic mass can be rounded up to 7981^{81}81Br atomic mass can be rounded up to 81Since the relative abundance of both isotopes is about 50% each, the relative atomic mass of Bromine should be close to 80. Choice D corresponds to that estimation.

list.title: Question 45
list.content: Refer to the following chemical equation:2NOX2(g)→NX2OX4(g)\ce{2NO2 (g) -> N2O4 (g)}2NOX2​(g)​NX2​OX4​(g)At the same temperature and pressure,25.0cm325.0\,\text{cm}^325.0cm3of nitrogen dioxide (NOX2\ce{NO2}NOX2​) gas is completely converted to dinitrogen tetroxide (NX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​) gas. What will be the volume ofNX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​produced?A.10.0cm3\hspace{1em} 10.0\,\text{cm}^310.0cm3B.12.5cm3\hspace{1em} 12.5\,\text{cm}^312.5cm3C.25.0cm3\hspace{1em} 25.0\,\text{cm}^325.0cm3D.50.0cm3\hspace{1em} 50.0\,\text{cm}^350.0cm3
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Based on the balanced chemical equation, the number of moles ofNOX2\ce{NO2}NOX2​is twice that ofNX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​. Avogadro's law states that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles of the gas present(252=12.5)\left(\dfrac{25}{2} = 12.5\right)(225​=12.5).

list.content: How many molecules are there in 4.80 mol of glucose?A.\hspace{1em}2.89×\times×1024^{24}24moleculesB.\hspace{1em}2.50×\times×1024^{24}24moleculesC.\hspace{1em}3.50×\times×1024^{24}24moleculesD.\hspace{1em}2.59×\times×1024^{24}24molecules

list.title: Question 48
list.content: Which of the following statements correctly describes a compound?I.A compound can be physically separated into simpler substances.II.In a pure compound, the boiling point, melting point and solubility are uniform.III.Each compound has a fixed chemical formula in which the subscripts remain constant.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Statement I is incorrect because compounds cannot be broken down by physical means, only by chemical reactions. Statement II is correct because compounds have fixed physical properties (boiling point, melting point, solubility) due to their uniform composition. Statement III is correct because compounds obey the Law of Definite Proportions, they have fixed chemical formulas where the subscripts do not change (e.g.,HX2O\ce{H2O}HX2​Ois always water).

list.markScheme: f=cλ=3.00×108m s−11.68m=1.79×108s−1✓f = \dfrac{c}{\lambda} = \dfrac{3.00\times 10^8 \,\text{m s}^{-1}}{1.68\,\text{m}} = \answer{1.79\times 10^8\,\text{s}^{-1}}\,\checkmarkf=λc​=1.68m3.00×108m s−1​=1.79×108s−1​✓λ=cf=3.00×108m s−12.00×108s−1=1.50m✓\lambda = \dfrac{c}{f} = \dfrac{3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}}{2.00\times 10^8\,\text{s}^{-1}} = \answer{1.50\,\text{m}}\,\checkmarkλ=fc​=2.00×108s−13.00×108m s−1​=1.50m​✓As you increase the wavelength, you decrease the value of the frequency. Therefore, the frequency is inversely proportional to the wavelength.✓\checkmark✓

list.title: Question 50
list.content:
Based on the graph below, choose the correct statement that describes the relationship between pressure and temperature for a fixed mass and volume of a gas?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5b7d708-dada-487b-9f1b-ee2fb3f45b47/images/02187be4-3809-445d-b70e-4ae6dde3de0d/1.3-36.png)

A.\hspace{1em}Pressure is inversely proportional to the absolute temperatureB.\hspace{1em}Pressure is directly proportional to the square of the absolute temperatureC.\hspace{1em}Pressure is inversely proportional to the square of the absolute temperatureD.\hspace{1em}Pressure is directly proportional to the absolute temperature
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The graph of P vs T shows a linear graph (straight line passing through the origin) that rises upward. This graph shows that P is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. As the absolute temperature increases, the pressure of the gas also increases.

list.title: Question 51
list.content: Which statement about the mass spectrum of an element is correct?I.The tallest peak always represents the heaviest isotope.II.The relative abundance of an isotope is indicated by its peak height.III.The mass/charge ratio is displayed on the horizontal axis.A.\hspace{1em}I and IIB.\hspace{1em}II and IIIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​In a mass spectrum, the horizontal axis shows the mass–to–\text{--to--}–to–charge ratio(m/z),(m/z),(m/z),and the height of each peak reflects the relative abundance of that isotope. This means the taller the peak, the more abundant the isotope is in the sample: the tallest peak is the most abundant isotope.

list.title: Question 52
list.content: The atom of element X has a mass number of 127 and has 74 neutrons. The ion derived from X has 54 electrons.Calculate the number of protons of element X.[1]State the nuclear symbol of the ion formed (refer to the periodic table).[2]An isotope of X has a mass number of 132. Determine the number of neutrons in its atom.[2]
list.markScheme: Number of protons = 127 – 74 =53✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Number of protons (ZZZ) = mass number(AAA) – number of neutrons(NNN)Nuclear symbol:53127I_{53}^{127}\textrm{I}53127​I−^{-}−✓\checkmark✓✓\checkmark✓Note:Onemarkforthechargeandonemarkforthenuclearsymbol.\textit{Note: One mark for the charge and one mark for the nuclear symbol.}Note: One mark for the charge and one mark for the nuclear symbol.Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The atomic number of the element X is 53 (number of protons). Therefore, it corresponds to iodine with a mass numberA=127A= 127A=127(referring to the periodic table). The number of electrons in the ion formed is 54. This means that the atom has gained one electron, and the overall charge of the ion is(1−).(1-).(1−).Since it is an isotope, the number of protons is the same for all atoms of isotopes of the same element.✓\checkmark✓Number ofneutrons=132−53=\textrm{neutrons} = 132 - 53 = \neutrons=132−53=79 neutrons✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​number of neutrons = mass number−-−number of protons

list.title: Question 53
list.content: The following table shows the number of subatomic particles present in five different species.SpeciesNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsR888S11810T9108U101010V121012Which species are ions?A.\hspace{1em}R and SB.\hspace{1em}S and TC.\hspace{1em}T and UD.\hspace{1em}U and V
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Ions of an element do not have the same numbers of protons and electrons.Only speciesS and Tdo not have the same number of protons and electrons, so they are ions.Note: S and T are not ions of the same element, but both have nonzero charge so are considered ions.

list.title: Question 54
list.content: What is the ground state electron configuration of an atom of an element in Group 16 of the periodic table?A.1s22s22p2\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^21s22s22p2B.1s22s22p4\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^41s22s22p4C.1s22s22p63s23p64s23d6\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^61s22s22p63s23p64s23d6D.1s22s22p63s23p64s23d104p6\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^61s22s22p63s23p64s23d104p6

list.title: Question 55
list.content: Eugenol is an oily, aromatic liquid extracted from essential oils such as clove and cinnamon. The molecular formula of eugenol isCX10HX12OX2.\ce{C_{10}H_{12}O_{2}}.CX10​HX12​OX2​.Calculate the molar mass of eugenol.[1]Determine the percentage by mass of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in eugenol.[3]Predict the simplest, whole−-−number ratio of the atoms in eugenol.[1]
list.markScheme: Molar mass: M(C10_{10}10​H12_{12}12​O2_{2}2​)=12.01×10+1.01×12+16.00×2=120.1+12.12+32.00== 12.01 \times 10 + 1.01 \times 12 +16.00 \times 2 = 120.1 + 12.12 + 32.00 =\=12.01×10+1.01×12+16.00×2=120.1+12.12+32.00=164.22g mol−1164.22 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}164.22g mol−1✓\checkmark✓Percentage by mass% C =(120.1164.22)\left(\dfrac{120.1}{164.22}\right)(164.22120.1​)(100)  =73.13 %✓\checkmark✓% H =(12.12164.22)\left(\dfrac{12.12}{164.22}\right)(164.2212.12​)(100) =7.38 %✓\checkmark✓% O =(32.00164.22)\left(\dfrac{32.00}{164.22}\right)(164.2232.00​)(100) =19.49 %✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Divide the total mass of atoms of each element by the molar mass of eugenol and multiply it by 100The molecular formula of eugenol is C10_{10}10​H12_{12}12​O2_{2}2​. Therefore, its empirical formula is C5_{5}5​H6_{6}6​O✓\checkmark✓(ratio C : H : O = 5 : 6 : 1)Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Divide by the highest common factor (2) to determine the simplest whole number ratio

list.title: Question 56
list.content: Deuterium is an isotope of hydrogen that contains one proton, one neutron, and one electron.Complete the following table.[2]ProtonsNeutronsElectronsRelative chargeRelative mass∼11836\sim\dfrac{1}{1836}∼18361​Location\\Using the following data, calculate the relative atomic mass of hydrogen correct to five decimal places, showing your work.[2]IsotopeRelative abundanceHydrogen-199.980%Deuterium0.012%Hydrogen-30.008%\\Describe the emission spectrum of the hydrogen atom.[2]Outline the difference between a continuous spectrum and a line spectrum.[1]Suggest how your answer to (b)(i) shows that energy levels are quantized.[1]
list.markScheme: All correct, two✓\checkmark✓Allow one✓\checkmark✓for one correctProtonsNeutronsElectronsRelative charge+10−1-1−1Relative mass11∼11836\sim \dfrac{1}{1836}∼18361​LocationNucleusNucleusOutside the nucleus\\99.980100×1+0.012100×2+0.008100×3=1.00028\dfrac{99.980}{100} \times 1 + \dfrac{0.012}{100} \times 2 + \dfrac{0.008}{100} \times 3 = 1.0002810099.980​×1+1000.012​×2+1000.008​×3=1.00028Correct working✓\checkmark✓Correct answer✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To calculate the relative atomic mass, we need to multiply the isotopic masses with their relative abundances and add them together.A series of lines✓\checkmark✓that converge at higher energies.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The hydrogen emission spectrum has a series of lines that get closer together at one end. These lines represent wavelengths of light that are emitted when an electron jumps between energy levels. As electrons move further from the nucleus, the energy levels become closer in energy so the energy difference decreases and the lines are closer together and converge.In a continuous spectrum, all wavelengths are possible. In a line spectrum, only certain wavelengths are possible.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:In the hydrogen emission spectrum, only certain wavelengths of light equal to the energy difference between two energy levels are possible, forming a line spectrum. A continuous spectrum is not restricted to certain wavelengths, rather all wavelengths are possible.Since the lines are discrete and represent electron jumps between energy levels, this shows us that the energy levels are quantized.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The hydrogen emission spectrum is a line spectrum that only contains certain wavelengths of light. The lines represent an electron releasing energy as it drops to a lower energy level, equal to the energy difference between the two energy levels. In order for the lines to be discrete, the conclusion must be made that energy levels are quantized.

list.title: Question 61
list.content: Which of the following statements about nitrogen is correct?I.Oxygen has a higher first ionization energy than nitrogen.II.There is a large increase between the5th5^{\text{th}}5thand6th6^{\text{th}}6thionization energies of nitrogen.III.Phosphorus has a lower first ionization energy than nitrogen.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The electron configuration for oxygen is1s22s22p41s^2\,2s^2\,2p^41s22s22p4whereas nitrogen is1s22s22p31s^2\,2s^2\,2p^31s22s22p3. Due to the increased stability of nitrogen's half-filledppp-shell, more energy is required to remove an electron from a nitrogen atom than an oxygen atom. Statement I is incorrect.Statement II is correct as nitrogen has 5 valence electrons and the 6th electron is removed from a shell closer to the nucleus.Statement III is correct as first ionization energy decreases down a group.

list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​In mass spectrometry, them/zm/zm/zvalue represents the mass to charge ratio of an ion. Most ions formed in a mass spectrometer are singly charged (1+), so them/zm/zm/zvalue is equal to the mass number of the isotope. A peak at 40 suggests an ion with a mass of 40 and a charge of+1.+1.+1.Argon has a common isotope,X40X2240Ar\ce{^{40}Ar}X40​X2240​Arin line with its relative atomic mass of 39.95.

list.content: Fluorine isotopes are used in PET scans to detect cancer. A sample used in one scan contains two isotopes of fluorine:Fluorine isotopeMass (amu)% abundanceIsotope 118.0065%Isotope 2X35%The relative atomic mass of the fluorine in this sample is 18.35.Determine the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in a neutral atom of isotope 1.[1]State the relative mass and charge of each subatomic particle.[2]Calculate the mass of isotope 2.[1]Predict and explain one physical property that differs between the two isotopes.[2]
list.markScheme: protons 9, neutrons 9,ANDelectrons 9✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The atomic number of fluorine is 9, so every fluorine atom has 9 protons. Isotope 1 has a mass number of 18, so it contains18−9=918 - 9 = 918−9=9neutrons. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons, so it has 9 electrons.charges: proton = +1, neutron = 0ANDelectron =−1✓-1\ \checkmark−1✓masses: proton = 1, neutron = 1ANDelectron∼0\sim 0∼0/ negligible✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The SI units for the masses and charges of the elementary particles are in the data booklet.Neutrons are uncharged.  Protons and electrons have charges±1.602177×10−19textC.\pm 1.602177\times 10^{-19}text{ C}.±1.602177×10−19textC.Dividing by the fundamental unit of charge gives the typical charges: proton = +1, neutron = 0, and electron =−1.-1.−1.Neutrons and protons have similar masses:mn=1.674927×10−27kgm_n = 1.674927\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg}mn​=1.674927×10−27kgandmp=1.672622×10−27kgm_p = 1.672622\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg}mp​=1.672622×10−27kgwhile electrons are more than one thousand times smaller,me=9.109384×10−31kg.m_e = 9.109384\times 10^{-31}\text{ kg}.me​=9.109384×10−31kg.Dividing by the fundamental unit of mass, 1/12th^\text{th}ththe mass of a carbon–\text{--}–12 atom,1.66054×10−27kg,1.66054\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg},1.66054×10−27kg,the masses in atomic mass units can be determined: proton = 1.0073, neutron = 1.0087, and electron = 0.0005.  In IB Chemistry, we typically use the simpler values proton = 1, neutron = 1, and electron∼0\sim 0∼0.18.35=(0.65)(18.00)+0.35x;x=19.0018.35 = (0.65)(18.00) + 0.35x\ ;\quad x = 19.0018.35=(0.65)(18.00)+0.35x;x=19.00Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The relative atomic mass is the weighted average of the isotopic masses.Ar=65×18.00+35×x100=18.35A_r = \dfrac{65 \times 18.00 + 35 \times x}{100} = 18.35Ar​=10065×18.00+35×x​=18.35x=19.00x = 19.00x=19.00any one of the following physical properties:isotope 2 has a slower diffusion rate✓\checkmark✓isotope 2 has a higher density✓\checkmark✓isotope 2 has a (slightly) higher boiling/melting point✓\checkmark✓isotope 2 has a higher mass✓\checkmark✓Allow the opposite about isotope 1.Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Even though both isotopes of fluorine behave the same chemically, physical properties can vary due to their different masses. Isotope 2 has one extra neutron, making it slightly heavier.This would lead to a slower diffusion rate (heavier atoms move more slowly), higher density, and a slightly higher boiling or melting point.

list.title: Question 72
list.content:
In the following paper chromatogram using water as the solvent, which component of the mixture (1 or 2) has the greatest affinity for the mobile phase, and what is the identity of the mobile phase?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95da42b0-14db-4e30-b256-79f959578499/images/6e277958-c3bb-46b5-8887-07823180a277/CH0851.png)

A.\hspace{1em}1; waterB.\hspace{1em}1; paperC.\hspace{1em}2; waterD.\hspace{1em}2; paper
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The student must first recall that the component with the greatest affinity for the mobile phase will travel the farthest in paper chromatography. In this case, spot 2 is the farthest from the starting line, so it has the greatest affinity for the mobile phase.In paper chromatography, the mobile phase is always the solvent (water, in this case), while the stationary phase is the paper.This question is categorized as easy because the student must only recall basic definitions and concepts for paper chromatography.

list.title: Question 73
list.content: Which of the following pairs of terms describe the shape of ans−s-s−orbital and the relative energy of ad−d-d−orbital?Shapeofs–orbital\enskip\textbf{Shape of \textit{s--}orbital}\enskipShape ofs–orbitalRelativeenergyofd–orbital\enskip \textbf{Relative energy of \textit{d--}orbital}\enskipRelative energy ofd–orbital\hspace{1em}A.\hspace{1em}SphericalLow\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}Dumbbell−-−shapeHigh\hspace{1em}C.\hspace{1em}SphericalHigh\hspace{1em}D.\hspace{1em}Dumbbell−-−shapeLow
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Thes−s-s−orbital has a spherical shape. In terms of energy,ssshas the lowest, followed bypppandd−d-d−orbitals. Thus, Choices A, B, and D are all incorrect.

list.title: Question 74
list.content: [Maximum marks: 7]Crude oil (also known as petroleum) is a homogeneous mixture of volatile liquid hydrocarbons. Before it can be used, it must be refined to separate it into simpler, more useful mixtures.Describe a homogeneous mixture.[1]Contrast the microscopic structure and behavior of liquids and gases using the kinetic molecular theory.[2]State the physical property of the components of crude oil that allows them to be separated by fractional distillation.[1]Kerosene, a fuel used in aviation, is one of the fractions obtained from crude oil.\newline \ \newlineKerosene has a boiling point of 240.00°C. Convert this temperature to Kelvin using Section 1 of the IB Chemistry Data Booklet.[1]Explain, using the kinetic molecular theory, why kerosene vaporizes when heated.[2]
list.markScheme: uniform composition /  single−-−phase of physically−-−combined components / two or more different elements or compounds not in fixed ratios / components not chemically bonded✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​A homogeneous mixture is one in which the composition is uniform throughout, meaning the individual components are evenly distributed and cannot be distinguished by simple observation. They appear as a single phase. Unlike compounds, the substances within a homogeneous mixture are not chemically bonded, so they retain their original chemical properties and they can combine in any ratio since they do not obey the Law of Definite Proportions.Any two of:liquid particles are close together while gas particles are far apart✓\checkmark✓liquid particles experience intermolecular /interatomic forces while gas particles do not✓\checkmark✓liquids are not compressible while gases are very compressible✓\checkmark✓liquids have a fixed volume while gases expand to fill a container✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The particles in a liquid move freely, sliding past each other in a closely−-−packed but disordered structure.  This allows a liquid to change its shape to fit its container while maintaining a fixed volume.  Since the particles remain in close contact, liquids are not compressible.  The particles do experience attractions to one aonther (intermolecular / interatomic forces) that must be overcome to enter into the gas phase.The particles in a gas are in constant random motion, moving rabidly in all directions with negligible forces between them.  The particles are far apart, allowing gases to expand to fill their container and making them highly compressible.\\ \newline \\Different boiling points/volatility✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The components of crude oil can be separated by fractional distillation because they have different boiling points. When crude oil is heated, the hydrocarbons with the lowest boiling points evaporate first, while those with higher boiling points remain in liquid form until reaching their respective boiling temperatures.  The fractions that are removed from the sample are groups of similarly sized hydrocarbons.240.00+273.15=513.15K✓240.00+273.15 = 513.15 \textrm{\ K}\:\checkmark240.00+273.15=513.15K✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The Kelvin scale is shifted from the Celsius scale to place the 0 at absolute zero instead of the freezing point of water:Temperature (K) = Temperature (∘^\circ∘C) + 273.15kinetic energy  increases, molecules move faster✓\checkmark✓boils when molecules have enough energy to overcome intermolecular forces, and transition from liquid to gas✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​According to the kinetic molecular theory, the temperature of a substance is directly related to the average kinetic energy of its particles. As kerosene is heated, its molecules absorb energy and move faster, increasing their kinetic energy. At the boiling point, the molecules have gained enough energy to break the intermolecular forces that hold them in the liquid state. This allows them to escape as into the gas phase, leading to vaporization.

list.title: Question 75
list.content: Which of the following is a mixture?I.SolderII.AmmoniaIII.SeawaterA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I, II, and IIID.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Pure substances have a definite and uniform chemical composition. Pure substances can be classified as elements if they are composed of one kind of atom or as compounds if they are composed of two or more kinds of atoms in a fixed ratio.Ammonia (NHX3\ce{NH3}NHX3​) is a compound and presents a1:31:31:3N to H ratio. Ammonia is not a mixture.On the other hand, mixtures have two or more substances physically combined that retain their individual properties together. The mixture composition is uniform for homogeneous mixtures and nonuniform for heterogeneous mixtures.Alloys are homogeneous mixtures.Solder is a homogeneous mixture.Seawater isNaCl\ce{NaCl}NaCl(and other soluble compounds) dissolved in water, a homogeneous mixture.This question is categorized as easy as students must distinguish mixtures from pure substances and apply their knowledge to some specific examples.

list.title: Question 76
list.content: Which of the following correctly compares the2s2s2sand3s3s3satomic orbitals?Average distance from the nucleusOrbital energyA.\hspace{1em}2s>3s2s > 3s2s>3s2s<3s2s < 3s2s<3sB.2s>3s2s > 3s2s>3s2s>3s2s > 3s2s>3sC.2s<3s2s < 3s2s<3s2s<3s2s < 3s2s<3sD.2s<3s2s < 3s2s<3s2s>3s2s > 3s2s>3s
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The3s3s3sorbital is larger than the2s2s2sorbital so an electron in a3s3s3sorbital is, on average, farther from the nucleus than one in a2s2s2sorbital. Additionally, the3s3s3sorbital is higher in energy because electrons in higher energy levels experience weaker electrostatic attraction to the nucleus, due to increased shielding by inner electrons and greater average distance. Therefore, both the average distance and the energy of the3s3s3sorbital are greater than those of the2s2s2sorbital.

list.title: Question 77
list.content: Which of the following statements about liquids is correct?A.\hspace{1em}They can be compressed and undergo an endothermic process to vaporize.B.\hspace{1em}They cannot be compressed and undergo an endothermic process to vaporize.C.\hspace{1em}They can be compressed and undergo an exothermic process to vaporize.D.\hspace{1em}They cannot be compressed and undergo an exothermic process to vaporize.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the kinetic molecular theory, particles in a liquid are close together and held by intermolecular forces, which gives a liquid a fixed volume. However, these particles can move past one another, so a liquid does not have a fixed shape. Because the particles are already close together, liquids are nearly incompressible.Liquids can also change to the gas state when enough energy is supplied to overcome the intermolecular attractions. This process of vaporization is endothermic, as energy from the surroundings is absorbed to separate the particles further apart.This question is of medium difficulty, as students must recall the properties of liquids and link them to the energy changes involved in changes of state.

list.title: Question 78
list.content: Which of the following ionization energies is the largest in magnitude?A.\hspace{1em}The first ionization energy of sodiumB.\hspace{1em}The second ionization energy of magnesiumC.\hspace{1em}The third ionization energy of aluminiumD.\hspace{1em}The fourth ionization energy of silicon
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Successive ionization energies are larger, as electrons are removed, there is less electron-electron repulsion, so the remaining electrons are pulled closer to the nucleus, and more energy is required to remove them.

list.markScheme: C(s)O2\mathbf{_2}2​(g)CO2\mathbf{_2}2​(g)elementelementcompoundAward M1 if all three are correct.✓\checkmark✓Further explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}Further explanation​:Elements are composed of only one kind of atoms (such as C andOX2\ce{O2}OX2​).Compounds are composed of two or more kinds of atoms in a fixed ratio (such as in the case ofCOX2\ce{CO2}COX2​here, with one carbon every two oxygens), and mixtures have two or more substances (either elements or compounds) physically mixed together. None of these examples given is a mixture.Deposition.✓\checkmark✓Further explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}Further explanation​:Deposition is the change of state from a gas into a solid.Any two of the following:COX2(s)→COX2(g)\ce{CO2(s) -> CO2(g)}COX2​(s)​COX2​(g)absorbing heat;✓\checkmark✓Sublimation of carbon dioxide produces a stable/inert/non-toxic gas;✓\checkmark✓Low temperatures preserve/extend shelf-life/refrigerate;✓\checkmark✓Dry ice stays cooler and lasts longer than water ice.✓\checkmark✓ORother reasons related to these mentioned above.Further explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}Further explanation​:Vaccine cooling requires keeping a vaccine at a low temperature. Vaccines can be stored by surrounding them with dry ice.Suppose the system is suddenly exposed to a high temperature. In that case, the heat will be used to sublime the solid carbon dioxide, avoiding the increase in the temperature of the vaccines stored.In addition, when carbon dioxide sublimes, absorbing heat, an inert gas is formed, avoiding the damage of the vaccines. As a result, sublimation can be effective in storing refrigerated vaccines.All these gases in the air are evenly distributed (appear as one layer) / air has a uniform composition;✓\checkmark✓Properties of air are constant throughout the mixture of gases.✓\checkmark✓

list.title: Question 81
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass of an unknown element, according to its mass spectrum given below?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ee5ac3d6-1adf-4485-af22-64aafeda4c8c/images/7d116e30-4735-4b2b-b53c-803201dfd930/CH2010.png)

A.6×1+7×6+8×3100\hspace{1em}\dfrac{6\times 1 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3}{100}1006×1+7×6+8×3​B.6×0.75+7×6+8×3.2510\hspace{1em}\dfrac{6\times 0.75 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3.25}{10}106×0.75+7×6+8×3.25​C.6×1+7×6+8×310\hspace{1em}\dfrac{6\times 1 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3}{10}106×1+7×6+8×3​D.6×0.75+7×6+8×3.25100\hspace{1em}\dfrac{6\times 0.75 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3.25}{100}1006×0.75+7×6+8×3.25​
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The student must determine the relative atomic mass of an element using its isotopic composition, as provided by a mass spectrum.A mass spectrum provides information about each isotope of an element. Every peak corresponds to a specific isotope. The mass–\text{--}–to–\text{--}–charge ratio,m/z,m/z,m/z,represents the atomic mass of the isotope since each ion is assumed to have a charge of+1.+1.+1.The height of the peak, or relative intensity, is proportional to its abundance. The relative atomic mass,Ar,A_r,Ar​,can be calculated as the weighted average of the atomic mass of each isotope:Ar=m1×I1+m2×I2+…I1+I2+…A_r = \dfrac{m_1\times I_1 + m_2\times I_2 + \ldots}{I_1 + I_2 + \ldots}Ar​=I1​+I2​+…m1​×I1​+m2​×I2​+…​wheremmmis the mass of an isotope andIIIis the intensity of its peak.For this question,Ar=6×0.75+7×6+8×3.250.75+6+3.25A_r = \dfrac{6\times 0.75 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3.25}{0.75 + 6 + 3.25}Ar​=0.75+6+3.256×0.75+7×6+8×3.25​Ar=6×0.75+7×6+8×3.2510A_r = \dfrac{6\times 0.75 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3.25}{10}Ar​=106×0.75+7×6+8×3.25​This question is categorized as easy as the student must be able to calculate the relative atomic mass from a mass spectrum.

list.title: Question 82
list.content: Which species have the same electron configuration?I.Ni, Cu+^++, Zn2+^{2+}2+II.12^{12}12C,13^{13}13C,14^{14}14CIII.O2−^{2-}2−, F−^-−, NeA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement II is correct as isotopes only differ in the number of neutrons.Statement III is correct as they are all isoelectronic with Ne (full valence shell).At first glance, Statement I may look correct as they all have the same number of electrons. However, since they are transition metals, we must consider how the electrons are arranged in the4s4s4sand3d3d3dorbitals.Ni has an electron configuration of [Ar]4s23d84s^2\,3d^84s23d8whereas Cu+^++and Zn2+^{2+}2+have electron configurations of [Ar]3d103d^{10}3d10, remembering that copper is an exception and that4s4s4selectrons are removed before3d3d3delectrons in ions.  Statement I is incorrect.

list.title: Question 85
list.content: Which of the following represents the correct ground state electron configuration of chromium?A.1s22s22p63s23p63d44s2\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^4\,4s^21s22s22p63s23p63d44s2B.1s22s22p63s23p64s24d4\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,4d^41s22s22p63s23p64s24d4C.1s22s22p63s23p63d54s1\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^5\,4s^11s22s22p63s23p63d54s1D.1s22s22p63s23p64s14d5\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,4d^51s22s22p63s23p64s14d5
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The electron configuration of chromium (Cr) is unusual because it violates the aufbau principle, which states that electrons will fill orbitals in order of increasing energy.Normally, the4s4s4sorbital would be completely filled before the3d3d3dorbital, since the4s4s4sorbital has a lower energy level than the3d3d3dorbital.The electron configuration1s22s22p63s23p63d54s11s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^5\,4s^11s22s22p63s23p63d54s1is more stable because it maximizes the number of half−-−filled and completely filleddddorbitals, which are energetically favorable. Half−-−filled and completely filleddddorbitals are more stable than partially filleddddorbitals, due to electron−-−electron repulsion effects.

Therefore, the number of neutrons for each is:IsotopeMass NumberAtomic NumberProtonsNeutronsX614X26214C\ce{^14_6C}X614​X26214​C146614−6=814-6=814−6=8X816X28216O\ce{^16_8O}X816​X28216​O168816−8=816-8=816−8=8X918X29218F\ce{^18_9F}X918​X29218​F189918−9=918-9=918−9=9X1020X210220Ne\ce{^20_10Ne}X1020​X210220​Ne20101020−10=10\mathbf{20-10=10}20−10=10

list.title: Question 87
list.content: 0.0400 moles of magnesium nitrateMg(NOX3)X2\ce{Mg(NO3)2}Mg(NOX3​)X2​is dissolved in 500 cm3^33of water. What is the resulting concentration of all ions in solution?A.0.240mol dm−3\hspace{1em}0.240 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}0.240mol dm−3B.0.0600mol dm−3\hspace{1em}0.0600 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}0.0600mol dm−3C.0.160mol dm−3\hspace{1em}0.160 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}0.160mol dm−3D.0.120mol dm−3\hspace{1em}0.120 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}0.120mol dm−3
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​When magnesium nitrate is placed in water it completely dissolves to form its ions:Mg(NOX3)X2→MgX2++2NOX3X−\ce{Mg(NO3)2 -> Mg^{2+} + 2 NO3-}Mg(NOX3​)X2​​MgX2++2NOX3​X−If the initial amount of magnesium nitrate was 0.0400 mol, the ions will appear in a1:21:21:2ratio, 0.0400 molMgX2+\ce{Mg^{2+}}MgX2+and 0.0800 molNOX3X−\ce{NO3-}NOX3​X−.  The total amount of ions is sum,0.0400+0.0800=0.1200mol.0.0400 + 0.0800 = 0.1200 \textrm{ mol}.0.0400+0.0800=0.1200mol.To find the concentration, use the relationshipC=nVC = \dfrac{n}{V}C=Vn​.  The units of volume must be converted from cm3^33to dm3^33, so we can use the relationship1000cm3=1dm3.1000\,\text{cm}^3 = 1\,\text{dm}^3.1000cm3=1dm3.C=nV=0.1200mol500cm3×1000cm31dm3=0.240mol dm−3C = \dfrac{n}{V} = \dfrac{0.1200 \textrm{\ mol}}{500 \textrm{\ cm}^3} \times \dfrac{1000 \textrm{\ cm}^3}{1 \textrm{\ dm}^3} = 0.240\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}C=Vn​=500cm30.1200mol​×1dm31000cm3​=0.240mol dm−3

list.title: Question 88
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The bonds inOX3\ce{O3}OX3​have bond order 1.5, as theπ\piπbonding pair is delocalized across the two bonds.The bond inOX2\ce{O2}OX2​has bond order 2. The bonds inOX3\ce{O3}OX3​are therefore weaker than those inOX2\ce{O2}OX2​and broken by a longer wavelength of light (331 nm) than the bond in inOX2\ce{O2}OX2​(241 nm).The student must provide two pieces of information: the relative bond strengths of ozone and oxygen and the correlation between energy and wavelength. Nonetheless, this question is of only moderate difficulty since it requires recall of two aspects of a key topic covered explicitly in the syllabus.

list.title: Question 89
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass given by the mass spectrum below?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0d0e9fca-9872-4cd3-86f9-1153ea9ebc23/images/e4e822e1-a79d-466e-9dcd-3fd96b14c975/CH1182v2.png)

A.\hspace{1em}24.7B.\hspace{1em}27.4C.\hspace{1em}25.3D.\hspace{1em}22.3
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:An interpretation of the mass spectra is needed to determine the relative atomic mass from the isotopic composition. As intensities are given, these are proportional to the relative abundances of the isotopes in the sample. The calculation is shown below.Ar=(1×22)+(2×23)+(5×25)+(1×26)+(1×28)1+2+5+1+1A_r = \dfrac{(1 \times 22) + (2 \times 23) + (5 \times 25) + (1 \times 26) + (1 \times 28)}{1 + 2 + 5 + 1 + 1}Ar​=1+2+5+1+1(1×22)+(2×23)+(5×25)+(1×26)+(1×28)​Ar=24710=24.7A_r = \dfrac{247}{10} = 24.7Ar​=10247​=24.7This question is categorized as moderate, as students must be able to calculate the relative atomic mass from  isotopic abundances read from a mass spectrum.

list.title: Question 90
list.content:
The heating curve of a substance is given below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/12ec30ef-773c-40ce-8f65-b63c87d59de4/images/d5dea206-9bd8-4703-bb24-89ed5f0d0ebd/CH1100.png)

Which statement(s) below is(are) correct?I.\hspace{1.em}Y is the melting point.II.\hspace{0.7em}Along line segment MN, the solid is warming up.III.\hspace{0.4em}Along the line segment NO, the liquid and solid state coexist.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}II only
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The heating curve illustrates how energy input affects a substance: it either raises the temperature within a phase or is used to overcome intermolecular forces during a phase change.During a flat section of the curve, the energy supplied does not increase temperature but instead drives the change of state. In segment NO, melting occurs and solid and liquid phases coexist, so Statement III is correct.During sloped sections, the added energy increases the temperature of the substance. In segment MN, the substance is in the solid state and its temperature rises as heat is absorbed, so Statement II is correct.Statement I is incorrect because Y corresponds to the boiling point, not the melting point.In summary:MN: solid heatingNO: melting (solid + liquid coexist)OP: liquid heatingPQ: boiling (liquid + gas coexist)This question is of medium difficulty, as students must distinguish between heating within a phase and energy changes during phase transitions.

list.title: Question 91
list.content: Sugar must be recovered from a solution of sugar and ethanol. Which statement(s) below is(are) correct?Hint: Ethanol is highly flammable with a boiling point of 78∘\,{}^\circ∘C.I.\hspace{1.em}Evaporation with a Bunsen burner is appropriate.II.\hspace{0.7em}A hot water bath (above78∘C78\,{}^\circ\text{C}78∘C) can be used with an evaporating basin containing the mixture.III.\hspace{0.4em}Filtration is safe and appropriate for this separation.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and II only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Ethanol is highly flammable so direct heating with a Bunsen burner is unsafe. Statement I is incorrect.The correct method is to use a hot water bath at a temperature above ethanol's boiling point. This allows ethanol to evaporate safely, leaving solid sugar in the evaporating basin. Statement II is correct.Filtration cannot separate sugar dissolved in ethanol, since both pass through the filter paper. Statement III is therefore incorrect.This question is of medium difficulty, as it requires understanding both the practical safety concerns of laboratory techniques and the limitations of separation methods.

list.title: Question 92
list.content: Which statement about the first ionization energies for the elements in period 3 isincorrect?A.P\hspace{1em}\ce{P}Phas a lower first ionization energy thanS\ce{S}SbecauseS\ce{S}Shas more protonsB.S\hspace{1em}\ce{S}Shas a lower first ionization energy than P because S has greatereX−−eX−\ce{e^-}-\ce{e^-}eX−−eX−repulsionC.Na\hspace{1em}\ce{Na}Nahas the lowest first ionization energyD.Ar\hspace{1em}\ce{Ar}Arhas the highest first ionization energy
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Generally, the first ionization energy increases across a period (due to the decrease in atomic radius and the increase in nuclear charge). In period 3, Na is the first element with the lowest ionization energy, and Ar is the last element with the highest ionization energy.There are some exceptions to the trend. Phosphorus (1012 kJ mol−1^{-1}−1) has a higher ionization energy than sulfur (1000 kJ/mol), despite sulfur being further right on the periodic table.To understand this exception, we can consider the electron configuration for S,1s22s22p63s23p41s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^41s22s22p63s23p4, and P,1s22s22p63s23p31s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^31s22s22p63s23p3. In sulfur, one orbital contains paired electrons, increasing electron-electron repulsion. This repulsion lowers sulfur's ionization energy by making it easier to remove an electron, despite its higher nuclear charge.

list.title: Question 93
list.content: Which statement(s) is(are) correct about the condensation of water?I.\hspace{1.em}It is the reverse of sublimation.II.\hspace{0.7em}It is exothermic.III.HX2O\hspace{0.4em}\ce{H2O}HX2​Omolecules arrange in a fixed shape.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Condensation corresponds to the transition from a gas into a liquid. It is the opposite of vaporization. The reverse process of sublimation (a solid becoming a gas) is deposition. Statement I is incorrect.As the gas becomes liquid, particles get closer, and attractive forces between particles appear. This is an exothermic process as energy is released to the surroundings. Statement II is correct.While condensing, water particles get closer to get into the liquid state. Liquids have a fixed volume but no fixed shape. Statement III is incorrect.This question is categorized as medium difficulty. Students must understand the model describing solids, liquids, and gases and changes in states of matter.

list.title: Question 94
list.content: Which of the following species has the highest number of unpaired electrons?A.Cr\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr}CrB.CrX2+\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{2+}}CrX2+C.CrX3+\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{3+}}CrX3+D.CrX6+\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{6+}}CrX6+
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Chromium is one of the exceptions to completely filling the 4sssorbital before the 3dddorbital.It has an electron configuration of[Ar]4s13d5[Ar] 4s^1  3d^5[Ar]4s13d5and all six valence electrons are unpaired. As electrons are removed to form chromium ions, the number of unpaired electrons decreases. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

list.title: Question 95
list.content:
Consider the cooling curve of ethanol below which shows the temperature change as heat is removed at a constant rate.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/82172fd2-c4d0-4e78-b06f-3acc44195dc3/images/6d132a89-2951-40e2-bf6d-97c13f23c472/CH1220.png)

Which statement is correct about ethanol?A.\hspace{1em}The enthalpy of fusion is less than the enthalpy of vaporization.B.\hspace{1em}Liquid ethanol has a lower heat capacity than gaseous ethanol.C.\hspace{1em}Sublimation occurs at78∘C.78{}^\circ\text{C}.78∘C.D.\hspace{1em}Deposition occurs at−114∘C.-114{}^\circ\text{C}.−114∘C.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A cooling curve tracks how a substance loses energy as temperature decreases. The sloped regions show cooling within a phase, where particles lose kinetic energy and the temperature falls. The flat regions represent phase changes, when temperature remains constant because the energy released is due to intermolecular forces being formed.The long plateau near78∘C78^\circ\text{C}78∘Ccorresponds to condensation. Gas particles must come close together and form many new intermolecular forces, releasing a large quantity of energy to the surroundings. The shorter plateau near−114∘C-114^\circ\text{C}−114∘Ccorresponds to freezing, where fewer forces are formed as the liquid arranges into the solid structure, so less energy is released.The enthalpy of vaporization and the enthalpy of fusion are positive values, because they describe the endothermic changes of melting and vaporizing. On a cooling curve, we see the reverse processes, condensation and freezing, which have the same magnitude of enthalpy change but the opposite sign. The enthalpy of vaporization is larger than the enthalpy of fusion.The sloped regions represent cooling within a single phase, where particles lose kinetic energy and the temperature falls. The gradient of the slope is inversely related to the specific heat capacity: a steeper slope means the substance cools more quickly and therefore has a lower heat capacity. For ethanol, the liquid section has a shallower slope than the gas section, showing that liquid ethanol has a higher heat capacity than the vapour.Only condensation and freezing are represented here. Sublimation (solid to gas) or deposition (gas to solid) do not occur under these conditions and are not shown.

list.title: Question 96
list.content:
X63X2263Cu\ce{^{63}Cu}X63​X2263​CuandX65X2265Cu\ce{^{65}Cu}X65​X2265​Cuare the two most abundant isotopes of copper.Define isotope.[1]Determine the correct numbers of subatomic particles to complete the following table.[1]Copper-63Copper-65Number of protonsNumber of electronsNumber of neutronsCalculate the relative abundances ofX63X2263Cu\ce{^{63}Cu}X63​X2263​CuandX65X2265Cu\ce{^{65}Cu}X65​X2265​Cuusing section 6 (Section 7- 2025 Syllabus) of the data booklet.[3]Complete the orbital diagram for the valence electrons in a copper atom and a copper (II) ion.[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cd37483-9faf-4827-abe9-8c21e31e9e97/images/f470055e-fefe-474a-8407-420630894d44/CH0684b.png)
list.markScheme:
Isotopes of an element have the same atomic number but different mass numbers / same number of protons but a different number of neutrons.✓\checkmark✓All correct✓\checkmark✓Copper-63Copper-65Number of protons2929Number of electrons2929Number of neutrons3436Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The number of protons for both isotopes is the same as the atomic number of copper. Since both isotopes are electrically neutral, the number of electrons is the same as the number of protons. The number of neutrons is calculated by subtracting the number of protons from the mass number.Letxxxbe the relative abundance of copper-63. Using the data booklet, the relative atomic mass of copper is 63.55.63x+65(100−x)100=63.55⟹−2x=−145✓\dfrac{63x+65\left(100-x\right)}{100} = 63.55\quad \Longrightarrow \quad -2x = -145\,\checkmark10063x+65(100−x)​=63.55⟹−2x=−145✓Relative abundance of copper-63:x=72.5%x=72.5\%x=72.5%✓\checkmark✓Relative abundance of copper-65:100−x=100−72.5=27.5%100-x=100-72.5=27.5\%100−x=100−72.5=27.5%✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The relative atomic mass is calculated by finding the weighted average of the isotopes. This means we can find the relative abundances if we know the relative atomic mass of copper and the isotopes of copper.We know that the relative abundances of the two isotopes must add up to 100%\%%so we can set the abundance of copper-63 as a variablexxxand the abundance of copper-65 as100−x100-x100−x. We can set up an equation with these abundances and the isotopic masses and rearrange to solve forxxx. Withxxx, we can then calculate the individual abundances.All arrow correct for each of Cu and Cu2+^{2+}2+

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cd37483-9faf-4827-abe9-8c21e31e9e97/images/c82d90ce-ffac-4589-bfed-d237efe0d33e/CH0684b-MS.png)

Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Copper is one of the exceptions to having the 4s orbital completely filled before filling the 3d orbital−-−it has an electron configuration of [Ar]4s13d104s^1\,3d^{10}4s13d10. When removing electrons to form cations, the 4s electrons are removed before the 3d electrons so the copper (II) ion has an electron configuration of  [Ar]3d93d^93d9. When drawing the orbital diagrams, remember that each orbital can only fit two electrons of opposite spin and each degenerate 3d orbital is first singly filled before pairing the electrons up.

list.title: Question 97
list.content: Which of the following statements about atomic structure isincorrect?A.\hspace{1em}The atomic nucleus contains over99.9%99.9\%99.9%of an atom's mass.B.\hspace{1em}The number of neutrons in an atom typically increases as the atomic number increases.C.\hspace{1em}The mass of an electron is approximately1/18361/18361/1836of a proton's mass.D.\hspace{1em}Electrons orbit the nucleus in fixed orbits, similar to planets orbiting the Sun.
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​While early models of the atom, such as Bohr's atomic model, proposed that electrons move in fixed circular orbits around the nucleus, modern quantum mechanics has replaced this idea. Instead of fixed paths, electrons exist in probability clouds called orbitals, where their exact location cannot be determined. These orbitals are described by quantum mechanics, where electrons behave more like waves than particles in fixed orbits. Therefore, the idea of electrons orbiting the nucleus like planets is an outdated model that does not accurately describe atomic structure.

=mM=50.0g176.14gmol−1\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{50.0\,\text{g}}{176.14\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}Mm​=176.14gmol−150.0g​=0.284mol0.284\,\text{mol}0.284mol✓\checkmark✓Number of molecules:N=n×NA=(0.284mol)(6.02×1023)N = n\times N_A = (0.284\,\text{mol})(6.02\times 10^{23})N=n×NA​=(0.284mol)(6.02×1023)=1.71×10231.71\times
