Therefore, multiplying the moles of ascorbic acid by 6 results in obtaining the moles of carbon.

list.title: Question 99
list.content: Which of the following correctly describes the properties of a homogeneous mixture?A.\hspace{1em}The physical properties are uniform and the chemical properties of its components remain unchanged.B.\hspace{1em}The physical and chemical properties are those of its most abundant component.C.\hspace{1em}The physical and chemical properties are an average of the properties of its components.D.\hspace{1em}The physical properties vary throughout the sample, and its components do not retain their chemical properties.
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​A homogeneous mixture is one in which the composition and physical properties are uniform throughout the sample, and the chemical identity of each component remains unchanged.Unlike a pure substance, a mixture's physical properties depend on the proportions and interactions of its components rather than on its most abundant component or a simple average.  Salt water is conductive while both pure water liquid and pure sodium chloride crystals are not.  Solder, a common alloy of tin and lead used in electronics, has a melting point of183∘C183^\circ\text{C}183∘Cwhile lead melts at 327∘C^\circ\text{C}∘Cand tin melts at 232∘C.^\circ\text{C}.∘C.Again, solder does not take on the properties of the more abundant tin or have a melting point that is the average of its components.

list.title: Question 100
list.content: The mass spectrum of an element shows only two peaks: one atm/z=50m/z = 50m/z=50with relative abundance 2 and the other atm/z=52m/z = 52m/z=52with relative abundance 1. What is the relative atomic mass of the element?A.\hspace{1em}51.00B.\hspace{1em}50.67C.\hspace{1em}50.50D.\hspace{1em}51.33
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​In a mass spectrum, the height of each peak reflects the relative abundance of that isotope.  The relative atomic mass can be determined from the weighted average of the isotopes:Ar=(2)(50)+(1)(52)3=50.67A_r = \dfrac{(2)(50) + (1)(52)}{3} = 50.67Ar​=3(2)(50)+(1)(52)​=50.67

list.title: Question 101
list.content: Which of the following correctly describes the forces that hold an atom together?A.\hspace{1.em}Electrostatic attraction holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while the strong nuclear force keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.B.\hspace{1.em}The strong nuclear force holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while electrostatic attraction keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.C.\hspace{1.em}Gravitational forces play a significant role in keeping electrons in orbit around the nucleus, along with electrostatic attraction.D.\hspace{1.em}The strong nuclear force is responsible for holding the entire atom together, including the electrons.
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The correct explanation is that the strong nuclear force holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while electrostatic attraction keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.The strong nuclear force is one of the four fundamental forces of nature and is responsible for overcoming the repulsion between positively charged protons, keeping them bound together with neutrons inside the nucleus. Without this force, the protons would repel each other due to their positive charges. On the other hand, electrostatic attraction is responsible for keeping negatively charged electrons bound to the positively charged nucleus. This force is much weaker than the strong nuclear force but is crucial for maintaining atomic structure. Contrary to one of the incorrect options, gravitational forces are negligible at the atomic scale, and the strong nuclear force does not play a role in keeping electrons attached to the nucleus.

list.title: Question 102
list.content: Which statement aboutNX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​isincorrect?A.\hspace{1em}Its empirical formula isNOX2.\ce{NO2}.NOX2​.B.\hspace{1em}Its percentage composition is 30.45% nitrogen.C.\hspace{1em}Its percentage composition is 53.32% oxygen.D.\hspace{1em}Its molar mass is92.02g mol−1.92.02\,\text{g mol}^{-1}.92.02g mol−1.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The empirical formula gives the simplest ratio of atoms of each element present in that compound.NX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​has two nitrogen atoms for every four oxygen atoms, the simplest ratio is1:2,1:2,1:2,and the empirical formula isNOX2.\ce{NO2}.NOX2​.The molar mass ofNX2OX4\ce{N2O4}NX2​OX4​can be determined by adding the masses of each atom.M=2(14.01)+4(16.00)=92.02g mol−1M = 2(14.01) + 4(16.00) = 92.02 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}M=2(14.01)+4(16.00)=92.02g mol−1The percentage composition must be calculated by assuming one mole of the substance.  For nitrogen:%N=mNmNOX2×100%=2(14.01g)92.02g×100%=30.45%\%\ce{N} = \dfrac{m_\ce{N}}{m_{\ce{NO2}}} \times 100\% = \dfrac{2(14.01 \textrm{\ g})}{92.02 \textrm{\ g}} \times 100\%  = 30.45\%%N=mNOX2​​mN​​×100%=92.02g2(14.01g)​×100%=30.45%Since there are only two elements, the mass percent of oxygen is100−%N=69.55%.100 - \%\ce{N} = 69.55 \%.100−%N=69.55%.This question is categorized as easy as students must be able to understand the difference between empirical and molecular formulae and should also be able to calculate the percentage composition.

list.title: Question 103
list.content: Cu\ce{Cu}Cuis a transition metal commonly used in wires.Determine the complete electron configuration ofCu\ce{Cu}Cu.[1]State the condensed electron configuration ofCuX+.\ce{Cu+}.CuX+.[1]Determine whether the electron configuration ofCu\ce{Cu}Cufollows the usual rules of electron configuration.[1]
list.markScheme: Longhand/complete electron configuration ofCu\ce{Cu}Cu1sX22sX22pX63sX23pX63dX104sX1✓\ce{1s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^{10} 4s^1}\,\checkmark1sX22sX22pX63sX23pX63dX104sX1✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Cu\ce{Cu}Cuis one of the exceptions where a3d3d3dorbital would fill before4s4s4sand this is due to the fact that a full3d3d3dorbital is more stable.Condensed electron configuration[Ar]3dX10✓\ce{[Ar]\,3d^{10}}\,\checkmark[Ar]3dX10✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​1 electron lost from4s4s4sorbital (highest energy level).There is an anomaly with the electron configuration ofCu\ce{Cu}Cusimply because there is slightly greater stability associated with the fully filled (3d103d^{10}3d10) subshell than the incomplete one. Hence, the3d103d^{10}3d10is filled first before pairing the4s4s4ssubshell.✓\checkmark✓

list.title: Question 104
list.content:
Some plant pigments were analyzed through paper chromatography. StandardsA,B,C, andDhave been used against the pigments.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/041cf040-4592-491d-9395-7a0e393f941b/images/28f2ec03-20c4-469e-9bfb-b1c2e0c2d1a1/unnamed%20(1).png)

Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[c◯Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]A group of students analyzed the results. Some of their hypothesis are listed below.Mariana's hypothesis: PlantZcontains pigments B and C, and it has been proven to be a mixture of three components.Hiba's hypothesis: PlantYpresents pigments A and D. All three plants are made of a mixture of pigments.Priya's hypothesis: PlantXhas many colored components. The red component is the one with the lowest retention factor.Comment on each hypothesis and determine its validity.[3]Calculate the retention factor of the red spot in standard A.[1]Identify the standard with the lowest affinity for the solvent used in the paper chromatography. Explain your reasoning.[2]Suggest a limitation of the paper chromatography described as a separating technique.[1]
list.markScheme:
Mariana's hypothesis is incorrect, and plant Z has at least three components;✓\checkmark✓Hiba's hypothesis is correct, and all the plants present more than one spot;✓\checkmark✓Priya's hypothesis is incorrect, and the red spot has the highest retention factor.✓\checkmark✓Further explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}Further explanation​:Mariana's hypothesis is incorrect. Plant Z contains standards B and C as the spots in B and C are detected. However, separation in three spots does not prove to be a mixture of three components only. Some of these spots could be mixtures of unseparated components. We can say that plant Z is a mixture of at least three components.Hiba's hypothesis is correct as plant Y presents the spots detected in pigments A and D. In addition, it is true that all these plants (X, Y, and Z) are made of a mixture of pigments as different spots have been detected in all of them.Priya's hypothesis is incorrect. Plant X has many colored components. However, the red spot has the highest retention factor compared to the other spots.RF=13.6cm14.5cm=0.94✓R_F = \dfrac{13.6\,\text{cm}}{14.5\,\text{cm}} = 0.94\,\checkmarkRF​=14.5cm13.6cm​=0.94✓Accept any value between 0.92 and 0.96.Further explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation}}Further explanation​:RF=distance traveled by the spotdistance traveled by the solvent frontR_F = \dfrac{\text{distance traveled by the spot}}{\text{distance traveled by the solvent front}}RF​=distance traveled by the solvent frontdistance traveled by the spot​

list.title: Question 105
list.content: A mixture is composed of wood chips, water, and sodium chloride. Which sequence of techniques could be used to isolate the wood chips and the sodium chloride separately?A.\hspace{1em}Evaporation followed by paper chromatographyB.\hspace{1em}Filtration followed by paper chromatographyC.\hspace{1em}Evaporation followed by solvationD.\hspace{1em}Filtration followed by evaporation
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To answer this question, the student must understand the properties of the mixture's components.The wood chips would not dissolve in the water, so they are filtered out first. This will leave the sodium chloride dissolved in the water. The water can be evaporated to remove the water (to isolate the salt).Paper chromatography would be ineffective in this scenario as it is used for separating substances such as dyes, pigments, and proteins.This question is categorized as medium complexity because the student must understand the properties of matter and separation techniques.

list.title: Question 107
list.content: Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom would produce the shortest wavelength?A.5p⟶1s\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 1s5p⟶1sB.5p⟶2s\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 2s5p⟶2sC.5p⟶3s\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 3s5p⟶3sD.5p⟶4s\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 4s5p⟶4s
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The shortest wavelength corresponds to a higher frequency and therefore a higher energy transition. The5p5p5pto1s1s1srepresents the largest energy drop and therefore would produce the shortest wavelength.

list.title: Question 109
list.content: An electron in a hydrogen atom transitions fromn=1n = 1n=1ton=4n = 4n=4, which statement below best describes the energy involved in this transition?A.\hspace{1em}Energy is absorbed in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum.B.\hspace{1em}Energy is emitted in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum.C.\hspace{1em}Energy is absorbed in the ultraviolet range of the electromagnetic spectrum.D.\hspace{1em}Energy is emitted in the ultraviolet range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Transitions from energy levelsn=2,3,4…n = 2, 3, 4\ldotsn=2,3,4…ton=1n = 1n=1represent the largest energy transitions due to the convergence of energy levels moving away from the nucleus.A transition fromn=4⟶n=1n = 4 \longrightarrow n = 1n=4⟶n=1emits in the UV range of the spectrum. Since the proposed transition is fromn=1n = 1n=1ton=4n = 4n=4, ultraviolet light is absorbed rather than emitted.

list.title: Question 111
list.content: Successive ionization energies for an unknown element are given in the table below.Ionization energy /kJmol−1\mathbf{kJ\ mol^{-1}}kJmol−1First ionization energy494Second ionization energy4562Third ionization energy6912Fourth ionization energy9543To which element the trend above for successive ionization energies belong to?A.\hspace{1em}LiB.\hspace{1em}NaC.\hspace{1em}MgD.\hspace{1em}Al
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Students must understand that patterns in successive ionization energies give evidence for the energy levels in the atom.From the given data, we can see a significant increase from first to second ionization energy. This jump between the first and second ionization energy indicates that the second electron is removed from a lower energy level. As a result, we can conclude that the element has one valence electron and belongs to group 1.The element has at least 4 electrons, so it cannot be lithium.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as the student must deduce the group of an element from its successive ionization energy data.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/28111e44-7138-4944-ad35-20fb46aef292/images/020bc511-da0e-46d9-a097-f28de93e7d96/2-681d.png)
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Orbital diagrams must follow three rules: the Aufbau principle, Hund's rule, and the Pauli exclusion principle.Options A and C are the orbital diagrams for copper and chromium respectively−-−the two exceptions to completely filling the4s4s4sorbital before the3d3d3dorbital.Option B is the orbital diagram for either the copper(I) ion or the zinc (II) ion as4s4s4selectrons are removed before3d3d3delectrons.This leaves Option D as the option that is not possible as it is what we would expect the orbital diagram to be for copper if it followed the trend that4s4s4sorbitals are filled before3d3d3dorbitals. As4s4s4selectrons are removed before3d3d3delectrons, this cannot be the orbital diagram for any ions either. A full3d3d3dsubshell is more stable.

list.title: Question 114
list.content: An element has the electron configuration1s22s22p63s23p64s23d71s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^71s22s22p63s23p64s23d7. Which of the below gives this element the correct number of energy levels, block, and group?Energy levelsBlockGroupA.\hspace{1em}3sss2B.\hspace{1em}3ddd7C.\hspace{1em}4sss7D.\hspace{1em}4ddd9
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​This highest principal energy level is 4 (4s24s^24s2).The subshell being filled is3d3d3d, making it ad−d-d−block element. Its position in thed−d-d−block and the total number of valence electrons, being 9 (4s2+3d74s^2 + 3d^74s2+3d7), places this element in group 9.

list.content: The elemental composition of compoundB\textbf{B}Bis given in the table.\enskipElement\enskipAbundance/%mass\enskip \textbf{Abundance} \mathbf{\ /\ \% mass}\enskipAbundance/%massC\ce{C}C75H\ce{H}H25What is the empirical formula of compoundB\textbf{B}B?Atomic masses (amu)C=12,H=1\ce{C} = 12, \ce{H} = 1C=12,H=1A.CX3H\hspace{1em}\ce{C3H}CX3​HB.CH\hspace{1em}\ce{CH}CHC.CX3HX2\hspace{1em}\ce{C3H2}CX3​HX2​D.CHX4\hspace{1em}\ce{CH4}CHX4​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To determine the empirical formula, assume a 100 g sample of the compound. This would contain 75 g of carbon and 25 g of hydrogen. Converting to moles givesnC=75g C12g mol−1=6.25moln_{\ce{C}} = \dfrac{75 \textrm{\ g C}}{12 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 6.25 \textrm{\ mol}nC​=12g mol−175g C​=6.25molnH=25g H1g mol−1=25moln_{\ce{H}} = \dfrac{25 \textrm{\ g H}}{1 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}} = 25 \textrm{\ mol}nH​=1g mol−125g H​=25molThe simplest whole number ratio is therefore6.25:25,6.25 : 25,6.25:25,which simplifies to1:4.1 : 4.1:4.This means that for every one atom of carbon there are four atoms of hydrogen, so the empirical formula isCHX4\ce{CH4}CHX4​.

list.title: Question 120
list.content: Consider the data below on the successive ionization energies forAl.\ce{Al}.Al.\enskipElectrons Removed\enskip1234Energy(kJmol−1)\textbf{Energy(kJ mol}\mathbf{^{-1}})Energy(kJ mol−1)577\enskip577\enskip5771816\enskip1816\enskip18162881\enskip2881\enskip288111600\enskip11600\enskip11600Explain why the successive ionization energies for an element increase.[1]Explain how the successive ionization energies for aluminium give evidence for its three valence electrons.[2]Using sections 1 and 2 of the data booklet, calculate the wavelength of light required to remove an electron from an aluminium atom.[3]
list.markScheme:
As electrons are removed, there is less electron- electron repulsion, so the remaining electrons are pulled closer to the nucleus and more energy is required to remove them.✓.\, \checkmark.✓There is a large increase in ionization energy between the 3rd and 4th electron, indicating that the 4th electron is removed from a different (lower/closer) energy level.✓\checkmark✓The 4th electron is removed from an energy level closer to the nucleus, with stronger forces of attraction, so aluminium has three electrons in its valence shell.✓\checkmark✓\mbox{}IE=(L)(E)⟹E=IEL=577×1036.02×1023=9.58×10−19J✓E=(h)(f)⟹f=Eh=9.58×10−196.63×10−34=1.45×1015Hz✓c=(λ)(f)⟹λ=cf=3×1081.45×1015=2.08×10−7m✓\begin{aligned}
IE &= (L)(E) \Longrightarrow E = \dfrac{IE}{L} = \dfrac{577\times 10^3}{6.02\times 10^{23}} = 9.58\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}\, \checkmark \\
E &= (h)(f) \Longrightarrow f = \dfrac{E}{h} = \dfrac{9.58\times 10^{-19}}{6.63\times10^{-34}} = 1.45\times 10^{15}\,\text{Hz}\, \checkmark \\
c &= (\lambda)(f) \Longrightarrow \lambda = \dfrac{c}{f} = \dfrac{3\times 10^{8}}{1.45\times10^{15}} \\
&= \answer{2.08\times 10^{-7}\text{m}}\,\checkmark
\end{aligned}IEEc​=(L)(E)⟹E=LIE​=6.02×1023577×103​=9.58×10−19J✓=(h)(f)⟹f=hE​=6.63×10−349.58×10−19​=1.45×1015Hz✓=(λ)(f)⟹λ=fc​=1.45×10153×108​=2.08×10−7m​✓​

list.title: Question 121
list.content:
Biological dyes contaminated a local pond. These dyes are known to be soluble solids. A sample of the polluted pond water was collected for separation and further identification of the dyes to determine how best to remediate the area.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/760b58bf-4e46-4e5e-8e06-140c7724c06b/images/3080cb24-1b57-4323-9bba-609b9e38ea65/CH0854.png)

State whether this mixture is homogeneous or heterogeneous, explaining your answer.[2]State the technique that could be used to remove the wood chips, algae, and plant matter from the mixture.[1]State the technique that could be used to isolate the dissolved solids (salts, dyes, etc) from the water.[1]State the technique that could be used to separate the salts from the dyes.[1]Explain the properties of the substances that enable their separation in question (d).[2]Once the dyes have been separated from the remainder of the sample, paper chromatography could be used to determine how many dyes are present. State the identity of the stationary phase and an example of a mobile phase.[1]From the following paper chromatogram, state which dye (AorB) has a greater affinity for the mobile, describing the evidence to support this answer.[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/760b58bf-4e46-4e5e-8e06-140c7724c06b/images/aaf79678-54da-49c0-aa4d-3686d9795d95/CH0854g.png)
list.markScheme: heterogenous;✓\checkmark✓More than one type of material/component/substance is visible/identifiable✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Homogeneous mixtures contain more than one substance physically combined that appear as one phase (layer) throughout. These types of mixtures are indistinguishable from pure substance. A heterogeneous mixture contains more than one easily identifiable substance (several layers).filtration/filtering✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:If a mixture contains solids in a liquid and those solids are insoluble, then filtration is a viable method for separation.evaporation✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:If a mixture contains soluble solids in a solvent, the solids can be isolated by evaporating the solvent by applying heat.recrystallization✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Recrystallization separates components of a solid mixture, provided that the substances have varying solvent solubility at different temperatures.differing solvent solubility;✓\checkmark✓at different temperatures✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:When recrystallizing a substance, the impure substance is dissolved in a warm liquid where the components have variable solubility in that solvent at different temperatures. This mixture is then evaporated to form a saturated solution which is subsequently placed in an ice bath. This causes the mixture's components with a lower solubility in the solvent to precipitate (form a solid), enabling it to be separated via filtration.Stationary phase = paper;Mobile phase = water✓\checkmark✓Award M1 only if both the stationary and mobile phases are correct.The mobile phase could be any polar solvent, such as methanol or ethanol.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:In paper chromatography, the stationary phase is always the paper, and the mobile phase is whichever solvent is used to separate the mixture's components.A;✓\checkmark✓(SpotA) has moved the furthest (from the starting line)/is closest to the solvent front✓\checkmark✓Award M2 if M1 was incorrect, but the answer is consistent (B; spot B is the furthest from the solvent front).Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:In paper chromatography, the components of a mixture with the greatest affinity for the solvent will move the furthest on the chromatogram. This means that the forces of attraction between the solvent and the substance are greater than between the substance and the paper.

list.title: Question 122
list.content: The wavelength of light emitted for then=∞→1n=\infty \rightarrow 1n=∞→1transition for an electron in a zinc atom is296nm.296\, nm.296nm.Define first ionization energy.[2]Write an equation that represents the first ionization energy of zinc.[1]Using sections 1 and 2 of the data booklet, calculate the first ionization energy of zinc in kJ mol−1^{-1}−1.[3]
list.markScheme:
The minimum energy required to remove one mole of electrons✓\checkmark✓from one mole of gaseous atoms.✓\checkmark✓Zn(g)→ZnX+(g)+eX−✓\ce{Zn(g) -> Zn+(g) + e-}\, \checkmarkZn(g)​ZnX+(g)+eX−✓State symbols required\mbox{}c=(λ)(f)⟹f=cλ=3×108m s−1296×10−9m=1.01×1015Hz✓E=(h)(f)⟹E=(6.63×10−34J s)(1.01×1015s−1)=6.72×10−19J✓IE=(L)(E)⟹IE=(6.02×1023)(6.72×10−19)=404544J mol−1=405kJ mol−1✓\begin{aligned}
c &= (\lambda)(f) \Longrightarrow f = \dfrac{c}{\lambda}=\dfrac{3\times10^8\text{m s}^{-1}}{296\times 10^{-9}\text{m}} = 1.01\times10^{15}\text{Hz}\, \checkmark  \\
E &= (h)(f) \Longrightarrow E = (6.63\times 10^{-34}\text{J s})(1.01\times 10^{15}\text{s}^{-1}) = 6.72\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}\,\checkmark \\
IE &= (L)(E) \Longrightarrow IE = (6.02\times 10^{23})(6.72\times 10^{-19}) = 404544\,\text{J mol}^{-1} \\
&= \answer{405\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}}\,\checkmark
\end{aligned}cEIE​=(λ)(f)⟹f=λc​=296×10−9m3×108m s−1​=1.01×1015Hz✓=(h)(f)⟹E=(6.63×10−34J s)(1.01×1015s−1)=6.72×10−19J✓=(L)(E)⟹IE=(6.02×1023)(6.72×10−19)=404544J mol−1=405kJ mol−1​✓​Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​Ionization energy is the energy required to move an electron from the ground state to the infinite level and so can be expressed asn=1→∞n = 1\rightarrow \inftyn=1→∞(requiring the same energy as would be emitted for the reverse process, 296 nm).L refers to Avogadro's number (NA_AA​).

list.title: Question 123
list.content: [Maximum marks: 6]Lead white is a pigment historically used by artists to achieve a warm white. It is no longer commonly used today due to its toxicity.A sample from one painting was analyzed, and it was found that the lead pigment contained two isotopes of lead with mass numbers 206 and 208, in a ratio of3:2.3:2.3:2.Define the term isotope.[1]Calculate the relative atomic mass of lead in the sample. Show your working[2]In another pigment sample, the relative atomic mass of lead was determined to be 207.6.Suggest why the relative atomic masses differ between the samples.[1]Predict and explain whether the lead present in both samples would have the same physical and chemical properties.[2]
list.markScheme: two atoms with the same number of protons and  different number of neutrons✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Isotopes are atoms of the same element (so they have the same number of protons), but they have different numbers of neutrons, which means they have different mass numbers. This affects the atomic mass but not the chemical behavior.(206.0)(3)+(208.0)(2)5\dfrac{(206.0)(3) + (208.0)(2)}{5}5(206.0)(3)+(208.0)(2)​OR(206.0)(60)+(208.0)(40)100✓\dfrac{(206.0)(60) + (208.0)(40)}{100}\ \checkmark100(206.0)(60)+(208.0)(40)​✓206.8✓206.8\ \checkmark206.8✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The relative atomic mass is the weighted average of the mass of each isotope. With a3:23:23:2ratio, the percent abundance is60:40.60:40.60:40.Ar=∑mass of isotope×percent abundance100A_r = \sum \dfrac{\text{mass of isotope}\times \text{percent abundance}}{100}Ar​=∑100mass of isotope×percent abundance​Ar=(206.0)(60)+(208.0)(40)100=206.8A_r = \dfrac{(206.0)(60) + (208.0)(40)}{100} = 206.8Ar​=100(206.0)(60)+(208.0)(40)​=206.8any of the following:different sources/geological origins of the lead✓\checkmark✓different manufacturing/refining processes used to prepare pigments✓\checkmark✓small sample size so different distribution of isotopes✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Different lead samples can come from different mines or regions, and the natural abundance of isotopes varies slightly depending on the geological source. That is why one sample could have more206Pb,^{206}\ce{Pb},206Pb,while another has more208Pb.^{208}\ce{Pb}.208Pb.chemical properties same: same number of electrons/same electron configuration✓\checkmark✓physical properties may differ: different mass/boiling point/density/rate of diffusion✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The chemical properties would be the same because both isotopes of lead have the same number of electrons. Chemical reactions depend on the electron arrangement, not the number of neutrons. However, the physical properties (like mass, density, diffusion rate, boiling/melting points) would be different due to the difference in mass.

list.title: Question 124
list.content: A scientist wants to analyze the components of an ink sample. The ink is first dissolved in an organic solvent and separated into its components using paper chromatography.  The solvent is then distilled to remove impurities and be reused.Which of the following properties enable these separation techniques to be effective?Paper ChromatographyDistillationA.\hspace{1em}relative solubility of ink componentsdifference in densityB.relative solubility of ink componentsdifference in boiling pointC.difference in particle sizedifference in boiling pointD.difference in particle sizedifference in density
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation: }}Explanation:​Paper ChromatographyThe dyes separate because of their differences in solubility in the mobile phase (solvent) and their interactions with the stationary phase (chromatography paper).More soluble dyes travel farther with the solvent, while less soluble dyes stick closer to the baseline.DistillationThe solvent is recovered using distillation, which relies on differences in boiling points between the solvent and impurities.The solvent evaporates first, leaving impurities behind.  It is then condensed back into liquid form for reuse.

list.title: Question 125
list.content: Complete combustion of50cm350\text{\ cm}^350cm3of a hydrocarbon vapour produces350cm3350\text{\ cm}^3350cm3of carbon dioxide at the same temperature and pressure. Which is a possible molecular formula of the hydrocarbon?A.CX8HX18\hspace{1em}\ce{C8H18}CX8​HX18​B.CX7HX16\hspace{1em}\ce{C7H16}CX7​HX16​C.CX6HX14\hspace{1em}\ce{C6H14}CX6​HX14​D.CX5HX12\hspace{1em}\ce{C5H12}CX5​HX12​
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To determine the molecular formula of the alkane, we start by understanding the general reaction for the complete combustion of a hydrocarbon:CXxHXy+(x+y4)OX2→xCOX2+(y2)HX2O\ce{C_xH_y + \left(\dfrac{x+y}{4}\right) O2 -> x CO2 + \left(\dfrac{y}{2}\right) H2O}CXx​HXy​​+(4x+y​)OX2​​xCOX2​+(2y​)HX2​OVolume of hydrocarbon vapour=50cm3= 50\text{\ cm}^3=50cm3Volume of carbon dioxide produced=350cm3= 350\text{\ cm}^3=350cm3The volumes of gases are proportional to the number of moles (at constant temperature and pressure). Therefore, we can infer the number of moles directly from the volumes given.From the reaction stoichiometry, we see that 1 mole of hydrocarbon(CXxHXy)(\ce{C_xH_y})(CXx​HXy​​)producesxxxmoles ofCOX2.\ce{CO2}.COX2​.Since we start with50cm350\text{\ cm}^350cm3of hydrocarbon and produce350cm3350\text{\ cm}^3350cm3ofCOX2:\ce{CO2}:COX2​:x1=350cm350cm3;x=7\dfrac{x}{1} = \dfrac{350\text{\ cm}^3}{50\text{\ cm}^3};\quad  x = 71x​=50cm3350cm3​;x=7As an alkane, the general formula isCXnHX2n+2.\ce{C_nH_{2n+2}}.CXn​HX2n+2​​.The alkane here isCX7HX16.\ce{C7H16}.CX7​HX16​.

list.title: Question 126
list.content: Which of the following does NOT have two valence electrons?A.\hspace{1em}Al+^++B.\hspace{1em}ZnC.\hspace{1em}CaD.\hspace{1em}Sc3+^{3+}3+
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Electron configuration of Al+^++: [Ne]3s23s^23s2Electron configuration of Zn: [Ar]4s24s^24s23d103d^{10}3d10Electron configuration of Ca: [Ar]4s24s^24s2Electron configuration of Sc: [Ar]4s24s^24s23d13d^13d1.Sc will lose 2 electrons in the 4s sublevel and 1 from the 3d sublevel, leaving a complete 3rd energy level with 8 valence electrons in Sc3+^{3+}3+(1s22s22p63s23p61s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^61s22s22p63s23p6).

list.title: Question 127
list.content: How manyfullyoccupiedppporbitals are there in selenium, Se, atom?A.\hspace{1em}2B.\hspace{1em}3C.\hspace{1em}7D.\hspace{1em}9
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Selenium's electron configuration is1s22s22p63s23p64s23d104p41s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,3d^{10}\,4p^41s22s22p63s23p64s23d104p4.The three2p2p2pand three3p3p3porbitals are fully occupied, along with one4p4p4porbital.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89bd9bcb-c836-45ae-92f4-7c208e7e6ff5/images/116855d7-2a12-459d-ac3b-c43a03ebefb5/image.png)

list.title: Question 128
list.content: A research team needs to separate a mixture containing:Vegetable oil (density0.9g/cm3,0.9 \textrm{\ g/cm}^3,0.9g/cm3,immiscible with water)Ethanol (density0.8g/cm3,0.8 \textrm{\ g/cm}^3,0.8g/cm3,miscible with water, boiling point78∘C)78^\circ\textrm{C})78∘C)Water (density1.0g/cm3,1.0 \textrm{\ g/cm}^3,1.0g/cm3,boiling point100∘C)100^\circ\textrm{C})100∘C)Which separation technique would be most appropriate to isolate pure water from this mixture?A.\hspace{1.em}Decanting followed by crystallizationB.\hspace{1.em}Fractional distillation of the entire mixtureC.\hspace{1.em}Filtration followed by evaporationD.\hspace{1.em}Simple distillation after removing the oil layer
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​This separation requires understanding of miscibility and boiling point differences. The oil is immiscible with water and ethanol, so it can be separated first by decanting or using a separating funnel, leaving behind a homogeneous water−-−ethanol mixture. Since ethanol and water have different boiling points(78∘C(78^\circ\textrm{C}(78∘Cvs.100∘C),100^\circ\textrm{C}),100∘C),simple distillation can separate them effectively. The ethanol will vaporize first at78∘C,78^\circ\textrm{C},78∘C,leaving pure water behind. Fractional distillation would work but is unnecessarily complex for this large of a boiling point difference. Filtration and crystallization are inappropriate for liquid mixtures.

list.title: Question 129
list.content:
A dye is contaminated with another substance. The chromatograms below show the dye before recrystallization (1) and after recrystallization (2).Which chromatogram provides evidence that recrystallization has successfully removed the contaminant?\hspace{0.em}\hspace{0.9em}A.B.\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9429cd2e-4a8c-4cda-846f-0a018623e02f/images/d1691f67-6d7f-42d3-a7ef-888357ced332/CH0852a.png)

\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9429cd2e-4a8c-4cda-846f-0a018623e02f/images/f6173c92-1fbc-4ef0-b73f-b7cc315798a1/CH0852b.png)

C.D.\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9429cd2e-4a8c-4cda-846f-0a018623e02f/images/ecbd5dfb-ef2c-4c2e-9b06-f0b6d168d5d3/CH0852c.png)

\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9429cd2e-4a8c-4cda-846f-0a018623e02f/images/be6e17c1-379a-4a1a-9daa-91a2de41a891/CH0852d.png)
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In chromatography, the presence of more than one spot indicates that the sample contains more than one component. A successful recrystallization should therefore result in only a single spot remaining, at the same position as the pure dye. One chromatogram shows this clearly: before recrystallization two spots are present, but afterwards only one spot remains. This is consistent with the removal of the contaminant and the retention of the dye.By contrast, chromatograms that still display multiple spots after recrystallization show that impurities remain in the sample. A result with no visible spots suggests that the dye itself has been lost, while a chromatogram that continues to display both dye and contaminant indicates that separation was unsuccessful.This question is of medium difficulty because students must connect the theoretical purpose of recrystallization with the experimental evidence provided by chromatography.

list.title: Question 130
list.content:
Which of the following mass spectra corresponds to chlorine?A.\hspace{1em}B.\mbox{}\\[-25pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/d3b68f53-bcaa-41cb-85ae-807f4feca98d/CH2117a.png)

\mbox{}\\[-25pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/fad74a6e-a33e-4fa7-8ab3-155d219cc9f7/CH2117b.png)

C.D.\mbox{}\\[-25pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/015d691d-93ee-47ee-92dd-688e431e6582/CH2117c.png)

\mbox{}\\[-25pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/51050137-8d3a-498d-bc05-d7bb55253a60/CH2117d.png)
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The relative atomic mass of chlorine is listed as 35.45 on the periodic table. This value is a weighted average of the masses of chlorine's naturally occurring isotopes, based on their relative abundances. Since 35.45 is much closer to 35 than to 37, it suggests that the lighter isotope(X35X2235Cl)\ce{(^{35}Cl)}(X35​X2235​Cl)is more abundant than the heavier one(X37X2237Cl).\ce{(^{37}Cl)}.(X37​X2237​Cl).In fact, chlorine exists as approximately 75%(X35X2235Cl)\ce{(^{35}Cl)}(X35​X2235​Cl)and 25%(X37X2237Cl).\ce{(^{37}Cl)}.(X37​X2237​Cl).Therefore, the correct mass spectrum must show two peaks atm/z=35m/z = 35m/z=35and 37, with the peak at 35 being roughly three times taller than the one at 37, matching the natural isotope distribution that results in a relative atomic mass of 35.45.

list.title: Question 131
list.content: If 1.20 g of magnesium metal reacts with excess hydrobromic acid, what volume of hydrogen gas is evolved at STP, given the molar volume at STP is 22.4 dm3^33?A.\hspace{1em}0.224 dm3^33B.\hspace{1em}2.24 dm3^33C.\hspace{1em}1.12 dm3^33D.\hspace{1em}4.48 dm3^33
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:V=n×Vm=1.20g24g mol−1×22.4dm3mol−1=1.12dm3V = n \times V_m= \dfrac{1.20\,\text{g}}{24\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}}\times 22.4\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = 1.12\,\text{dm}^3V=n×Vm​=24g mol−11.20g​×22.4dm3mol−1=1.12dm3

list.title: Question 132
list.content: A sample of gas at the top of a mountain has a pressure of75kPa75\text{ kPa}75kPaand a volume of4.0dm3.4.0\text{ dm}^3.4.0dm3.If that same sample is brought to the bottom of the mountain where the pressure is now100kPa,100\text{ kPa},100kPa,what is the new volume of the gas assuming that the temperature is kept constant?A.0.75dm3\hspace{1em}0.75\text{ dm}^30.75dm3B.0.19dm3\hspace{1em}0.19\text{ dm}^30.19dm3C.3.0dm3\hspace{1em}3.0\text{ dm}^33.0dm3D.5.3dm3\hspace{1em}5.3\text{ dm}^35.3dm3
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​This question is answered using the Ideal Gas Law equation,PV=nRT.PV = nRT.PV=nRT.It is assumed that the moles of the gas are the same and the temperature remains constant, so we can setPVPVPVfor each scenario to be equal to each other:P1V1=P2V2P_1V_1 = P_2V_2P1​V1​=P2​V2​whereP1V1P_1V_1P1​V1​is  the pressure and volume at the top of the mountainP2V2P_2V_2P2​V2​isthe pressure and volume at the bottom of the mountainRearranging,V2=P1V1P2=(75kPa)(4.0dm3)100kPa=3.0dm3V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{P_2} = \dfrac{(75\text{ kPa})(4.0\text{ dm}^3)}{100\text{ kPa}} = \answer{3.0\text{ dm}^{3}}V2​=P2​P1​V1​​=100kPa(75kPa)(4.0dm3)​=3.0dm3​

list.title: Question 133
list.content: 36.0 cm3^33of a 1.00 mol dm−3^{-3}−3solution of copper (II) nitrate reacts with 0.540 g of aluminum metal.How many moles of copper metal would be produced in the following reaction?3Cu(NOX3)X2+2Al→2Al(NOX3)X3+3Cu\ce{3 Cu(NO3)2 + 2 Al -> 2 Al(NO3)3 + 3 Cu}3Cu(NOX3​)X2​+2Al​2Al(NOX3​)X3​+3CuA.\hspace{1em}0.0360 molesB.\hspace{1em}0.0300 molesC.\hspace{1em}0.0200 molesD.\hspace{1em}0.0133 moles
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Find the moles of each reactant:Cu(NOX3)X2\ce{Cu(NO3)2}Cu(NOX3​)X2​:n=C×V=1.00mol dm−3×0.036dm3=0.036molCu(NOX3)X2n = C \times V = 1.00\,\textrm{mol dm}^{-3}\times 0.036\,\text{dm}^3 = 0.036\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2}n=C×V=1.00mol dm−3×0.036dm3=0.036molCu(NOX3​)X2​Al\ce{Al}Al:n=mM=0.540g27g mol−1=0.020mol Aln = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{0.540\,\text{g}}{27\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.020\,\text{mol Al}n=Mm​=27g mol−10.540g​=0.020mol AlDetermine the limiting reactant by finding the moles of copper(II) nitrate required to react with the aluminium:0.020mol Al×3molCu(NOX3)X22mol Al=0.030molCu(NOX3)X20.020\,\text{mol Al}\times \dfrac{3\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2}}{2\,\text{mol  Al}} = 0.030\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2}0.020mol Al×2mol Al3molCu(NOX3​)X2​​=0.030molCu(NOX3​)X2​Because0.036molCu(NOX3)X2>0.030molCu(NOX3)X20.036\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2} > 0.030\,\text{mol }\ce{Cu(NO3)2}0.036molCu(NOX3​)X2​>0.030molCu(NOX3​)X2​, Al is the limiting reactant.Therefore, the yield of copper can be deduced:0.020mol Al×3mol Cu2mol Al=0.030mol Cu0.020\,\text{mol Al}\times \dfrac{3\,\text{mol Cu}}{2\,\text{mol Al}} = 0.030\,\text{mol Cu}0.020mol Al×2mol Al3mol Cu​=0.030mol CuThe theoretical yield of copper is 0.030 mol Cu.

list.title: Question 134
list.content: Aluminum hydrogen carbonate will decompose to produce aluminum oxide, carbon dioxide gas, and water according to the following equation:2Al(HCOX3)X3(s)→AlX2OX3(s)+6COX2(g)+3HX2O(l)\ce{2 Al(HCO3)3(s) -> Al2O3(s) + 6 CO2(g) + 3 H_2O(l)}2Al(HCOX3​)X3​(s)​AlX2​OX3​(s)+6COX2​(g)+3HX2​O(l)If 0.300 moles of aluminum hydrogen carbonate(Mr≈210)(M_r \approx 210)(Mr​≈210)decomposes and 10.2 g of aluminum oxide(Mr≈102)(M_r \approx 102)(Mr​≈102)is collected, what is the percent yield?A.67.0%\hspace{1em}67.0\%67.0%B.33.0%\hspace{1em}33.0\%33.0%C.75.0%\hspace{1em}75.0\%75.0%D.133%\hspace{1em}133\%133%
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Determine the theoretical yield ofAlX2OX3\ce{Al2O3}AlX2​OX3​using the mole ratio from the balanced chemical equation:0.300molAl(HCOX3)X3×1molAlX2OX32molAl(HCOX3)X3=0.150molAlX2OX30.300\,\text{mol }\ce{Al(HCO3)3}\times \dfrac{1\,\text{mol }\ce{Al2O3}}{2\,\text{mol }\ce{Al(HCO3)3}} = 0.150\,\text{mol }\ce{Al2O3}0.300molAl(HCOX3​)X3​×2molAl(HCOX3​)X3​1molAlX2​OX3​​=0.150molAlX2​OX3​Determine experimental yield ofAlX2OX3\ce{Al2O3}AlX2​OX3​in moles using the relationshipn=mMn = \dfrac{m}{M}n=Mm​.10.2gAlX2OX3102g mol−1=0.100molAlX2OX3\dfrac{10.2\,\text{g }\ce{Al2O3}}{102\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.100\,\text{mol }\ce{Al2O3}102g mol−110.2gAlX2​OX3​​=0.100molAlX2​OX3​Take the ratio to find the percent yield:0.100mol0.150mol×100%=67%\dfrac{0.100\,\text{mol}}{0.150\,\text{mol}}\times 100\% = 67\%0.150mol0.100mol​×100%=67%

list.title: Question 135
list.content:
Which statement about the sequence described below is correct?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb37324e-0915-4ce5-9fc8-f418bea0e2e8/images/dbfa0984-b75c-44d5-96f4-4b37b10db02c/CH1219.png)

A.\hspace{1em}Sea water is a mixture, and the residue contains saltB.\hspace{1em}Sea water is a mixture, and the filtrate contains sandC.\hspace{1em}Pure NaCl is isolated through this sequenceD.\hspace{1em}Distilled water can be separated through this sequence
list.markScheme:
DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Seawater is a homogeneous mixture containing more than one element or compound. Seawater is made of water with dissolved salts (not only sodium chloride), some insoluble impurities suspended, and some dissolved gases.Physical methods, such as filtration and distillation, can be applied to separate the mixture's components.However, only some of the components might get isolated by this sequence. Filtration allows the separation of solid, insoluble particles from the mixture. These solid particles will remain in the residue, whereas the liquid phase will go through the filter to be collected as the filtrate.\hspace{15em}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb37324e-0915-4ce5-9fc8-f418bea0e2e8/images/585a0e5a-01f9-45bd-ad99-cbb81612c756/CH1219filtv2.png)

\hspace{15em}[Created with Chemix (http\text{http}https://chemix.org)]If the filtrate is distilled, dissolved particles will remain in the flask, and water will be vaporized and condensed as a distillate. The liquid component can be separated with this method (water). However, in the flask, all the soluble salts will remain (this might include other salts than NaCl).\hspace{10em}

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb37324e-0915-4ce5-9fc8-f418bea0e2e8/images/6373a973-26d0-419f-86cf-cbd094ef532f/CH1219distill.png)

\hspace{10em}[Created with Chemix (http\text{http}https://chemix.org)]The sequence is shown below:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb37324e-0915-4ce5-9fc8-f418bea0e2e8/images/4d52e721-1da3-4832-89a6-dbea6d56e1a1/CH1219flow.png)

This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students are expected to recall the concept of the mixture and understand how filtration and distillation allow the separation of mixtures.

list.title: Question 136
list.content: Which of the following statements aboutppporbitals are correct?I.A2p2p2porbital has the same shape as a3p3p3porbital.II.Electrons in the2p2p2porbital are, on average, closer to the nucleus than electrons in the3p3p3porbital.III.The angle between thepxp_xpx​andpyp_ypy​orbitals is90∘.90^\circ.90∘.A.\hspace{1em}I and IIB.\hspace{1em}II and IIIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Allppporbitals share the same fundamental dumbbell shape, regardless of their energy level. A2p2p2pand a3p3p3porbital have identical shapes but differ in size and energy: the3p3p3porbital is larger and has higher energy. Statement I is correct.While2p2p2pand3p3p3porbitals belong to different energy levels, electrons in a2p2p2porbital are, on average, found closer to the nucleus than those in a3p3p3porbital. This is because as the energy level increases, the average distance between the electron and the nucleus increases as well.  Statement II is also correct.Finally, the threeppporbitals(px,py,andpz)(p_x, p_y,\text{ and } p_z)(px​,py​,andpz​)are oriented along mutually perpendicular axes in three−-−dimensional space. The angle between any two of them, such aspxp_xpx​andpy,p_y,py​,is90∘.90^\circ.90∘.Statement III is correct.

list.title: Question 137
list.content: How many fully occupiedppporbitals are present in a ground–\text{--}–state arsenic (As) atom?A.\hspace{1em}2B.\hspace{1em}3C.\hspace{1em}6D.\hspace{1em}7
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:From its placement in Period 4 of the periodic table, arsenic will have two completely filledpppsubshells, or 6 filledppporbitals. The condensed electron configuration of arsenic is[Ar]4s23d104p3.[\text{Ar}]\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^3.[Ar]4s23d104p3.Hund's rule reminds us that the three valencepppelectrons in arsenic will singly–\text{--}–occupy the three4p4p4porbitals. There will be 6 fully occupiedppporbitals.

list.title: Question 138
list.content: Which electrons are lost in the formation of a copper (II)  ion from a copper atom?A.\hspace{1em}One3s3s3selectron and one3d3d3delectronB.\hspace{1em}One4s4s4selectron and one3d3d3delectronC.\hspace{1em}Two4s4s4selectronsD.\hspace{1em}Two3d3d3delectrons
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Cu\ce{Cu}Cuhas the electron configuration[Ar]4s13d10\ce{[Ar]}\, 4s^1\,3d^{10}[Ar]4s13d10(a full d-subshell is more stable). The4s4s4selectron is lost in the first ionization followed by a3d3d3delectron.

list.title: Question 139
list.content: How many unpaired electrons are in theMnX2+\ce{Mn^{2+}}MnX2+ion?A.\hspace{1em}5B.\hspace{1em}3C.\hspace{1em}1D.\hspace{1em}2
list.markScheme:
AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Manganese atoms have 25 electrons and have the electron configurationMn:1s22s22p63s23p64s23d51s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 4s^2 3d^51s22s22p63s23p64s23d5according to the aufbau principle.  When transition metals lose electrons, they lose them from the sublevel with the highestn−n-n−level.  For Mn, the two electrons are lost from the4s4s4ssublevel to form the ionMnX2+\ce{Mn^2+}MnX2+.MnX2+\ce{Mn^{2+}}MnX2+:1s22s22p63s23p63d51s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^51s22s22p63s23p63d5To determine the number of unpaired electrons, we can draw the orbital box diagram and use Hund's law which maximizes the number of unpaired electrons in partially filled sublevels.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e265c959-7bc9-4194-ba46-8554199f8bb3/images/9a9bc6c8-e8b3-49c5-af73-68b3320ed6a3/CH0777.png)

There are five unpaired electrons in theMnX2+\ce{Mn^{2+}}MnX2+ion.

list.title: Question 140
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To calculate the relative atomic mass of an element with two isotopes, we need to first read the relative abundance from the graph. The abundance of the isotope with mass 151 is 48%  and the isotope with mass 153 has an abundance of  52%. A 50:50 mix would yield an average mass of 152, since the 153 abundance is slightly higher, we expect the answer to be just more than 152.  Only one answer makes sense, 152.04.To quantitatively solve for the relative average mass(Ar),(A_r),(Ar​),we will estimate the relative abundances and take the weighted average of the masses of the two isotopes.Ar=(151)(48)+(153)(52)100=152.04A_r =\dfrac{(151)(48) + (153)(52)}{100} = 152.04Ar​=100(151)(48)+(153)(52)​=152.04To solve without a calculator, rewrite 153 as151+2151 + 2151+2in the equation above to findAr=(151)(48)+(151+2)(52)100A_r = \dfrac{(151)(48) + (151+2)(52)}{100}Ar​=100(151)(48)+(151+2)(52)​Distributing yieldsAr=(151)(48)+(151)(52)+(2)(52)100A_r = \dfrac{(151)(48) + (151)(52) + (2)(52)}{100}Ar​=100(151)(48)+(151)(52)+(2)(52)​Combine the first and second terms to find(151)(48+52)(151)(48+52)(151)(48+52)or(151)(100),(151)(100),(151)(100),soAr=(151)(100)+(2)(52)100A_r = \dfrac{(151)(100) + (2)(52)}{100}Ar​=100(151)(100)+(2)(52)​Ar=151+((2)(52)100)=151+1.04=152.04A_r = 151 + \left(\dfrac{(2)(52)}{100}\right) = 151 + 1.04 = 152.04Ar​=151+(100(2)(52)​)=151+1.04=152.04

list.title: Question 141
list.content: Which statement(s) is (are) correct about a pure substance?I.\hspace{1.em}It is always an elementII.\hspace{0.7em}Its melting point is sharp.III.\hspace{0.4em}More than one pure substance is present in a heterogeneous mixture.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}II only
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Pure substances can be elements (for example,OX2)\ce{O2})OX2​)and/or compounds (for example,HX2O).\ce{H2O}).HX2​O).Statement I is incorrect.Pure substances present a sharp melting point as they melt at a specific temperature. Statement II is correct.Heterogeneous mixtures have a non-uniform composition made by different substances physically mixed together. Statement III is correct.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must understand what a pure substance is. They are also expected to recall the melting point as a technique applied to identify pure substances (as they have a sharp melting point) and clearly understand what heterogeneous mixtures are.

list.title: Question 142
list.content: Which technique is most suitable for separating a mixture of ethanol and water?A.\hspace{1em}gravity filtrationB.\hspace{1em}distillationC.\hspace{1em}recrystallizationD.\hspace{1em}evaporation
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The separation of mixtures is dependent on the physical properties of the substances such as boiling point, solubility, or state of matter.Gravity filtrationis used to separate an insoluble  solid from a liquid by passing it through a filter.Distillationuses the difference in boiling points to  separate liquid components of a mixture.  Ethanol is more volatile than water and has a lower boiling point: it will vaporize at a lower temperature and can be collected by a condenser in a separate container.Recrystallizationis a purification method for solid substances. The impure solid is dissolved in a hot solvent, and upon cooling, pure crystals form while soluble impurities remain in the filtrateEvaporationis used to recover a dissolved solid by removing all of the liquid solvent.In this case, ethanol and water are both liquids that have different boiling points. Therefore, this mixture can be separated by distillation.

list.title: Question 143
list.content: Paper chromatography is a technique that can be used to separate which of the following?A.\hspace{1em}A liquid and an insoluble solidB.\hspace{1em}Soluble solidsC.\hspace{1em}A solid and an insoluble liquidD.\hspace{1em}Insoluble solids
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The student must correctly understand the process of paper chromatography. Components of a mixture can be successfully separated using paper chromatography only if the components are soluble in the mobile phase (the solvent). The components of the mixture can be liquids or solids when pure.This question is categorized as medium because the student must understand that solubility in the mobile phase is essential for a successful separation using paper chromatography. Beyond that, there are no calculations or other facts to recall.

list.title: Question 144
list.content: Which of the following is the correct electron configuration for iron inFeClX2?\ce{FeCl2}?FeClX2​?A.1s22s22p63s23p64s23d6\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^61s22s22p63s23p64s23d6B.1s22s22p63s23p64s23d4\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^41s22s22p63s23p64s23d4C.1s22s22p63s23p63d6\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\  3d^61s22s22p63s23p63d6D.1s22s22p63s23p64s23d8\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^81s22s22p63s23p64s23d8
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The ground–\text{--}–state electron configuration of neutral iron is1s22s22p63s23p64s23d6.1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^6.1s22s22p63s23p64s23d6.InFeClX2,\ce{FeCl2},FeClX2​,iron has a2+2+2+charge so two electrons are removed from the iron atom. In transition metals, electrons are removed from the4s4s4ssublevel first, not3d,3d,3d,even though4s4s4sis filled before3d.3d.3d.Therefore,FeX2+\ce{Fe^2+}FeX2+has the configuration1s22s22p63s23p63d6.1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 3d^6.1s22s22p63s23p63d6.

list.title: Question 145
list.content: Lithium is a low-density alkali metal that reacts vigorously with water.Given the below data and referring to the periodic table, calculate the relative abundances of the isotopes of lithium.[3]IsotopeAtomic Mass6Li^{6}\textrm{Li}6Li6.0157Li^{7}\textrm{Li}7Li7.016State the definition of an isotope.[1]Outline the concept of relative abundance.[1]
list.markScheme:
Let x be the relative abundance of Lithium-7 and (100-x) be the relative abundance of lithium-6.Periodic table shows relative atomic mass of Lithium is 6.94.✓\checkmark✓Therefore,7.016x+6.015(100−x)100=6.947.016x+601.5−6.015x100=6.947.016x+601.5−6.015x=6941.001x+601.5=694x=92.4\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{7.016x + 6.015(100-x)}{100} &= 6.94 \\
\dfrac{7.016x + 601.5 - 6.015x}{100} &= 6.94 \\
7.016x + 601.5 - 6.015x &= 694 \\
1.001x + 601.5 &= 694 \\
x &= 92.4 %
\end{aligned}1007.016x+6.015(100−x)​1007.016x+601.5−6.015x​7.016x+601.5−6.015x1.001x+601.5x​=6.94=6.94=694=694=92.4​The relative abundances of each isotope are7.6 %✓\checkmark✓for Li-6 and92.4 %✓\checkmark✓for Li-7.Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​100 - 92.4 = 7.6Isotopes are atoms of an element with the same number of protons but with different number of neutrons.✓\checkmark✓AwardfullmarkifsamenumberofprotonsANDdifferentnumberofneutronsmentioned\textit{Award full mark if same number of protons AND different number of neutrons mentioned}Award full mark if same number of protons AND different number of neutrons mentionedRelative abundance is the percent abundance in nature of a particular isotope.✓\checkmark✓

list.title: Question 146
list.content: Based on the table below, what is the correct calculation to determine the final volume of a fixed mass of gas:InitialFinalPressure (atm)1.001.60Temperature (∘^\circ∘C)2010Volume (dm3^33)5.00?A.\hspace{1em}(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)(1.60atm)(293K)\dfrac{(1.00 \ \textrm{atm})(5.00 \  \textrm{dm}^3)(283 \ \textrm{K})}{(1.60\ \textrm{atm})(293\ \textrm{K})}(1.60atm)(293K)(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)​B.\hspace{1em}(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(10∘C)(1.60atm)(20∘C)\dfrac{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00 \ \textrm{dm}^3)(10 \ ^\circ\mathrm{C})}{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(20 \  ^\circ\mathrm{C})}(1.60atm)(20∘C)(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(10∘C)​C.\hspace{1em}(1.60atm)(5.00dm3)(20∘C)(1.00atm)(10∘C)\dfrac{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00\ \textrm{dm}^3)(20 ^\circ\mathrm{C})}{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(10 ^\circ\mathrm{C})}(1.00atm)(10∘C)(1.60atm)(5.00dm3)(20∘C)​D.\hspace{1em}(1.60atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)(1.00atm)(293K)\dfrac{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00\ \textrm{dm}^3)(283\textrm{\ K})}{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(293\textrm{\ K})}(1.00atm)(293K)(1.60atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Ideal gas equation:PV=nRTPV= nRTPV=nRTThe number of moles is the same since there is a fixed mass of gas, and R is a constant.P1V1=nRT1P_1V_1= nRT_1P1​V1​=nRT1​andP2V2=nRT2P_2V_2 = nRT_2P2​V2​=nRT2​The temperature must be measured on the absolute scale, in K.Using the combined gas law equation,P1V1T1=P2V2T2\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}T1​P1​V1​​=T2​P2​V2​​we can derive the expression:V2=P1V1T2P2T1=(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)(1.60atm)(293K)V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{P_2T_1} = \dfrac{(1.00\,\text{atm})(5.00\,\text{dm}^3)(283\,\text{K})}{(1.60\,\text{atm})(293\,\text{K})}V2​=P2​T1​P1​V1​T2​​=(1.60atm)(293K)(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)​10∘C+273=283K10\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 283\,\text{K}10∘C+273=283K20∘C+273=293K20\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 293\,\text{K}20∘C+273=293K

list.title: Question 147
list.content: Which is the correct empirical formula for a compound that is composed of 40% sulfur and 60% oxygen by mass?A.SO\hspace{1em}\ce{SO}SOB.SX2OX3\hspace{1em}\ce{S2O3}SX2​OX3​C.SOX2\hspace{1em}\ce{SO2}SOX2​D.SOX3\hspace{1em}\ce{SO3}SOX3​
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​To determine the empirical formula from a mass % composition, first we assume that the sample is 100 g so that the percent composition can be easily converted to mass:40% sulfur⟶\longrightarrow⟶40 g sulfur60% oxygen⟶\longrightarrow⟶60 g oxygenNext, these masses are converted into moles:40g S×1mol32g=1.25mol S40\text{ g S}\times \dfrac{1\text{ mol}}{32\text{ g}} = 1.25\text{ mol S}40g S×32g1mol​=1.25mol S60g O×1mol16g=3.75mol O60\text{ g O}\times \dfrac{1\text{ mol}}{16\text{ g}} = 3.75\text{ mol O}60g O×16g1mol​=3.75mol OFrom here, the ratio between the atoms is determined:mol Omol S=3.75mol1.25mol=3\dfrac{\text{mol O}}{\text{mol S}} = \dfrac{3.75\text{ mol}}{1.25\text{ mol}} = 3mol Smol O​=1.25mol3.75mol​=3Therefore, there are 3 atoms of oxygen for every 1 atom of sulfur so the empirical formula isSOX3.\ce{SO3}.SOX3​.

list.title: Question 148
list.content: Element Y has 4 stable isotopes. The table below shows the relative abundance and atomic masses of these isotopes.IsotopePercent abundanceAtomic mass11.40 %203.97224.10 %205.97322.10 %206.98452.40 %207.98Calculate the relative atomic mass of the element.[2]Identify the element.[1]The atom of the element can form an ion with a charge of 4+. Determine the number of electrons in the ion.[1]Determine the nuclear symbol of another corresponding ion of element Y given the numbers of subatomic particles: electrons = 80; neutrons = 122.[1]
list.markScheme: Relative atomic mass of Element Y = (203.97) (0.014) + (205.97) (0.241)+ (206.98) (0.221) + (207.98)(0.524) =207.2✓\checkmark✓✓\checkmark✓Award2marksforcompletecorrectanswer\textit{Award 2 marks for complete correct answer}Award 2 marks for complete correct answer.Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Relative atomic mass is the sum of each atomic mass of each isotope multiplied by its percentage abundance.Lead (Pb)✓\checkmark✓Acceptnameand/orsymbol\textit{Accept name and/or symbol}Accept name and/or symbolFurther Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The element with a relative atomic mass equal to 207.2 is Lead.78✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The element is lead (Pb). Lead has an atomic number of 82. This means that a neutral atom of lead has 82 protons and 82 electrons. Its atom loses 4 electrons (82-4) and becomes a cation with a charge of 4+(Pb4+^{4+}4+).Nuclear symbol:X82204X2822204PbX2+\ce{^{204}_{82}Pb^{2+}}X82204​X2822204​PbX2+✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​There are 80 electrons in the corresponding ion. This means that the atom has lost 2 electrons and has a become an ion of charge 2+.Mass number = protons + neutrons = 82 + 122 = 204

list.title: Question 149
list.content: Which gives the correct electron configuration for the chromium atom, Cr, and the chromium cation,CrX+\ce{Cr+}CrX+?CrCr+\mathbf{^+}+A.\hspace{1em}[Ar]3d44s23d^4 4s^23d44s2[Ar]3d44s13d^4 4s^13d44s1B.\hspace{1em}[Ar]3d54s13d^5 4s^13d54s1[Ar]3d44s13d^4 4s^13d44s1C.\hspace{1em}[Ar]3d44s23d^4 4s^23d44s2[Ar]3d34s23d^3 4s^23d34s2D.\hspace{1em}[Ar]3d54s13d^5 4s^13d54s1[Ar]3d53d^53d5
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Chromium is an exception to the rule for the first−-−rowd−d-d−block elements due to the stability of a half−-−filledd−d-d−subshell. When forming a positive ion, electrons are first lost from4s4s4sand then3d3d3d.

list.title: Question 150
list.content: Under which conditions would a gas deviate the most from the ideal gas model?A.\hspace{1em}1 atm, 298 KB.\hspace{1em}200 atm, 25∘^\circ∘CC.\hspace{1em}200 kPa, 25∘^\circ∘CD.\hspace{1em}100 kPa, 298 K
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\text{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The student must understand that gases deviate from an ideal gas when the temperature is low and when the pressure is high.At low temperatures, the particles move slower and thus are able to form more intermolecular forces.At high pressure the particles are closer together, also allowing for more plentiful attractive forces.In both of these cases, intermolecular forces of attraction cannot be assumed to be negligible and so the gas under those conditions is no longer considered an ideal gas.This question is categorized as medium because the student needs to carefully consider the answer choices. A pressure of 1 atm is the same as 100 kPa. Likewise, 298 K is the same as 25∘^\circ∘C. A pressure of 200 kPa, while higher, is not high enough to drastically increase attractive forces. A pressure of 200 atm would be consistent with the pressure in a compressed gas cylinder when the gas is in liquid form, and is therefore not behaving as an ideal gas.

list.title: Question 151
list.content:
The graph below shows the successive ionization energy data for an unknown metal M.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/52199042-cddb-421f-b65d-11e90428d392/images/555bf712-15ca-47f4-8685-1f60dc9bef9a/CH1251.png)

What is the likely formula of the oxide formed with this metal?A.MO\hspace{1em}\ce{MO}MOB.MOX2\hspace{1em}\ce{MO_2}MOX2​C.MX2O\hspace{1em}\ce{M_2O}MX2​OD.MX2OX3\hspace{1em}\ce{M_2O_3}MX2​OX3​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The graph shows a large jump after the removal of the first electron, which indicates that this metal has just one valence electron. This places it in group 1 of the periodic table. In group 1 metals, the second electron lies in an inner energy level, much closer to the nucleus and much more difficult to remove, which explains the sudden increase in ionization energy.A group 1 metal forms a monovalent cation,MX+\ce{M^+}MX+, which bonds ionically with oxide,OX2−\ce{O^{2-}}OX2−. To achieve charge balance, twoMX+\ce{M^+}MX+ions combine with oneOX2−\ce{O^{2-}}OX2−, giving the formulaMX2O\ce{M2O}MX2​O.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must deduce the group of the metal to figure out the formula of the compound formed with oxygen.

list.title: Question 152
list.content:
An element X has a relative atomic mass of 21.25.Which mass spectrum corresponds to the isotopic composition of X?A.B.\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/b0f297d5-de02-4d19-9f8e-aba47a085fa2/CH1249a.png)

\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/85cc2686-44c7-4fc4-829e-caa5bf3d8634/CH1249b.png)

C.D.\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/65ba8959-0722-4060-81f2-d7e431903fb7/CH1249c.png)

\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/1cf0441e-3b60-41ab-8de6-0e574e270db3/CH1249d.png)
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The relative atomic mass of an element is calculated as the weighted mean of the isotope masses, using their percentage abundances. For spectrum A, the calculation is:Ar=(20×25)+(21×25)+(22×50)100=21.25A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 25) + (21 \times 25) + (22 \times 50)}{100} =  21.25Ar​=100(20×25)+(21×25)+(22×50)​=21.25This matches the value given in the question.For comparison:Spectrum B:Ar=(20×10)+(21×10)+(22×80)100=21.70A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 10) + (21 \times 10) + (22 \times 80)}{100} =  21.70Ar​=100(20×10)+(21×10)+(22×80)​=21.70Spectrum C:Ar=(20×90)+(21×5)+(22×5)100=20.15A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 90) + (21 \times 5) + (22 \times 5)}{100} =  20.15Ar​=100(20×90)+(21×5)+(22×5)​=20.15Spectrum D:Ar=(20×25)+(22×75)100=21.50A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 25) + (22 \times 75)}{100} =  21.50Ar​=100(20×25)+(22×75)​=21.50This question is of medium difficulty because it tests the ability to apply the weighted mean formula systematically and also to reason qualitatively about how the distribution of isotopes shifts the average mass.

list.title: Question 153
list.content:
Given below is the mass spectrum of the stable isotopes of rubidium (Rb). What is the relative atomic mass of rubidium?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6e3db916-1d81-4664-9ab6-a5028574d644/images/627f7e43-e21d-4f9a-830f-cb78841ea511/CH0053.png)

A.\hspace{1em}85.5B.\hspace{1em}86.7C.\hspace{1em}85.9D.\hspace{1em}87.4
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The approximate height of each peak is the relative abundance of each isotope.\hspace{4em}Rb–\text{--}–85∼\sim∼75 %\hspace{4em}Rb–\text{--}–87∼\sim∼25 %Rb–\text{--}–85 is the most abundant isotope within a large difference, therefore,  the relative atomic mass should be closer to 85 than 87. 85.5 is the most reasonable answer.Mathematically, we can calculate the weighted average of the mass:m=75100×85+25100×87=75100×85+25100×(85+2)=75100×85+25100×85+25100×2=85+25100×2=85.5\begin{aligned} m &= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 87\\
\\
 &= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times (85+2)\\
 \\
&= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 2\\
\\
&   = 85 +  \dfrac{25}{100}\times 2 = 85.5\\
\end{aligned}m​=10075​×85+10025​×87=10075​×85+10025​×(85+2)=10075​×85+10025​×85+10025​×2=85+10025​×2=85.5​

list.title: Question 154
list.content: What is the relative atomic mass,ArA_rAr​, of an unknown element found in a meteorite with the isotopic abundances shown below?Isotope% Abundance39X^{39}\ce{X}39X80.040X^{40}\ce{X}40X1.041X^{41}\ce{X}41X19.0A.\hspace{1em}39.00B.\hspace{1em}40.00C.\hspace{1em}39.39D.\hspace{1em}40.50
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Based on calculations, the relative atomic mass ofX\ce{X}Xis:Ar=(39×80.0)+(40×1.00)+(41×19.00)100=39.39A_r = \dfrac{\left(39\times 80.0\right)+\left(40\times 1.00\right)+(41\times 19.00\ )}{100} = 39.39Ar​=100(39×80.0)+(40×1.00)+(41×19.00)​=39.39Students are not required to work out the calculation. theArA_rAr​cab be estimated to be close to 39 due to the high percent abundance of that isotope, but slightly higher due to the existence of the more massive isotopes.

list.content:

list.title: Question 156
list.content:
The graph below shows the successive ionization energies for an atom of an element.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bc94e49-7fd3-4b70-a969-ef5f078da97d/images/83b03c82-82b4-4c1b-b650-67ea3e3bcb90/CH0687.png)

Which element could be represented by this graph?A.\hspace{1em}OB.\hspace{1em}SC.\hspace{1em}BeD.\hspace{1em}Mg
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Large increase between the second and third ionization energies provides evidence that the element is in group 2 (Be or Mg).Be only has four electrons, so this data could not be for an atom of beryllium.

list.title: Question 157
list.content: [Maximum marks: 10]Magnesium is an element in group 2 of the periodic table.State the full electron configuration for magnesium and the block it can be found in the periodic table.[2]Explain how successive ionization energies can prove that magnesium is in group 2 and period 3 of the periodic table.[3]State the equation for the second ionization energy of magnesium.[1]State an equation for the reaction between magnesium oxide and water, and comment on the pH of the resultant solution.[2]By referring to their relative ionization energies, compare the metallic behavior of magnesium to calcium and beryllium (values from the data booklet are not required).[2]

list.title: Question 158
list.content:
Which of the following best explains why dark lines appear in the following spectrum?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5365ef0-5209-4ec6-ac9b-a2122f77697a/images/9e7287da-5026-4ca4-8933-7137e113e049/CH2145.png)

A.\hspace{1em}Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons fall to lower energy levels.B.\hspace{1em}Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.C.\hspace{1em}Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons fall to lower energy levels.D.\hspace{1em}Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Dark lines in an absorption spectrum are caused by electrons in atoms absorbing photons of specific energies. These energies correspond to the difference between allowed energy levels in the atom. When atoms absorb those photons, the electrons are excited to higher energy levels, and the absorbed wavelengths are missing from the observed spectrum, creating dark lines.Some answers might seem tempting but are incorrect. For example, photons are not emitted when electrons are excited because energy must be absorbed for an electron to move to a higher level. Likewise, when electrons fall to lower energy levels, they emit photons, which is how emission spectra are formed. Suggesting that photons are absorbed while electrons fall is inaccurate, since falling to a lower energy level releases energy rather than requiring it.

list.title: Question 159
list.content: The first ionization energy of rubidium is403kJ mol−1.403\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.403kJ mol−1.What is the wavelength of convergence for the rubidium atomic spectrum?A.2970nm\hspace{1em}2970\,\text{nm}2970nmB.297nm\hspace{1em}297\,\text{nm}297nmC.2.97×10−4m\hspace{1em}2.97 \times 10^{-4}\,\text{m}2.97×10−4mD.4.93×10−31m\hspace{1em}4.93 \times 10^{-31}\,\text{m}4.93×10−31m
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The convergence limit in an atomic spectrum corresponds to the energy required to remove an electron from the ground state of the atom, which is the first ionization energy. To use this value, it must first be expressed per atom rather than per mole:Ephoton=IENA=403×103J mol−16.02×1023mol−1=6.69×10−19JE_\ce{photon} = \dfrac{\textrm{IE}}{N_A} = \dfrac{403\times 10^3\text{\ J mol}^{-1}}{6.02\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}} = 6.69\times 10^{-19}\text{\ J}Ephoton​=NA​IE​=6.02×1023mol−1403×103J mol−1​=6.69×10−19JThis is the energy of a single photon at the convergence limit. Using the relationshipE=hcλ,E = \dfrac{hc}{λ},E=λhc​,the wavelength can be determined.λ=hcE=(6.63×10−34J s)(3.00×108m s−1)6.69×10−19J=2.97×10−7m=297nm\lambda = \dfrac{hc}{E} = \dfrac{(6.63\times 10^{-34}\,\text{J s})(3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1})}{6.69\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}} = 2.97\times 10^{-7}\,\text{m} = \answer{297\,\text{nm}}λ=Ehc​=6.69×10−19J(6.63×10−34J s)(3.00×108m s−1)​=2.97×10−7m=297nm​The question is of medium difficulty because it requires students to connect the concept of ionization energy with the convergence limit, perform a unit conversion from per mole to per photon, and express the final result using the correct SI prefix.
