list.title: Question 161
list.content: A sample of oxygen gas with volumeV1V_1V1​is at pressure1.00×105Pa1.00\times\ 10^5\,\text{Pa}1.00×105Pa. At constant temperature, what is the pressure ifV1V_1V1​is halved?A.2.00×105Pa\hspace{1em}2.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}2.00×105PaB.5.00×104Pa\hspace{1em}5.00\times 10^4\,\text{Pa}5.00×104PaC.5.00×105Pa\hspace{1em}5.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}5.00×105PaD.2.00×104Pa\hspace{1em}2.00\times 10^4\,\text{Pa}2.00×104Pa
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to Boyle's Law, at constant temperature:P1V1=P2V2P_1V_1 = P_2V_2P1​V1​=P2​V2​Rearranging,P2=P1V1V2=P1V112V1=2P1P_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{V_2} = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{\frac{1}{2}V_1} = 2P_1P2​=V2​P1​V1​​=21​V1​P1​V1​​=2P1​P2=2.00×105PaP_2 = \answer{2.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}}P2​=2.00×105Pa​

list.title: Question 162
list.content: Which of the following solutions has the greatest quantity of moles of ions in solutions?A.200cm3\hspace{1em}200\text{ cm}^3200cm3of1.0mol dm−3NaCl1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ NaCl}1.0mol dm−3NaClB.200cm3\hspace{1em}200\text{ cm}^3200cm3of1.0mol dm−3MgClX21.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ MgCl2}1.0mol dm−3MgClX2​C.100cm3\hspace{1em}100\text{ cm}^3100cm3of1.0mol dm−3NaCl1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ NaCl}1.0mol dm−3NaClD.100cm3\hspace{1em}100\text{ cm}^3100cm3of1.0mol dm−3MgClX21.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\ce{ MgCl2}1.0mol dm−3MgClX2​
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​To determine the quantity of moles of ions in solution, each compound must be dissociated to reveal the stoichiometry. Next, the moles of each need to be considered using the equationn=CV.n = CV.n=CV.The greatest quantity of ions will be found in the mixtures with the highest volume, so the100cm3100\text{ cm}^3100cm3answer choices can be eliminated.For NaCl:NaCl→NaX++ClX−\ce{NaCl -> Na+ + Cl-}NaCl​NaX++ClX−n=(200cm3)(1dm31000cm3)(1.0mol dm−3)n = (200\text{ cm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\text{ dm}^3}{1000\text{ cm}^3}\right)(1.0\text{\ mol dm}^{-3})n=(200cm3)(1000cm31dm3​)(1.0mol dm−3)n=0.20mol NaCln = 0.20\text{ mol NaCl}n=0.20mol NaClThere is a1:11:11:1relationship between the moles of compound and the moles of each ion, therefore there are a total of0.2molNaX++0.2molClX−=0.4mol of ions0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Na+} + 0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Cl-} = 0.4\text{ mol of ions}0.2molNaX++0.2molClX−=0.4mol of ionsForMgCl2\mathbf{\mathit{MgCl_2}}MgCl2​:MgClX2→MgX2++2ClX−\ce{MgCl2 -> Mg^2+ + 2 Cl-}MgClX2​​MgX2++2ClX−n=(200cm3)(1dm31000cm3)(1.0mol dm−3)n = (200\text{ cm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\text{ dm}^3}{1000\text{ cm}^3}\right)(1.0\text{ mol dm}^{-3})n=(200cm3)(1000cm31dm3​)(1.0mol dm−3)n=0.20molMgClX2n = 0.20\text{ mol }\ce{MgCl2}n=0.20molMgClX2​There is a1:11:11:1relationship between the moles of compound andMgX2+\ce{Mg^2+}MgX2+and a1:21:21:2relationship between the moles of compound andClX−,\ce{Cl-},ClX−,therefore there are a total of0.2molMgX2++0.4molClX−=0.6mol of ions0.2\text{ mol }\ce{Mg^2+} + 0.4\text{ mol }\ce{Cl-} = \answer{0.6\text{ mol of ions}}0.2molMgX2++0.4molClX−=0.6mol of ions​

list.title: Question 163
list.content: What is the relative atomic mass of an element with the following isotopic mass data?\Isotope mass% abundance15022.0015151.0015227.00A.\hspace{1em}151.00B.\hspace{1em}154.50C.\hspace{1em}1.51D.\hspace{1em}151.05
list.markScheme:
DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​To answer this question, the student must use the following formula to find the relative atomic mass,ArA_rAr​:Ar=m1×a1+m2×a2+…100A_r = \dfrac{m_1\times a_1 + m_2\times a_2 + \ldots}{100}Ar​=100m1​×a1​+m2​×a2​+…​wheremim_imi​is the mass of an isotope in amu andaia_iai​is the abundance of that isotope expressed in percent.
For this question,Ar=(150×22.00)+(151×51.00)+(152×27.00)100=151.05A_r = \dfrac{(150 \times 22.00) + (151 \times 51.00) + (152 \times 27.00)}{100} = 151.05Ar​=100(150×22.00)+(151×51.00)+(152×27.00)​=151.05This question is categorized as medium difficulty because the student must know how to calculate a weighted average as opposed to a regular average. For example, if the student were to simply average 150, 151 and 152, then they would arrive at the answer 151.00 amu, while the true answer of 151.05 amu accounts for the weighted average of the isotopes.

list.title: Question 164
list.content: A mixture of100g100\textrm{\ g}100gof sand,1.00g1.00\textrm{\ g}1.00gof sodium chloride,200cm3200\textrm{\ cm}^3200cm3of water, and2.00g2.00\textrm{\ g}2.00gof iron fillings must be separated. All the components are expected to be recovered.Which sequence of steps would work for this purpose?A.\hspace{1em}Filtration, evaporation of the filtrate, and use of a magnet with the residueB.\hspace{1em}Filtration, evaporation of the residue, and use of a magnet with the filtrateC.\hspace{1em}Filtration, simple distillation of the filtrate and use of a magnet with the residueD.\hspace{1em}Filtration, simple distillation of the residue and use of a magnet with the filtrate
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Filtration separates the insoluble solid mixture of sand and iron from the sodium chloride solution. The residue on the filter paper contains sand and iron, while the sodium chloride solution passes through as the filtrate.To recover both water and sodium chloride from the filtrate, simple distillation is used. During distillation, water is collected as the distillate and sodium chloride remains in the flask. This ensures both components are obtained separately, which evaporation alone would not allow.Finally, the residue is separated into sand and iron by using a magnet, since iron filings are magnetic. This sequence ensures that all four components are successfully recovered.The question is of medium difficulty, as students must identify the correct order of separation techniques and understand the purpose of each step.

list.title: Question 165
list.content: The boiling point of propan−-−2−-−ol is82∘C.82\,{}^\circ\text{C}.82∘C.Which statement(s) below is(are) correct?I.\hspace{1.em}Evaporation of propan−-−2−-−ol can occur at80∘C.80\,{}^\circ\text{C}.80∘C.II.\hspace{0.7em}Condensation of propan−-−2−-−ol can occur at82∘C.82\,{}^\circ\text{C}.82∘C.III.\hspace{0.4em}At100∘C100\,{}^\circ\text{C}100∘C, propan−-−2−-−ol molecules are close together and randomly arranged.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}III only
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Evaporation is the change from liquid to gas at the surface of a liquid and can occur at any temperature below the boiling point. Therefore, propan−-−2−-−ol can evaporate at80,∘C80,{}^\circ\text{C}80,∘C, making Statement I correct.The boiling point is also the condensation point, since it is the temperature at which liquid and gas are in equilibrium. Propan−-−2−-−ol can both boil and condense at82,∘C82,{}^\circ\text{C}82,∘C, so Statement II is correct.At100,∘C100,{}^\circ\text{C}100,∘C, propan−-−2−-−ol is above its boiling point and exists as a gas. In the gaseous state, particles are far apart and move randomly, not close together. This means Statement III is incorrect.This is a challenging question, as it requires students to distinguish between evaporation and boiling, apply the idea that boiling and condensation occur at the same temperature, and link these concepts to the particle model of matter.

list.title: Question 166
list.content:
A solution of propan−-−1−-−ol and propan−-−2−-−ol must be separated. The full structural formulas of these are given below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/00dedc88-7e57-4767-96b3-881206963b72/images/a60e3a4b-67bc-4abd-ae31-a49cda8a6d52/CH1095.png)

Which statement(s) is(are) correct?I.\hspace{1.em}Distillation allows the separation of the components of this mixture.II.\hspace{0.7em}A condenser, thermometer, and evaporating basin are needed for distillation.III.\hspace{0.4em}The distillate would be propan−-−2−-−ol.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}III onlyD.\hspace{1em}II only
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Distillation is used to separate mixtures of miscible liquids with different boiling points, so Statement I is correct. The process involves heating the mixture until the more volatile liquid (the one with the lower boiling point) vaporizes, then condensing and collecting this vapor as the distillate. The less volatile component remains in the distillation flask.Here is the typical setup:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/00dedc88-7e57-4767-96b3-881206963b72/images/8bca4d25-da81-4aca-91e2-e91a58ca3eea/unnamed%20(1).png)

[© Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]\footnotesize{\textrm{[© Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}[c◯Revision Village 2023. Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]Statement II is incorrect because an evaporating basin is not used in distillation; the essential apparatus includes a distillation flask, a condenser, and a thermometer.Statement III is correct because propan−-−2−-−ol has more branching than propan−-−1−-−ol, leading to weaker intermolecular forces and therefore a lower boiling point. This means propan−-−2−-−ol vaporizes and is collected first as the distillate.This question is of moderate difficulty since it requires both knowledge of distillation as a separation technique and an understanding of how molecular structure affects boiling points.

list.title: Question 167
list.content: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a powerful diagnostic tool commonly used in medicine. They operate at a frequency of approximately2.00×1022.00 \times 10^22.00×102MHz. Using Section 5 of the IB Chemistry data booklet, in what region of the spectrum do MRI machines operate?A.\hspace{1em}RadioB.\hspace{1em}MicrowavesC.\hspace{1em}InfraredD.\hspace{1em}X−-−ray
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​A frequency of2.00×1022.00 \times 10^22.00×102MHz equals2.00×1082.00 \times 10^82.00×108Hz (1 MHz =1×1061 \times 10^61×106Hz).Frequency and wavelength are inversely proportional according to the equation, c =λf\lambda fλf.λ\lambdaλ=cf\dfrac{c}{f}fc​=3.00×108m s−12.00×108s−1=1.5m\dfrac{3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1}}{2.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ s}^{-1}} = 1.5 \textrm{\ m}2.00×108s−13.00×108m s−1​=1.5mThis wavelength lies in the radiowave portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.

list.title: Question 168
list.content: The table below shows the data gathered by a chemist regarding substances A, B, and C. Using the data given, discuss which is a pure substance or a mixture. If the substance is a pure substance, determine whether it is an element or a compound.SubstanceAppearanceMelting pointObserved propertyAWhite crystalline solid801∘C801\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C}801∘CIn aqueous solution, it reacts with silver nitrate forming a precipitate of silver chlorideBSilver metallic appearance660∘C660\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C}660∘CReacts with oxygen forming an oxideCFine white crystalline solid186∘C186\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C}186∘C-800∘C800\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C}800∘CReadily dissolves in water
list.markScheme: Substance A - pure substance/ compound✓\checkmark✓Substance B - pure substance/element✓\checkmark✓Substance C - mixture✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Substance A has a distinct melting point, which means it has a definite composition, hence it is a pure substance. The precipitate formed is a product of a double displacement reaction, which means substance A is a compound.Substance B also has a distinct melting point and is considered a pure substance. Substance B reacts with oxygen to form an oxide. This is an example of a synthesis reaction between an element (metal) and oxygen.Substance C has no distinct melting point. This implies that two or more substances are combined physically as a mixture. Mixtures do not have a definite composition and distinct properties.

list.title: Question 169
list.content:
The successive ionization energies for an unknown element are shown in the graph below. Which of the following statements regarding this element are correct?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2db804f3-104c-455a-aca4-896f6a765086/images/2e72a968-a136-4f83-8d80-c2744eefff9a/CH0778.png)

I.\hspace{1.em}Removal of the 4th electron is from a different energy level than the first 3 electrons.II.\hspace{0.7em}This element belongs in Group 13 on the periodic table.III.\hspace{0.4em}The effective nuclear charge is decreasing with the removal of successive electrons.A.\hspace{1em}I, II, and IIIB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​There is a disproportionate increase in ionization energy between the removal of the 3rd and 4th electron. Therefore, this element has 3 valence electrons, and the removal of the 4th electron would come from a lower energy level, and the element belongs in Group 13.With the removal of each subsequent electron, the remaining electrons experience less interference with one another and will experience a greater pull from the nucleus.

list.title: Question 171
list.content: Which of the following solutions will produce a neutral solution when reacted with 0.05 mol of sulfuric acid?A.50.0cm3of1.00mol dm−3NaOH\hspace{1em}50.0 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \text { of }\,  1.00 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3} \ce{\ NaOH}50.0cm3of1.00mol dm−3NaOHB.100.0cm3of2.00moldm−3NaOH\hspace{1em}100.0 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \text { of }\,  2.00 \textrm{\ mol\, dm}^{-3} \ce{\ NaOH}100.0cm3of2.00moldm−3NaOHC.100.0cm3of2.00moldm−3Ca(OH)X2\hspace{1em}100.0 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \text{ of }\,  2.00 \textrm{\ mol\, dm}^{-3}  \ce{\ Ca(OH)2}100.0cm3of2.00moldm−3Ca(OH)X2​D.25.0cm3of2.00moldm−3Ca(OH)X2\hspace{1em}25.0 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \text{ of }\,  2.00\textrm{\ mol\, dm}^{-3}  \ce{\ Ca(OH)2}25.0cm3of2.00moldm−3Ca(OH)X2​
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Sulfuric acid is diprotic and so reacts in a1:11:11:1ratio withCa(OH)X2\ce{Ca(OH)2}Ca(OH)X2​and a1:21:21:2ratio withNaOH.\ce{NaOH}.NaOH.n=CVn=CVn=CVwherennnis the amount in moles,CCCis the concentration andVVVis the volume in dm3.^3.3.In D,n=0.025dm3×2.00mol dm−3=0.05moln =0.025 \textrm{\ dm}^3 \times 2.00 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3} = 0.05 \textrm{\ mol}n=0.025dm3×2.00mol dm−3=0.05mol

list.title: Question 172
list.content: Which statement(s) is(are) correct for chromium?I.\hspace{1.em}The electron configuration for its divalent cation is[Ar]3d5.\ce{[Ar]}3d^5.[Ar]3d5.II.\hspace{0.7em}It belongs to thed−d-d−block.III.\hspace{0.4em}Its condensed electronic configuration is[Ar]4s23d4.\ce{[Ar]}4s^2\,3d^4.[Ar]4s23d4.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}III only
list.markScheme:
BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Neutral chromium has the observed ground−-−state configuration[Ar]4s13d5\ce{[Ar]}4s^1 \,3d^5[Ar]4s13d5(the4s4s4sand3d3d3dsubshells are very close in energy, and the4s13d54s^1 \,3d^54s13d5arrangement is lower in energy than4s23d44s^2 \, 3d^44s23d4for the atom). Statement III is false.When chromium cations form, the4s4s4selectrons are removed before the3d3d3delectrons (electrons are removed from the highestnnnlevel). ForCrX2+,\ce{Cr^{2+}},CrX2+,the electron configuration is[Ar]3d4.\ce{[Ar]}3d^4.[Ar]3d4.Statement I is false.With its highest−-−energy electrons in the3d3d3dsubshell, chromium belongs to thed−d-d−block transition metals.  Its placement in the periodic table supports this assessment.  Statement II is true.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3984ad5b-c9b4-4c1f-b0cd-bb001f4e6c5c/images/661f93f8-2ee6-44fe-9c0f-89c979cd5c80/CH1222.png)

list.title: Question 173
list.content: Which statements about successive ionization energies of sodium are correct?I.\hspace{1.em}They show an increasing trend as the number of electrons removed increases.II.\hspace{0.7em}There is a significant jump from the second to the third ionization energy.III.\hspace{0.4em}There is a significant jump from the ninth to the tenth ionization energy.A.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Successive ionization energies (IEn\ce{IE}_nIEn​) always increase as electrons are removed from an increasingly positive ion and from orbitals of lower energy, so statement I is correct.Sodium has the ground−-−state configuration1s22s22p63s1.1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^1.1s22s22p63s1.The largest jump for Na occurs when you cross from removing the valence electron to removing a core electron. For Na,IE1\ce{IE}_1IE1​removes the3s3s3selectron;IE2\ce{IE}_2IE2​begins removingn=2n=2n=2core electrons. Thus the big discontinuity is betweenIE1\ce{IE}_1IE1​andIE2,\ce{IE}_2,IE2​,(not betweenIE2\ce{IE}_2IE2​andIE3.\ce{IE}_3.IE3​.Statement II is incorrect.After nine electrons have been removed(IE1(\ce{IE}_1(IE1​throughIE9),\ce{IE}_9),IE9​),the remaining configuration is1s2.1s^2.1s2.The tenth ionization must remove a1s1s1selectron (crossing from then=2n=2n=2shell into then=1n=1n=1shell), which requires a dramatically larger energy. Therefore there is a second clear jump fromIE9\ce{IE}_9IE9​toIE10,\ce{IE}_{10},IE10​,so statement III is correct.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must be able to deduce the pattern for successive ionization energies of a given atom.

list.title: Question 174
list.content: Element Y has a greater atomic number than element X whilst X has a greater relative atomic mass than element Y. What is the most likely explanation?A.\mbox{}\\[-48pts]The relative atomic mass on an element is determined by the number of protons and neutrons and increases with increasing atomic number.B.\mbox{}\\[-48pts]He relative atomic mass of an element is determined by the number of isotopes of an element and increases with increasing isotopes per element.C.\mbox{}\\[-48pts]The relative atomic mass of an element is determined by the mass and abundance of its isotopes.D.\mbox{}\\[-38pts]The relative atomic mass of an element is determined by its most abundant isotope.
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The relative atomic mass of an element is determined by the mass and abundance of its isotopes. Even though element Y has a higher atomic number, element X has a greater relative atomic mass because its isotopes are heavier on average.Real examples can be found with argon and potassium or cobalt and nickel.181818\\Ar\LARGE{\textrm{Ar}}Ar\\39.95\ \ \ \ \ 39.95\ \ \ \ \39.95191919\\K\LARGE{\textrm{K}}K\\39.10\ \ \ \ \ 39.10 \ \ \ \ \39.10\ \ \ \ \272727\\Co\LARGE{\textrm{Co}}Co\\58.93\ \ \ \ \ 58.93\ \ \ \ \58.93282828\\Ni\LARGE{\textrm{Ni}}Ni\\58.69\ \ \ \ \ 58.69\ \ \ \ \58.69\\elementatomic number /\\number of protonsmost common isotopenumber of neutronsargon18argon−40-40−4022potassium19potassium−39-39−3920cobalt27cobalt−59-59−5932nickel28nickel−58-58−5830Despite having a lower atomic number, argon has a greater relative atomic mass than potassium because its most abundant isotope is argon−40,-40,−40,with 22 neutrons while potassium has lighter isotopes like potassium−39-39−39with only 20 neutrons.  Similarly, cobalt has more neutrons than nickel so its relative atomic mass is higher than nickel's. This relative atomic mass depends more on isotopic composition than atomic number.

list.title: Question 175
Question 176
list.content: Different isotopes of titanium are listed below, with their corresponding abundances found in a sample:X46X2246Ti\ce{^{46}Ti}X46​X2246​TiX47X2247Ti\ce{^{47}Ti}X47​X2247​TiX48X2248Ti\ce{^{48}Ti}X48​X2248​TiX49X2249Ti\ce{^{49}Ti}X49​X2249​TiX50X2250Ti\ce{^{50}Ti}X50​X2250​Ti% Abundance8.257.443.725.4175.18Which statement is correct for this sample?A.\hspace{1em}The calculated relative atomic mass is 47.87; the titanium is consistent with samples found on Earth.B.\hspace{1em}The calculated relative atomic mass is 49.32; the titanium is consistent with samples found on Earth.C.\hspace{1em}The calculated relative atomic mass is 49.32; the titanium may have an extraterrestrial origin.D.\hspace{1em}The calculated relative atomic mass is 48.00; the titanium may have an extraterrestrial origin.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The relative atomic mass from the isotopic abundance provided, is a weighted average of the isotope masses:Ar=46×8.25+47×7.44+48×3.72+49×5.41+50×75.18100A_r = \dfrac{46\times 8.25 + 47\times 7.44 + 48\times 3.72 + 49\times 5.41 + 50\times 75.18}{100}Ar​=10046×8.25+47×7.44+48×3.72+49×5.41+50×75.18​Ar=4931.83100=49.32A_r = \dfrac{4931.83}{100} = 49.32Ar​=1004931.83​=49.32The relative atomic mass listed for titanium in the periodic tableis 47.87 which differs from this sample with relative atomic mass 49.32. Isotopic abundances differ from one planet to another. The periodic table values are tabulated, considering the isotopic abundances on Earth. As a result, we can suggest that the sample of titanium tested may not belong to Earth.This question is categorized as medium as students must calculate the relative atomic mass from data and understand the nature of tabulated values in the periodic table.

list.title: Question 177
list.content:
The mass spectrum of chlorine gas is shown below:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4bc5f423-1a7e-49fa-88a1-ba5cabcfaf57/images/2bcbbf89-7755-48f9-8623-c37ddbea106e/S1.2H-949.png)

Calculate the relative molecular mass of chlorine gas using the mass spectrum.[2]State the identity of the particle responsible for the peak at 35m/zm/zm/z.[1]Calculate the relative atomic mass of chlorine using the mass spectrum.[2]
list.markScheme:
(70×100)+(72×65)+(74×10)100+65+10✓\dfrac{(70 \times 100) + (72 \times 65) + (74 \times 10)}{100 + 65 + 10}  \checkmark100+65+10(70×100)+(72×65)+(74×10)​✓70.97✓\checkmark✓Award [2] for the correct answer with working data;Do not award M1 or M2 for an answer with no working data (data book value).Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​Since chlorine gas exists as a diatomic molecule, the student needs to focus only on the masses forClX2\ce{Cl2}ClX2​(as opposed to Cl atom).This means that the masses at 35m/zm/zm/zand 37m/zm/zm/zcan be ignored. The masses at 70m/zm/zm/z, 72m/zm/zm/z, and 74m/zm/zm/zare for chlorine gas composed of the combinations of isotopes for chlorine:70m/z=ClX2m/z  = \ce{Cl2}m/z=ClX2​composed of twoX35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​Clatoms: 35 + 35 = 7072m/z=ClX2m/z = \ce{Cl2}m/z=ClX2​composed ofX37X2237Cl\ce{^{37}Cl}X37​X2237​ClandX35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​Clatoms: 35 + 37 = 7274m/z=ClX2m/z = \ce{Cl2}m/z=ClX2​composed of twoX37X2237Cl\ce{^{37}Cl}X37​X2237​Clatoms: 37 + 37 = 74The answer is calculated as follows:Relativemolecularmass=(isotopemass1×rel.intensity)+(isotopemass2×rel.intensity)+…Totalrel.intensity=(70×100)+(72×65)+(74×10)100+65+10=70.97\begin{aligned}
Relative\ molecular\ mass &= \dfrac{(isotope\ mass_ 1 \times rel.\ intensity) + (isotope\ mass_ 2 \times rel.\ intensity) + \ldots}{Total\ rel.\ intensity} \\	
&= \dfrac{(70 \times 100) + (72 \times 65) + (74 \times 10)}{100 + 65 + 10} \\
&= 70.97
\end{aligned}Relativemolecularmass​=Totalrel.intensity(isotopemass1​×rel.intensity)+(isotopemass2​×rel.intensity)+…​=100+65+10(70×100)+(72×65)+(74×10)​=70.97​X35X2235ClX+✓\ce{^{35}Cl^+}\,\checkmarkX35​X2235​ClX+✓Do not award M1 if the + sign is missing.Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​The detector for a mass spectrum will record cations that are either atoms, molecules, or fragments of molecules. In this case, the sample is of chlorine and so the peak at 35m/zm/zm/zis from a single atom ofX35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​Clthat has been bombarded with electrons in the mass spectrometer, resulting in the charged particle,X35X2235ClX+\ce{^{35}Cl+}X35​X2235​ClX+.(35×83)+(37×27)83+27✓\dfrac{(35 \times 83) + (37 \times 27)}{83 + 27} \checkmark83+27(35×83)+(37×27)​✓35.49✓\checkmark✓Award [2] for the correct answer within 0.05 with working data;Do not award M1 or M2 for an answer with no working data (data book value).Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​Since the question is asking only for the relative atomic mass of a chlorine atom, the student needs to focus only on the masses for the isotopes of Cl (as opposed toClX2\ce{Cl2}ClX2​).This means that the masses at 70m/z, 72m/z, and 74m/zcan be ignored. The masses at 35m/zand 37m/zare for isotopes of chlorine and their abundance is used to calculate the relative atomic mass of chlorine.The answer is calculated as follows:Relativeatomicmass=(isotopemass1×rel.intensity)+(isotopemass2×rel.intensity)+…Totalrel.intensity=(35×83)+(37×27)83+27=35.49\begin{aligned}
Relative\ atomic\ mass &=\dfrac{(isotope\ mass_ 1 \times rel.\ intensity) + (isotope\ mass_ 2 \times rel.\ intensity) + …}{Total\ rel.\ intensity} \\
&= \dfrac{(35 \times 83) + (37 \times 27)}{83 + 27} = 35.49
\end{aligned}Relativeatomicmass​=Totalrel.intensity(isotopemass1​×rel.intensity)+(isotopemass2​×rel.intensity)+…​=83+27(35×83)+(37×27)​=35.49​

list.title: Question 178
list.content: Successive ionization energies for elementsXXXandYYYinkJmol−1\textrm{kJ\, mol}^{-1}kJmol−1are shown in the table below. Which of the following ionic compounds is most likely to be formed when elementsXXXandYYYreact?\newlineSuccessive Ionization Energies (kJ mol−1^\mathbf{-1}−1)\enskipElement\enskip1st^{\mathbf{st}}st2nd^{\mathbf{nd}}nd3rd^{\mathbf{rd}}rd4th^{\mathbf{th}}th5th^{\mathbf{th}}th6th^{\mathbf{th}}th7th^{\mathbf{th}}th8th^{\mathbf{th}}thXXX7381450\enskip1450\enskip14507730\enskip7730 \enskip773010500\enskip10500\enskip1050013600\enskip13600\enskip1360018000\enskip18000\enskip1800021700\enskip21700\enskip2170025700\enskip25700\enskip25700YYY\enskip1250\enskip230038205160654093601100033600A.\hspace{1em}XYB.\hspace{1em}X2_22​YC.\hspace{1em}XY2_22​D.\hspace{1em}XY3_33​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:XXXis in Group 2, as there is a large increase between the 2nd and 3rd ionization energies.YYYis in Group 17, as there is a large increase between the 7th and 8th ionization energies.Group 2 elements form 2+ ions, Group 17 forms1−1-1−ions.

list.title: Question 179
list.content: What is the molecular formula of a compound with an empirical formula ofCHX2O\ce{CH2O}CHX2​Oand a molar mass of180.18g mol−1?180.18 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}?180.18g mol−1?A.CHX2O\hspace{1em}\ce{CH2O}CHX2​OB.CX6HX6OX6\hspace{1em}\ce{C6H6O6}CX6​HX6​OX6​C.CX6HX12OX6\hspace{1em}\ce{C6H12O6}CX6​HX12​OX6​D.CX5HX10OX5\hspace{1em}\ce{C5H10O5}CX5​HX10​OX5​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Students must understand the difference between molecular and empirical formulas.he empirical formula gives the simplest ratio of atoms in a molecule, whereas the molecular formula gives the actual number of atoms present in a molecule. If these two differ, the molecular formula can be deduced from the empirical formula.Empirical formula:CHX2O\ce{CH2O}CHX2​O12.01+2×1.01+16.00=30.03g mol−112.01 + 2\times 1.01 + 16.00 = 30.03\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}12.01+2×1.01+16.00=30.03g mol−1180.18g mol−130.03g mol−1≈6\dfrac{180.18\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}}{30.03\,\textrm{g mol}^{-1}}\approx 630.03g mol−1180.18g mol−1​≈6Molecular formula (six times the empirical formula):CX6HX12OX6\ce{C6H12O6}CX6​HX12​OX6​This question is categorized as medium as students must differentiate between molecular and empirical formulas and deduce the molecular formula with the periodic table and the molar mass given.

list.title: Question 180
list.content: Nickel has five stable isotopes. The masses and percent abundances are tabulated below:IsotopePercent abundance58^{58}58Ni68.08%60^{60}60Ni26.22%61^{61}61Ni1.14%62^{62}62NiA64^{64}64NiBThe relative atomic mass of nickel is 58.745, calculate the percent abundance of nickel–\text{--}–62 and nickel–\text{--}–64.[3]State the number of protons and neutrons in nickel–\text{--}–62.[1]Using your results from part (a), sketch the mass spectrum of nickel.[3]
list.markScheme:
58(68.08)+60(26.22)+61(1.14)+62A+64B=58.745(100)✓58(68.08)+ 60(26.22) + 61(1.14)+ 62A+ 64B = 58.745(100)\ \checkmark58(68.08)+60(26.22)+61(1.14)+62A+64B=58.745(100)✓A+B=100−(68.08+26.22+1.14)=4.56✓A + B = 100 - (68.08 + 26.22 + 1.14) = 4.56\ \checkmarkA+B=100−(68.08+26.22+1.14)=4.56✓A=4.36A = 4.36A=4.36ANDB=0.19✓B = 0.19\ \checkmarkB=0.19✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The weighted average of the isotopes must be equal to the relative atomic mass of nickel, 58.74.58.745=(58)(68.08)+(60)(26.22)+(61)(1.14)+62A+64B10058.745 = \dfrac{(58)(68.08) + (60)(26.22) + (61)(1.14) + 62A + 64B}{100}58.745=100(58)(68.08)+(60)(26.22)+(61)(1.14)+62A+64B​and the sum of the percent abundances must be 100.68.08+26.22+1.14+A+B=10068.08 + 26.22 + 1.14 + A + B = 10068.08+26.22+1.14+A+B=100Solving these two equations and two unknowns will giveAAAandB.B.B.From equation 2,A+B=4.56A + B = 4.56\quadA+B=4.56orB=4.56−A\quad B = 4.56 - AB=4.56−APlugging that in to equation 1,5874.5=5591.38+62A+64(4.56−A)5874.5 = 5591.38 + 62A + 64(4.56 - A)5874.5=5591.38+62A+64(4.56−A)Solving forAAAandBBBgive:A=4.36A = 4.36A=4.36andB=0.20B = 0.20B=0.20protons: 28ANDneutrons:62−28=34✓62 - 28 = 34\ \checkmark62−28=34✓\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/601d52e5-637f-40a8-a317-f72d356818d1/images/e9bf53d1-b776-4c7f-9e98-4b9091d034a8/CH2113v2.png)

Correct atomic masses for each isotope✓\checkmark✓Correct relative peak heights✓\checkmark✓Proper labeling of axes:x–x\text{--}x–axis:m/zm/zm/zor atomic massANDy–y\text{--}y–axis: relative abundance or intensity✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​A mass spectrum shows how many atoms of each isotope are present in a sample of an element, based on their mass–to–\text{--to--}–to–charge ratio(m/z).(m/z).(m/z).Each line represents an isotope assuming a+1+1+1charge. The height of the line corresponds to its abundance.

list.title: Question 181
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass of an element with the following mass spectrum?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/655b6395-7771-466f-97a8-4bdc04e9853b/images/6d6d10f7-cc62-41df-8124-e5af8c1d2c9c/S1.2H-948.png)

A.\hspace{1em}77B.\hspace{1em}76.3C.\hspace{1em}76D.\hspace{1em}75.8
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The student must apply the following equation to answer this question:Ar=(mass1×abundance1)+(mass2×abundance2)+…100A_r = \dfrac{(\textrm{mass}_ 1 \times \textrm{abundance}_1) + (\textrm{mass}_2 \times \textrm{abundance}_2)+ \ldots}{100}Ar​=100(mass1​×abundance1​)+(mass2​×abundance2​)+…​Applying the values from the graph:Ar=(75×20)+(76×30)+(77×50)100=76.3A_r =\dfrac{(75 \times 20) + (76 \times 30) + (77 \times 50)}{100} = 76.3Ar​=100(75×20)+(76×30)+(77×50)​=76.3This question is of medium difficulty as the student only needs to extract data from the graph and apply it in a standard way.

list.title: Question 182
list.content:
The figure shows the visible line emission spectrum of hydrogen.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71ddcbaf-7480-4a2b-adb7-ed5924a6edbf/images/3c917e33-7871-4db3-92fb-7ba883f0f5f8/CH2146.png)

Which of the following transitions is most likely responsible for the red line in the spectrum?A.n=5⟶n=2\hspace{1em}n = 5\longrightarrow n = 2n=5⟶n=2B.n=2⟶n=1\hspace{1em}n = 2\longrightarrow n = 1n=2⟶n=1C.n=4⟶n=2\hspace{1em}n = 4\longrightarrow n = 2n=4⟶n=2D.n=3⟶n=2\hspace{1em}n = 3\longrightarrow n = 2n=3⟶n=2
list.markScheme:
DExplanation:‾\underline{\text{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The red line marked in the figure is the longest-wavelength of the four visible lines and must come from the smallest energy drop that ends at the second energy level. Of the options given, the transition fromn=3n = 3n=3down ton=2n = 2n=2fits that description: it releases less energy than drops fromn=4n = 4n=4orn=5n = 5n=5ton=2,n = 2,n=2,so its photon has a longer wavelength and appears red. Then=2⟶n=1n = 2 \longrightarrow n = 1n=2⟶n=1transition is ruled out because it ends at the first level and produces ultraviolet light, which is not visible in the spectrum shown.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/71ddcbaf-7480-4a2b-adb7-ed5924a6edbf/images/058442e4-9a9f-423c-b942-81f41aad4b2c/CH2146ans.JPEG)

list.title: Question 183
list.content: 6.00 g of ethane gas(Mr≈30)(M_r \approx 30)(Mr​≈30)is placed in a flexible container at STP. The conditions are then changed to a new pressure of 200,000 Pa and a new temperature of 546 K.What is the new volume of the container after equilibrating to the new temperature and pressure?The molar volume of a gas at STP is 22.7 dm3^33.A.22.7dm3\hspace{1em}22.7\,\text{dm}^322.7dm3B.2.27dm3\hspace{1em}2.27\,\text{dm}^32.27dm3C.4.54dm3\hspace{1em}4.54\,\text{dm}^34.54dm3D.9.08dm3\hspace{1em}9.08\,\text{dm}^39.08dm3
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​At STP, standard temperature and pressure, the pressure is 100 kPa (100,000 Pa) and the temperature is 0∘^\circ∘C (273 K). A sample of ethane gas is taken from standard conditions and put into new conditions where the pressure is doubled (200000 kPa) and the temperature is doubled (546 K).The amount of ethane is constant through the experiment:nCX2HX6=mM=6.00g30g mol−1=0.200moln_\ce{C2H6} = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{6.00\,\text{g}}{30\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.200\,\text{mol}nCX2​HX6​​=Mm​=30g mol−16.00g​=0.200molUsing the molar volume of a gas at STP, we can deduce the original volume of the gas:V1=nVm=0.200mol×22.7dm3mol−1=4.54dm3V_1 = n V_m = 0.200\,\text{mol}\times 22.7\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = 4.54\,\text{dm}^3V1​=nVm​=0.200mol×22.7dm3mol−1=4.54dm3The final volume of the gas can be determined from the combined gas law:P1V1T1=P2V2T2\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}T1​P1​V1​​=T2​P2​V2​​Solving forV2V_2V2​:V2=P1V1T2T1P2V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{T_1P_2}V2​=T1​P2​P1​V1​T2​​;Logically, the pressureP2P_2P2​and the temperatureT2T_2T2​doubled, so the volumeV2V_2V2​remains the same. Mathematically,V2=100000Pa×4.54dm3×546K273K×200000PaV_2 = \dfrac{100000\,\text{Pa}\times 4.54\,\text{dm}^3\times 546\,\text{K}}{273\,\text{K}\times 200000\text{Pa}}V2​=273K×200000Pa100000Pa×4.54dm3×546K​The final volume of ethane is 4.54 dm3^33.

list.title: Question 184
list.content: A sample of9.70g9.70\,\text{g}9.70gof an unknown organic compound composed of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen was burnt with excess oxygen. The combustion produced nitrogen gas,27.5g27.5\,\text{g}27.5gofCOX2\ce{CO2}COX2​and6.57g6.57\,\text{g}6.57gofHX2O\ce{H2O}HX2​O.Calculate the mass of nitrogen produced.[3]Determine the empirical formula of the compound.[2]

list.title: Question 185
list.content: A gas is placed in a sealed rigid container and heated. What happens to the gas particles according to the kinetic molecular theory?A.\hspace{1em}They move faster and collide more frequently with each other, but the pressure remains constant.B.\hspace{1em}They gain kinetic energy and move faster, increasing collisions with the container walls, which increases pressure.C.\hspace{1em}They expand within the container, increasing the density of the gas.D.\hspace{1em}They gain kinetic energy, but temperature remains constant as intermolecular forces are overcome.
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​According to the kinetic molecular theory, when a gas is heated, the particles gain kinetic energy and move faster. Since the gas is in a sealed rigid container, the volume remains constant, meaning the only way for the gas to respond to heating is by increasing pressure. This happens because faster–\text{--}–moving particles collide more frequently and with greater force against the container walls, as described by Gay–\text{--}–Lussac's Law(P∝T(P\propto T(P∝Tat constant volume).

list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For neutralization, the moles of the acid must bestoichiometricallyequivalent\textit{stoichiometrically equivalent}stoichiometrically equivalentto the moles of base, that is they must appear in the3:23:23:2ratio given by the balanced chemical equation.First, find the moles of barium hydroxide using the relationshipn=CVn = CVn=CVwherennnis the amount in moles,CCCis the concentration in mol dm−3^{-3}−3andVVVis the volume in dm3^33.nBa(OH)X2=0.030mol dm−3×50.0cm31000cm3dm−3=0.0015moln_\ce{Ba(OH)2} = 0.030\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times \dfrac{50.0\,\text{cm}^3}{1000\,\text{cm}^3\,\text{dm}^{-3}} = 0.0015\,\text{mol}nBa(OH)X2​​=0.030mol dm−3×1000cm3dm−350.0cm3​=0.0015molThe moles of phosphoric acid can be deduced from the mole ratio:nHX3POX4=0.0015molBa(OH)X2×2molHX3POX43molBa(OH)X2=0.0010moln_\ce{H3PO4} = 0.0015\,\text{mol }\ce{Ba(OH)2}\times \dfrac{2\,\text{mol }\ce{H3PO4}}{3\,\text{mol }\ce{Ba(OH)2}} = 0.0010\,\text{mol}nHX3​POX4​​=0.0015molBa(OH)X2​×3molBa(OH)X2​2molHX3​POX4​​=0.0010molThe volume of phosphoric acid can be found with the relathionshipV=nCV = \dfrac{n}{C}V=Cn​, where the volume is converted back the cm3^33to match the answer choices.V=0.0010molHX3POX40.100mol dm−3×1000cm3dm−3=10cm3V = \dfrac{0.0010\,\text{mol }\ce{H3PO4}}{0.100\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}}\times 1000\,\text{cm}^3\,\text{dm}^{-3} = 10\,\text{cm}^3V=0.100mol dm−30.0010molHX3​POX4​​×1000cm3dm−3=10cm3The total volume required is10cm310\,\text{cm}^310cm3.

list.title: Question 187
list.content: The table below shows the successive ionization energies of two elements X and Y.Number of electrons removedIonization energy of X / kJ mol−1\mathbf{^{-1}}−1Ionization energy of Y / kJ mol−1\mathbf{^{-1}}−1149610002456222523691033574954345565133547004616613849672011727107Which is the correct formula for the compound formed between X and Y?A.XX2YX3\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y3}XX2​YX3​B.XY\hspace{1em}\ce{XY}XYC.XX2Y\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y}XX2​YD.XYX2\hspace{1em}\ce{XY2}XYX2​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The student must deduce the corresponding group of elements X and Y from the successive ionization energies given. An element's successive ionization energies increase as more energy is needed to remove electrons.  As the ion becomes more positive, it will take more energy to remove the next electron.  Successive ionization energies always increase. When the next electron is in a shell closer to the nucleus, the successive ionization energy will increase sharply because there is less shielding of the nuclear charge and because the distance between the electron and nucleus is smaller.In the table provided, the largest jump in the ionization energy for element X occurs betweenIE1IE_1IE1​(first ionization energy) andIE2IE_2IE2​(second ionization energy). This must correspond to a change in energy level. So, the atom of the element must have one valence electron and belong to group 1. In the case of Y, the largest jump in the ionization energy occurs betweenIE6IE_6IE6​(sixth ionization energy) andIE7IE_7IE7​(seventh ionization energy). So, the atom of the element must have six valence electrons and belong to group 16.X forms cations with one positive charge whereas Y forms ions with two negative charges. As a result, the combination ofXX+\ce{X+}XX+andYX2−\ce{Y^{2-}}YX2−isXX2Y.\ce{X2Y}.XX2​Y.This question is categorized as a medium as the student must use the information from successive ionization energies to deduce the corresponding group for the elements and then figure out how these are combined together.

list.content:
Ionization energy data for the elements can be used to provide evidence for energy levels and sublevels within the atom.The diagram below shows the amount of energy required to remove the first 10 electrons from a period 3 element.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/936356f8-e31b-4bf2-99a4-07f670f2d94b/images/e1a82b9f-5b5a-4cb0-a4b3-1a3d8405c221/CH0786a.png)

Write an equation that represents the third ionization energy of an element. You can useAas the symbol for the unknown element.[2]Identify the period 3 element and explain how the ionization data shown above supports your response.[3]Explain why the ionization data increases as subsequent electrons are removed from the atom.[1]Write the electron configuration for the commonly formed ion of this period 3 element.[1]The diagram below shows the first ionization energies of the elements across period 3.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/936356f8-e31b-4bf2-99a4-07f670f2d94b/images/6eee7b19-a1b4-45d8-880e-a5473303b658/CH0786b.png)

Explain how the first ionization data shown can be used to support the existence of thesssandpppsublevels of period 3.[4]Explain why argon has such a high first ionization energy.[1]
list.markScheme: AX2+(g)→AX3+(g)+eX−✓✓\ce{A^2+(g) -> A^3+(g) + e-}\,\checkmark\checkmarkAX2+(g)​AX3+(g)+eX−✓✓Award M2 for state symbols.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Ionization energy is the energy required to remove an electron from a ground−-−state gas−-−phase atom or ion. The removal of the third successive electron would come from the ion of the element that has already lost 2 electrons (AX2+\ce{A^{2+}}AX2+). Removal of the third electron would change the ion toAX3+\ce{A^{3+}}AX3+.Magnesium  / Mg✓\checkmark✓large jump between 2nd^{nd}ndand 3rd^{rd}rdionization energy, 3rd^{rd}rdelectron from inner energy level✓\checkmark✓two valence electrons✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Looking at the graph, there is a larger step (nonlinear) increase in the subsequent ionization energies for the removal of the third electron. This means the first two electrons are removed from the valence energy level, while the third is removed from an inner energy level, in this case the second energy level since the element is in period 3.more positively changed ion, stronger attraction to the nucleus✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Since ionization energy is the energy required to completely move the electron from the atom or ion, as the charge on the nucleus increases, the ionization energy must therefore increase.1sX22sX22pX6\ce{1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6}1sX22sX22pX6✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The period 3 element is magnesium with two valence electrons in the3s3s3ssublevel. Losing these two electrons leaves a the period 2 energy level, withsssandpppsublevels complete.drop in ionization energy from Mg to Al✓\checkmark✓electrons in3p3p3psubshell partially shielded by3s3s3selectrons✓\checkmark✓drop in the ionization energy moving from P to S✓\checkmark✓fourth electron in3p3p3psubshell experiences increasedeX−−eX−\ce{e-}-\ce{e-}eX−−eX−repulsion✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The trend of ionization energy across period 3 is generally upward due to the increasing nuclear charge pulling the outer electrons closer. However, the data also show irregularities that can only be explained by sublevels. The first occurs between magnesium and aluminium: in aluminium, the electron removed is from a3p3p3porbital, which lies at slightly higher energy and is shielded by the inner 3s orbital. This makes it easier to remove than the3s3s3selectron in magnesium. A second dip occurs between phosphorus and sulfur. Phosphorus has three unpaired3p3p3pelectrons, but sulfur has a fourth3p3p3pelectron that must pair with one of the others. The repulsion between two electrons in the same orbital lowers the energy required to remove one, creating the observed decrease. These two dips are direct experimental evidence that period 3 contains both3s3s3sand3p3p3psublevels.Ar has highest effective nuclear charge , same shielding✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Argon lies at the end of period 3, where the nuclear charge is greatest. Its outer electrons are still in then=3n=3n=3shell, but they experience a strong effective nuclear charge because shielding from inner electrons is relatively constant across the period. This strong attraction between nucleus and outer3p3p3pelectrons requires much more energy to remove them, so argon shows the highest first ionization energy of period 3.

list.title: Question 189
list.content: Which of the following statements about electron spin is correct?I.Unpaired electrons occupy separate orbitals within a sublevel before pairing occurs.II.Two electrons in the same orbital must have parallel spins.III.Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows two electrons to occupy the same orbital.A.\hspace{1em}I and IIB.\hspace{1em}II and IIIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​According to Hund's Rule, electrons fill orbitals of the same sublevel singly and with parallel spins before any pairing occurs. This minimizes electron-electron repulsion and leads to a more stable, lower-energy configuration. Statement I is correct.Electrons in the same orbital must have opposite spins, not parallel spins, to satisfy the Pauli Exclusion Principle, which prevents two electrons in the same orbital from having identical properties. Statement II is incorrect.Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows them to share an orbital, as long as their spins are opposite (↑\uparrow↑and↓\downarrow↓). This difference in spin enables two electrons to occupy the same spatial region without violating exclusion rules. Statement III is correct.

list.title: Question 190
list.content: A500cm3500\,\text{cm}^3500cm3flask is weighed empty.  After a chemical reaction was conducted, a gas was collected at SATP conditions.  The flask was found to increase in mass by1.43g.1.43\,\text{g}.1.43g.What is the name of the gas collected?A.\hspace{1em}HydrogenB.\hspace{1em}OxygenC.\hspace{1em}Carbon dioxideD.\hspace{1em}Chlorine
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At SATP conditions(P=100kPa,T=298.15K)(P = 100 \textrm{\ kPa}, T = 298.15 \textrm{\ K})(P=100kPa,T=298.15K), the ideal gas law can be used to deduce the molar mass of the unknown gas. Starting fromPV=nRT,PV=nRT,PV=nRT,and substitutingn=mM,n = \frac{m}{M},n=Mm​,we obtainPV=mRTMPV = \dfrac{mRT}{M}PV=MmRT​which rearranges toM=mRTPVM = \dfrac{mRT}{PV}M=PVmRT​Converting the volume todm3\textrm{dm}^3dm3(because1J=1kPa dm3),1 \textrm{\ J} = 1 \textrm{\ kPa dm}^3),1J=1kPa dm3),and substituting the given valuesM=1.43g×8.31J mol−1×298.15K100 kPa×0.500dm3=70.9g mol−1M = \dfrac{1.43 \textrm{\ g} \times 8.31 \textrm{\ J mol}^{-1} \times 298.15 \textrm{\ K}}{\textrm{\ 100 \textrm kPa} \times {0.500 \textrm{\ dm}^3}} = 70.9 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}M=100kPa×0.500dm31.43g×8.31J mol−1×298.15K​=70.9g mol−1Comparing this value with the molar masses of the candidate gases we can identify the unknown: hydrogen(HX2,2.02g mol−1),(\ce{H2}, \ 2.02 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),(HX2​,2.02g mol−1),oxygen(OX2,32.00g mol−1),(\ce{O2},\ 32.00 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),(OX2​,32.00g mol−1),carbon dioxide(COX2,44.01g mol−1),(\ce{CO2},\ 44.01 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),(COX2​,44.01g mol−1),and chlorine(ClX2,70.90g mol−1).(\ce{Cl2},\ 70.90 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}).(ClX2​,70.90g mol−1).The measured value corresponds to chlorine.This is a challenging question because it requires students to combine experimental data with the ideal gas equation to infer an unknown identity, rather than relying on a direct recall of facts.

list.title: Question 191
list.content: A chemist wants to purify a solid organic compound contaminated with small amounts of a soluble impurity. Which technique is most appropriate?A.\hspace{1.em}EvaporationB.\hspace{1.em}DistillationC.\hspace{1.em}RecrystallizationD.\hspace{1.em}Filtration
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Recrystallization is the most effective technique for purifying a solid organic compound when small amounts of a soluble impurity are present. In this process, the impure solid is dissolved in a hot solvent, and as the solution cools, the desired compound crystallizes out, leaving impurities behind in the solution. The purified crystals are then collected by filtration. This method works best when the desired compound is highly soluble in the solvent at high temperatures but only sparingly soluble at low temperatures, while the impurity remains dissolved in the solvent even at lower temperatures.Other techniques are less suitable in this case. Filtration would only be effective if the impurity were insoluble, which is not the case here. Evaporation would remove the solvent but leave behind both the solid and its impurities. Distillation is used to separate liquids based on boiling points and is not suitable for purifying a solid. Since recrystallization allows selective separation based on solubility differences, it is the best choice for purifying a solid contaminated with small amounts of a soluble impurity.

list.title: Question 192
list.content: A sample of solid iodine is placed in a sealed flask. The sample is heated gently. After a few minutes, the solid disappears, and a purple vapor is visible in the container. When the sample is cooled, solid iodine is again visible on the walls of the flask.Which of the following best explains this observation?A.\hspace{1.em}During heating, iodine particles absorb energy and evaporate; during cooling, iodine particles release energy and condense.B.\hspace{1.em}During heating, iodine particles absorb energy and condense, during cooling, iodine particles release energy and evaporate.C.\hspace{1.em}During heating, iodine particles absorb energy and sublime; during cooling, iodine particles release energy and undergo deposition.D.\hspace{1.em}During heating, iodine particles absorb energy and undergo deposition; during cooling, iodine particles release energy and sublime.
list.markScheme: CEpxlanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Epxlanation:}}Epxlanation:​The transition from solid to gas is sublimation and its reverse, the transition from gas to solid is deposition.Absorb heatPhase ChangeRelease heatPhase ChangeVaporizationliquid⟶\longrightarrow⟶gasCondensationgas⟶\longrightarrow⟶liquidNote: Vaporization above the boiling point is called boiling and below the boiling point is called evaporation. Melting is also called fusion.

list.title: Question 193
list.content: Which statement correctly describes the behavior of particles during the phase change from liquid to gas at the boiling point?A.\hspace{1em}Particles remain in the liquid phase until the temperature exceeds the boiling point.B.\hspace{1em}Particles absorb energy to overcome intermolecular forces, causing a continuous rise in temperature.C.\hspace{1em}Particles absorb energy to overcome intermolecular forces, but the temperature remains constant.D.\hspace{1em}Particles experience no change in energy while transitioning from liquid to gas.
list.markScheme:
CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​During boiling, all heat energy supplied to the system is used to break intermolecular forces, allowing the substance to transition from liquid to gas. The kinetic energy of the particles does not increase, meaning the temperature remains constant until the phase change is complete. This is evident in a heating curve, where the plateau at the boiling point indicates that energy is being used for vaporization rather than raising temperature.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/036ac452-cb2a-430e-b1ac-408d86f09a5b/images/35fd9e9e-afe4-420e-9a46-4319fab8a71a/CH2082.png)

list.title: Question 194
list.content: A sample of ethanol is placed in an open container. Over time, the volume of the liquid decreased, even though the temperature remained constant at 25∘C.^\circ\text{C}.∘C.Select the statement that best describes this phenomenon.A.\hspace{1em}Ethanol molecules at the surface vaporized at a temperature below boiling point.B.\hspace{1em}Ethanol intermolecular forces are weaker at the surface, leading to vaporization.C.\hspace{1em}Ethanol molecules reached the boiling point and vaporized.D.\hspace{1em}Ethanol molecules underwent a decrease in pressure, leading to vaporization.
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Evaporation occurs when molecules at the surface gain enough kinetic energy to overcome intermolecular forces and escape into the gas phase, even without reaching the boiling point. Unlike boiling, which requires the entire liquid to reach a specific temperature, evaporation happens gradually at any temperature.

list.title: Question 196
list.content: During a calorimetry experiment, a student recorded the initial and final temperature of a sample in the table below:Temperature /∘^\circ∘C\\±0.5∘\mathbf\pm 0.5^\circ±0.5∘C\ \ \ \ \Initial\ \ \ \ \18.0Final72.0What is the temperature change in Kelvin, including its uncertainty?A.327.0±1.0K\hspace{1em}327.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}327.0±1.0KB.327.0±0.5K\hspace{1em}327.0\pm 0.5\text{ K}327.0±0.5KC.54.0±1.0K\hspace{1em}54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}54.0±1.0KD.54.0±0.5K\hspace{1em}54.0\pm 0.5\text{ K}54.0±0.5K
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The correct answer is54.0±1.0K54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}54.0±1.0Kbecause the temperature change in Kelvin is equal to the temperature change in Celsius, meaning we simply subtract:72.0∘C−18.0∘C=54.0∘C72.0^\circ\text{C} - 18.0^\circ\text{C} = 54.0^\circ\text{C}72.0∘C−18.0∘C=54.0∘CThe Kelvin scale is shifted by273.15∘C,273.15^\circ\text{C},273.15∘C,but the degrees are the same size as Celsius degrees. Alternatively, both temperature can be converted to Kelvin before the subtraction345.15K−291.15K=54.0K345.15\text{ K} - 291.15\text{ K} = 54.0\text{ K}345.15K−291.15K=54.0KFor the uncertainty, since we are subtracting two measured values, we must add their absolute uncertainties:(±0.5K)+(±0.5K)=±1.0K(\pm 0.5\text{ K}) + (\pm 0.5\text{K}) = \pm 1.0\text{ K}(±0.5K)+(±0.5K)=±1.0KThis gives a final result of54.0±1.0K.54.0\pm 1.0\text{ K}.54.0±1.0K.

list.title: Question 197
list.content: Sodium azide is an ionic compound found within the airbags of some older cars. The airbag is deployed as a safety feature in the event of an accident. In this application, the sodium azide decomposes rapidly, and the gas formed inflates the airbag.The decomposition of sodium azide under these conditions is given below.2NaNX3(s)→2Na(s)+3NX2(g)\ce{2NaN3(s)-> 2Na(s) + 3N2(g)}2NaNX3​(s)​2Na(s)+3NX2​(g)Suggest the formula and charge for the azide ion.[1]A typical airbag requires65.0dm365.0\,\text{dm}^{3}65.0dm3of nitrogen gas for complete inflation at STP. Using section222of the data booklet, calculate the mass of sodium azide that the airbag must contain for this purpose.[4]
list.markScheme: The ion azide isNX3X−\ce{N3^-}NX3​X−✓\checkmark✓Award0ifchargeis(3−)\,{Award \ 0 \ if \ charge \ is\ (3-)}Award0ifchargeis(3−)Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Na\ce{Na}Nais in group 1; therefore, the ion formed isNaX1+.\ce{Na^1+}.NaX1+.The charges of the ions must cancel out to give an overall neutral compound.n(NX2)=Vmolarvolume=65.0dm322.7dm3mol−1=2.86mol✓n(\ce{N2}) = \dfrac{V}{\textit{molar volume}}=\dfrac{65.0\,\text{dm}^{3}}{22.7\,\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 2.86\,\text{mol}\,\checkmarkn(NX2​)=molar volumeV​=22.7dm3mol−165.0dm3​=2.86mol✓Mole ratio 2:3 applied for number of moles of sodium aziden(NaNX3)=(2.86)(23)=1.91mol✓n(\ce{NaN3}) = (2.86) \left(\dfrac{2}{3}\right)= 1.91\,\text{mol}\,\checkmarkn(NaNX3​)=(2.86)(32​)=1.91mol✓Molar mass for sodium azide calculated =65.02gmol−1✓65.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\,\checkmark65.02gmol−1✓m(NaNX3)=n×M=(1.91mol)(65.02gmol−1)=124gm(\ce{NaN3}) = n\times M = (1.91\,\text{mol})(65.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = \answer{124\text{g}}m(NaNX3​)=n×M=(1.91mol)(65.02gmol−1)=124g​(3 sf)✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The number of moles of gas at STP is calculated as volume divided by molar gas volume(22.7dm3mol−1)(22.7\,\text{dm}^3\text{mol}^{-1})(22.7dm3mol−1)M(NaNX3)=22.99+(14.01)(3)=65.02gmol−1M(\ce{NaN3}) = 22.99 + (14.01)(3) = 65.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}M(NaNX3​)=22.99+(14.01)(3)=65.02gmol−1

list.title: Question 198
list.content: What is the concentration of sodium ions in a0.356mol dm−30.356 \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}0.356mol dm−3solution of sodium sulfate?A.\hspace{1em}0.356B.\hspace{1em}0.712C.\hspace{1em}0.425D.\hspace{1em}0.850
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Sodium sulfate (NaX2SOX4\ce{Na2SO4}NaX2​SOX4​) dissociates in water, releasing two sodium cations.[NaX+]=2×0.356mol dm−3=0.712mol dm−3[\ce{Na+}] = 2\times 0.356\,\text{mol dm}^{-3} = 0.712\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}[NaX+]=2×0.356mol dm−3=0.712mol dm−3This question is categorized as medium difficulty, requiring students to deduce the molecular formula of sodium sulfate and the cation concentration in an aqueous solution.

list.title: Question 199
list.content: Which of the following gases most closely aligns with the behavior of an ideal gas?A.BrX2\hspace{1em}\ce{Br2}BrX2​, bromineB.HX2\hspace{1em}\ce{H2}HX2​, hydrogenC.ClX2\hspace{1em}\ce{Cl2}ClX2​, chlorineD.OX2\hspace{1em}\ce{O2}OX2​, oxygen
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\text{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The student must understand the concepts behind an ideal gas which assumes negligent volume and insignificant attractive forces between atoms or molecules.As the molar mass of a chemical species increases, the attractive forces between particles also increase. This causes a deviation from the ideal gas model as the relative molecular mass increases.This question is categorized as medium difficulty because the student must apply logic to the definition of an ideal gas.

list.title: Question 200
list.content: Which of the following correctly describes the electron configuration of theCaX2+\ce{Ca^2+}CaX2+ion?Number of occupiedpppsublevelsNumber of occupiedppporbitalsA.\hspace{1em}26B.212C.62D.122
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​In theCaX2+\ce{Ca^2+}CaX2+ion, the electron configuration is1s22s22p63s23p6.1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6.1s22s22p63s23p6.This means that twopppsublevels are occupied:2p2p2pand3p.3p.3p.Each of these sublevels includes threeppporbitals, and in this case, all sixppporbitals are fully occupied. Understanding the distinction between sublevels and orbitals is essential to interpreting electron configurations accurately.

list.title: Question 201
list.content: The successive ionization energies for element X are shown in the table below:SuccessiveIonizationEnergies(kJmol−1)\textbf{Successive Ionization Energies (kJ mol}^{\mathbf{-1}})Successive Ionization Energies (kJ mol−1)1st IE2nd IE3rd IE4th IE5th IE6th IE7th IE8th IE1000225233634556700484962710831724Write the equation that represents the second ionization energy of element X.[1]Predict the number of valence electrons for element X and justify your response.[2]Another element, Y, is found below and in the same group as element X in the periodic table. The electronegativity value of element Y is 2.6.Predict a reasonable value for the electronegativity value of element X. Explain your reasoning.[2]
list.markScheme: XX+(g)→XX2+(g)+eX−\ce{X^+(g) -> X^{2+}(g) + e^-}XX+(g)​XX2+(g)+eX−✓\checkmark✓State symbols must be shown.Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​Second ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of singly positive gaseous ions.element X has 6 valence electrons✓\checkmark✓large jump between 6th and 7th IE✓\checkmark✓Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​There is a large increase moving from the 6th IE to the 7th IE. This indicates that the 7th electron must be removed from a lower energy level closer to the nucleus as substantially more energy is required to remove the 7th electron.value between 2.6 and 3.4✓\checkmark✓smaller atom has higher electronegativity✓\checkmark✓Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​Element Y lies in the same group and below element X. Therefore, element Y has more energy levels in its atom than element X. Electronegativity is the attraction the atom of an element has for the shared pair of electrons in a covalent bond. This attraction will increase when there are fewer energy levels; hence electrons are closer to the nucleus or the atom, and the element has a higher electronegativity value.  The most electronegative atom in Group 16 is oxygen with 3.4.

list.title: Question 202
list.content: Which statement(s) is (are) correct about real gases?I.\hspace{1.em}Gas particles are considered to have negligible volume.II.\hspace{0.7em}At low temperatures, intermolecular forces exist.III.\hspace{0.4em}At high pressure, real gases behave as ideal gases.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II onlyD.\hspace{1em}II and III only
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Ideal gases are described as moving particles with no volume and no intermolecular forces. In contrast, real gases take into account the small volume of particles and the intermolecular forces that can cause a deviation from the ideal behavior.Statement I is incorrect as it applies to ideal gases only.Real gases behave like ideal gases at high temperatures and low pressures. Statement III is incorrect.At low temperatures, condensed phases exist, and intermolecular forces are significant. Statement II is correct.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must thoroughly compare and distinguish ideal and real gases.

list.title: Question 203
list.content: A student carried out an experiment to determine the empirical formula of an oxide of manganese.3.60g3.60\,\text{g}3.60gof the metal was heated in the presence of an excess of oxygen. When the metal reacted completely,5.64g5.64\,\text{g}5.64gof metal oxide were formed.Deduce the empirical formula of the oxide.[3]Suggest an experimental technique the student can use to ensure that the manganese has completely reacted.[1]A common impurity in manganese is carbon.  How would this impurity affect the determination of the empirical formula?[2]
list.markScheme: mOX2=5.64−3.60=2.04g✓m_\ce{O2} = 5.64 - 3.60 = 2.04\,\text{g}\ \checkmarkmOX2​​=5.64−3.60=2.04g✓nMn=0.0655n_\ce{Mn} = 0.0655nMn​=0.0655ANDnOX2=0.128✓n_\ce{O2} = 0.128\ \checkmarknOX2​​=0.128✓MnOX2✓\ce{MnO2}\ \checkmarkMnOX2​✓Award full marks for correct final answer.Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The mass of oxygen can be obtained by subtracting the mass of the metal from the mass of the metal oxide.mMnXxOXy−mMn=mOm_\ce{Mn_xO_y} - m_\ce{Mn} = m_\ce{O}mMnXx​OXy​​​−mMn​=mO​5.62g−3.60g=2.02g5.62\,\text{g} - 3.60\,\text{g} = 2.02\,\text{g}5.62g−3.60g=2.02gThe moles for each of the elements can be obtained by applying the formula;n=mMn = \dfrac{m}{M}n=Mm​.nMn=3.60g54.94g mol−1=0.0655moln_\ce{Mn} = \dfrac{3.60\,\text{g}}{54.94\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.0655\,\text{mol}nMn​=54.94g mol−13.60g​=0.0655molnO=2.04g16.00g mol−1=0.128moln_\ce{O} = \dfrac{2.04\,\text{g}}{16.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.128\,\text{mol}nO​=16.00g mol−12.04g​=0.128molThe simplest ratio is obtained by dividing the moles of the substance by the smallest value of moles. This is the empirical formula:Mn:0.0655mol0.0655mol=1\dfrac{0.0655\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 10.0655mol0.0655mol​=1O:0.128mol0.0655mol=1.95≈2\dfrac{0.128\,\text{mol}}{0.0655\,\text{mol}} = 1.95\approx 20.0655mol0.128mol​=1.95≈2The empirical formula isMnOX2\ce{MnO2}MnOX2​.Repeatedly heat and weigh until constant mass is achieved✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The mass of the sample is considered to have reached a constant value when the difference between successive weighings is minimal and falls within an acceptable range of experimental error. This indicates that all of the manganese has reacted with oxygen within practical restrictions.more oxygen will react per unit mass (to formCOX2)✓\ce{CO2})\,\checkmarkCOX2​)✓the ratio of O to Mn will be greater than 2✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​If the manganese sample contains carbon as an impurity, it will also react with oxygen to form carbon dioxide. The additional mass of oxygen bonded to carbon would be incorrectly attributed to the formation of the manganese oxide. This would result in an overestimation of the oxygen content in the final product and an artificially high oxygen-to-manganes ratio. Consequently, the empirical formula of the manganese oxide would be determined incorrectly, potentially showing a higher number of oxygen atoms per manganese atom than is accurate (e.g.,MnOX3\ce{MnO3}MnOX3​instead ofMnOX2).\ce{MnO2}).MnOX2​).

list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In the first three minutes, the mass of methanol formed ism(CHX3OH)=4.0g min−1×3min=12.0gm(\ce{CH3OH}) = 4.0 \textrm{\ g min}^{-1} \times 3 \textrm{\ min} = 12.0 \textrm{\ g}m(CHX3​OH)=4.0g min−1×3min=12.0gTo determine the amount of hydrogen gas that reacted we will need to use the molar ratio.  First, find the moles of methanol formed:n(CHX3OH)=mMr=12.0g(12.01+4.04+16.00)g mol−1n\ce{(CH3OH)} = \dfrac{m}{M_r} = \dfrac{12.0\,\text{g}}{(12.01 + 4.04 + 16.00) \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}}n(CHX3​OH)=Mr​m​=(12.01+4.04+16.00)g mol−112.0g​The balanced chemical reaction shows the ratio ofCHX3OH\ce{CH3OH}CHX3​OHtoHX2\ce{H2}HX2​is 1 : 2, son(HX2)=2×n(CHX3OH)n\ce{(H2)} = 2 \times  n\ce{(CH3OH)}n(HX2​)=2×n(CHX3​OH)The molar volume of hydrogen is22.7×103cm3mol−122.7\times 10^3\,\text{cm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1}22.7×103cm3mol−1.
