list.title: Question 205
list.content: Two elements, X and Y, have the following successive ionization energies (inkJ mol−1):\text{kJ mol}^{-1}):kJ mol−1):Element1st2nd3rd4th5th6thX73814517733105431363018020Y1012190729144964624721267What is the most likely formula of the compound formed when X and Y combine?A.XY\hspace{1em}\ce{XY}XYB.XX2YX3\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y3}XX2​YX3​C.XX3YX2\hspace{1em}\ce{X3Y2}XX3​YX2​D.XYX2\hspace{1em}\ce{XY2}XYX2​
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​First, the student must use the information about successive ionization energies to deduce the group of both elements. For element X, there is a significant jump in ionization energy between the second and third ionization energies (from1451kJ mol−11451\text{kJ mol}^{-1}1451kJ mol−1to7733kJ mol−1),7733\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}),7733kJ mol−1),indicating that the first two electrons are valence electrons. Therefore, X has two valence electrons and belongs to Group 2. For element Y, a large jump occurs between the fifth and sixth ionization energies (from6247kJ mol−16247\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}6247kJ mol−1to21267kJ mol−1),21267\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}),21267kJ mol−1),suggesting that the first five electrons are valence electrons. Thus, Y has five valence electrons and belongs to Group 15.Second, the student must determine the preferred charge of each of the elements to find the most likely compound that they would form. Element X, with two valence electrons, will likely lose both to form theXX2+\ce{X^2+}XX2+ion, while element Y, with five valence electrons, will likely gain three electrons to form theYX3−\ce{Y^3-}YX3−ion. To balance the charges in a neutral compound, threeXX2+\ce{X^2+}XX2+ions will combine with twoYX3−\ce{Y^3-}YX3−ions, resulting in the formulaXX3YX2.\ce{X3Y2}.XX3​YX2​.This question is categorized as medium difficulty because it requires analyzing ionization energy trends, deducing ionic charges, and balancing charges to determine the correct formula of the compound.

list.title: Question 206
list.content: A sample of chlorine gas contains the isotopesX35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​ClandX37X2237Cl\ce{^{37}Cl}X37​X2237​Cl. In the mass spectrum of a sample of chlorine gas, what is an interpretation of the peak at 74m/zm/zm/z?A.\hspace{1em}It was caused by the detection of a chlorine molecule consisting of twoX37X2237Cl\ce{^{37}Cl}X37​X2237​ClatomsB.\hspace{1em}It was caused by the detection of twoX37X2237Cl\ce{^{37}Cl}X37​X2237​ClatomsC.\hspace{1em}It was caused by the detection of a chlorine molecule consisting ofX35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​ClandX37X2237Cl\ce{^{37}Cl}X37​X2237​ClatomsD.\hspace{1em}It was caused by the detection of twoX35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​Clatoms
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The student must understand that in the mass spectrum of chlorine gas, there is more than one peak present and it consists of the combinations of molecules and atoms from the isotopes:X35X2235ClX+\ce{^{35}Cl^+}X35​X2235​ClX+at 35m/zm/zm/zX37X2237ClX+\ce{^{37}Cl^+}X37​X2237​ClX+at 37m/zm/zm/zX35X2235ClX2X+\ce{^{35}Cl_2^+}X35​X2235​ClX2​X+at 70m/zm/zm/z(composed of twoX35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​Clatoms: 35 + 35 = 70)X35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​ClX37X2237ClX+\ce{^{37}Cl^+}X37​X2237​ClX+at 72m/zm/zm/z(composed ofX37X2237Cl\ce{^{37}Cl}X37​X2237​ClandX35X2235Cl\ce{^{35}Cl}X35​X2235​Clatoms: 35 + 37 = 72)X37X2237ClX2X+\ce{^{37}Cl_2^+}X37​X2237​ClX2​X+at 74m/zm/zm/z(composed of twoX37X2237Cl\ce{^{37}Cl}X37​X2237​Clatoms: 37 + 37 = 74)This question is categorized as difficult because the student must interpret the mass spectrum data correctly based on the possible combinations from the chlorine isotopes.

list.title: Question 207
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Using the equationsc=λfc = \lambda fc=λfandE=hfE = hfE=hffrom the data booklet, the energy of one mole of photons with a wavelength of 600 nm can be determined. The energy of one photon isEphoton=hf=hcλE_{\ce{photon}} = hf = \dfrac{hc}{\lambda}Ephoton​=hf=λhc​and the energy of 1 mole of phtons isE=hcNAλE = \dfrac{hcN_A}{\lambda}E=λhcNA​​Plugging in the values:E=(6.63×10−34J s)(3.00×108m s−1)(6.02×1023mol−1)600nmE = \dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34} \textrm{\ J s})(3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1})(6.02 \times 10^{23} \textrm{\ mol}^{-1})}{600 \textrm{\ nm}}E=600nm(6.63×10−34J s)(3.00×108m s−1)(6.02×1023mol−1)​To get the final answer inkJ mol−1\textrm{\ kJ mol}^{-1}kJ mol−1, J must be converted to kJ and nm to m.E=(6.63×10−34J s)(1kJ1000J)(3.00×108m s−1)(6.02×1023mol−1)600nm×1m109nmE = \dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34} \textrm{\ J s})\left(\dfrac{1 \textrm{\ kJ}}{1000 \textrm{\ J}}\right)(3.00 \times 10^8 \textrm{\ m s}^{-1})(6.02 \times 10^{23} \textrm{\ mol}^{-1})}{600 \textrm{\ nm}\times\dfrac{1 \textrm{\ m}}{10^9 \textrm{\ nm}}}E=600nm×109nm1m​(6.63×10−34J s)(1000J1kJ​)(3.00×108m s−1)(6.02×1023mol−1)​E=(6.63×10−34)(3.00×108)(6.02×1023)(6.00×10−7)(1000)E = \dfrac{(6.63 \times 10^{-34})(3.00 \times 10^8 )(6.02 \times 10^{23})}{(6.00 \times 10^{-7})(1000) }E=(6.00×10−7)(1000)(6.63×10−34)(3.00×108)(6.02×1023)​\

list.title: Question 208
list.content: Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom emission spectrum emits radiation with the highest frequency?A.n=1⟶n=7\hspace{1em}n=1\longrightarrow n=7n=1⟶n=7B.n=7⟶n=1\hspace{1em}n=7 \longrightarrow n=1n=7⟶n=1C.n=5⟶n=2\hspace{1em}n=5 \longrightarrow n=2n=5⟶n=2D.n=4⟶n=3\hspace{1em}n=4 \longrightarrow n=3n=4⟶n=3
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To answer this question, students must differentiate emission (electrons decaying to a lower energy level) from absorption (electrons promoted to higher energy levels).Students should also recall the relationship between frequency and energy (E∝fE \propto fE∝f). The highest frequency corresponds to the highesy energy transition.  According to the Bohr model, thediscrete energy levels in the hydrogen spectrum converge at higher energies. Of the three emissions proposed, the one with the greatest frequency/energy isn=7⟶n=1.n=7 \longrightarrow n=1.n=7⟶n=1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89299878-7c02-447d-9568-fe86fcf00643/images/1fae25df-afde-432d-9d9e-b4c45710afca/CH0994.JPEG)

This question is categorized as hard as students compare transitions based on their knowledge of the hydrogen energy level diagram.

list.title: Question 209
list.content:
A mixture is investigated through paper chromatography, comparing it with standards X, Y, and Z. The development of the chromatograph allows the interpretation of the results shown below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ce658891-f7b1-4bd2-8eca-c19f7241f8b4/images/08815fef-1bd2-442a-9d73-ea5db26ea175/CH1096.png)

Which statement(s) is(are) correct?I.\hspace{1.em}X and Y are present in the mixture.II.\hspace{0.7em}Z is not present in the mixtureIII.\hspace{0.4em}The mixture must contain four components.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I, II, and IIID.\hspace{1em}II and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In paper chromatography, a solvent rises through the paper by capillary action and carries the components of a mixture with it. Different substances travel at different rates depending on their interactions with the paper and the solvent, producing a pattern of separated spots. The position of each spot can be expressed using the retention factor:Rf=distance moved by the spotdistance moved by the solvent frontR_f = \dfrac{\text{distance moved by the spot}}{\text{distance moved by the solvent front}}Rf​=distance moved by the solvent frontdistance moved by the spot​Retention factors range between 0 and 1 and provide a way to compare spots.In the chromatogram, the mixture has separated into four distinct spots. The sameRfR_fRf​value is seen in both the mixture and standard X, showing that X is present. Similarly, both spots of standard Y are also present in the mixture, so Y is included as well. Standard Z, however, has two spots not both present in the mixture, so Z is not included. Although four spots are visible in the mixture, this only proves that it contains at least four components—\text{---}—some spots may still contain more than one substance. Therefore, Statements I and II are correct, and Statement III is not.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must recall how chromatography works and interpret results for a specific case.

list.title: Question 210
list.content: To make a stock solution of aluminum nitrate(Al(NOX3)X3,\ce{(Al(NO3)3},(Al(NOX3​)X3​,Mr=213.00)M_r = 213.00)Mr​=213.00), 10.65 g is dissolved in 150 cm3^33of water.Which calculation below is used to determine the volume, in dm3^33, of the stock solution needed to make 1.0 dm3^33of a 0.050 mol dm−3^{-3}−3aluminum nitrate solution?A.\hspace{1em}10.65×1×0.050213.00×0.150\dfrac{10.65 \times 1 \times 0.050}{213.00 \times 0.150}213.00×0.15010.65×1×0.050​B.\hspace{1em}10.65213.00×0.050×1×0.150\dfrac{10.65}{213.00 \times 0.050 \times 1 \times 0.150}213.00×0.050×1×0.15010.65​C.\hspace{1em}0.050×213.00×0.15010.65\dfrac{0.050 \times 213.00 \times 0.150}{  10.65}10.650.050×213.00×0.150​D.\hspace{1em}213.0×0.05010.65×1×0.150\dfrac{213.0 \times 0.050}{10.65 \times 1 \times 0.150}10.65×1×0.150213.0×0.050​
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​First, find the concentration of the stock solution,C1C_1C1​.C=nVC = \dfrac{n}{V}C=Vn​n=10.65g213.00g mol−1;V=0.150dm3n = \dfrac{10.65\,\text{g}}{213.00\,\text{g mol}^{-1}}; \hspace{0.2in} V = 0.150\,\text{dm}^3n=213.00g mol−110.65g​;V=0.150dm3C1=10.65213.00×0.150mol dm−3C_1 = \dfrac{10.65}{213.00 \times 0.150}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}C1​=213.00×0.15010.65​mol dm−3For dilutions, we can use the formulaC1V1=C2V2C_1V_1 = C_2V_2C1​V1​=C2​V2​which relies on the number of moles in the concentrated stock solution being equal to the number of moles in the dilute, 1.0 mol dm3^33solution.Rearranging to find the volume of the stock solution required,V1V_1V1​,V1=C2×V2C1V_1 = \dfrac{C_2 \times  V_2}{C_1}V1​=C1​C2​×V2​​We are given thatC2=0.050mol dm−3C_2 = 0.050\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}C2​=0.050mol dm−3andV2=1.0dm3.V_2 = 1.0\,\text{dm}^3.V2​=1.0dm3.Plugging these values in to the expression forV1,V_1,V1​,along with theC1C_1C1​found above, givesV1=0.050mol dm−3×1.0dm310.65213.00×0.150mol dm−3V_1 = \dfrac{0.050\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times 1.0\,\text{dm}^3}{\frac{10.65}{213.00\times 0.150}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}}V1​=213.00×0.15010.65​mol dm−30.050mol dm−3×1.0dm3​V1=0.050×1.0×213.00×0.15010.65dm3V_1 = \dfrac{0.050\times 1.0\times 213.00\times 0.150}{10.65}\,\text{dm}^3V1​=10.650.050×1.0×213.00×0.150​dm3

list.title: Question 211
list.content: Which electron transition in a hydrogen atom emits the longest wavelength of light?A.n=3\hspace{1em}n = 3n=3ton=2n = 2n=2B.n=4\hspace{1em}n = 4n=4ton=3n = 3n=3C.n=5\hspace{1em}n = 5n=5ton=4n = 4n=4D.n=2\hspace{1em}n = 2n=2ton=1n = 1n=1
list.markScheme:
CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The electronic energy levels for the hydrogen atom converge at high energy (furthest from the nucleus), wheren=1n = 1n=1is closest to the nucleus. A simple diagram can be drawn to show the relative energy levels.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e38802a0-9d42-4913-b9b7-de2c97c3a807/images/a330f257-07c0-49ca-84ff-4a03ecd5af38/CH2032.png)

Each transition is indicated with an arrow, where the longest arrow equates to the highest energy. Energy and the wavelength of light are inversely proportional as follows:E=hcλE = \dfrac{hc}{\lambda}E=λhc​Therefore, a higher energy has a lower wavelength (and vice versa). For this question, we are looking for the shortest arrow which is the lowest energy and the longest wavelength (so,n=5n= 5n=5ton=4).n = 4).n=4).

list.title: Question 212
list.content: Which property is most likely to differ between two isotopes of the same element?A.\hspace{1em}The strength of chemical bonds they form in compounds.B.\hspace{1em}Their ability to conduct electricity in the solid state.C.\hspace{1em}Their reactivity with acids and bases.D.\hspace{1em}Their diffusion rate in gases.
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Isotopes have the same number of protons and electrons, meaning their chemical properties remain identical. This includes their ability to form chemical bonds and react with acids or bases. However, isotopes have different numbers of neutrons, leading to variations in their atomic mass which affects physical properties. In gases, the diffusion rate is inversely proportional to the square root of the atomic mass (as described by Graham's Law). Lighter isotopes diffuse faster than heavier isotopes, making diffusion rate the key property that differs between isotopes.While some physical properties vary between isotopes, such as density and melting point, properties like electrical conductivity remain unchanged. Conductivity depends on the movement of free electrons, which is not influenced by the nuclear mass.

list.title: Question 213
list.content: Water is added to200cm3200\,\text{cm}^3200cm3of a1.50×10−3mol dm−31.50\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}1.50×10−3mol dm−3HCl solution. The resulting solution has a volume300cm3300\,\text{cm}^3300cm3greater than the initial. Which statement is correct?A.\hspace{1em}The amount of solute remains constant, and the final concentration is6.00×10−4mol dm−3.6.00\times 10^{-4}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.6.00×10−4mol dm−3.B.\hspace{1em}The amount of solute remains constant, and the final concentration is1.00×10−3mol dm−3.1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.1.00×10−3mol dm−3.C.\hspace{1em}The amount of solute decreases, and the final concentration is6.00×10−4mol dm−3.6.00\times 10^{-4}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.6.00×10−4mol dm−3.D.\hspace{1em}The amount of solute decreases, and the final concentration is1.00×10−3mol dm−3.1.00\times 10^{-3}\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}.1.00×10−3mol dm−3.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:This is a dilution problem. The key idea is that when solvent is added, the number of moles of solute stays the same while the total volume increases. First calculate the amount of solute in the original solution usingn=CV.n = CV.n=CV.n=1.50×10−3mol dm−3×0.200dm3=3.00×10−4moln = 1.50 \times 10^{-3} \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3} \times 0.200 \textrm{\ dm}^3 = 3.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol}n=1.50×10−3mol dm−3×0.200dm3=3.00×10−4molAfter adding300,cm3300,\text{cm}^3300,cm3of water, the final volume is200+300=500cm3=0.500dm3200 + 300 = 500 \text{\ cm}^3 = 0.500 \text{\ dm}^3200+300=500cm3=0.500dm3.The concentration of the diluted solution is therefore[HCl]=3.00×10−4mol0.500dm3=6.00×10−4mol dm−3[\ce{HCl}] =  \dfrac{3.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol}}{0.500 \textrm{\ dm}^3} = 6.00 \times 10^{-4} \textrm{\ mol dm}^{-3}[HCl]=0.500dm33.00×10−4mol​=6.00×10−4mol dm−3

list.title: Question 214
list.content: A sample of gas at a certain temperature, pressure, and volume (T1T_1T1​,P1P_1P1​, andV1V_1V1​) undergoes a change in temperature and pressure (T2T_2T2​andP2P_2P2​). What is the new volume (V2V_2V2​)?Before:T1,P1,V1T_1, P_1, V_1T1​,P1​,V1​After:P2=2P1ANDT2=12T1P_2 = 2P_1 \quad \textrm{AND} \quad T_2 = \frac{1}{2} T_1P2​=2P1​ANDT2​=21​T1​A.12V1\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{2} V_121​V1​B.18V1\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{8} V_181​V1​C.14V1\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{4} V_141​V1​D.4V1\hspace{1em}4V_14V1​
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Use the combined gas law:P1V1T1=P2V2T2\dfrac{P_1 V_1}{T_1}= \dfrac{P_2 V_2}{T_2}T1​P1​V1​​=T2​P2​V2​​V2=P1V1T2T1P2=P1V112T1T12P1=12V12=V_2 =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 T_2}{T_1 P_2} =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 \ \frac{1}{2}T_1}{T_1\ 2P_1} =\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}V_1}{2} =V2​=T1​P2​P1​V1​T2​​=T1​2P1​P1​V1​21​T1​​=221​V1​​=14V1\frac{1}{4} V_141​V1​Alternate Method:To answer this question, the student must understand and apply the relationships between temperature, pressure, and volume in the ideal gas model:PV=nRTPV = nRTPV=nRTTherefore,V∝TV \propto TV∝TandP∝1VP \propto \dfrac{1}{V}P∝V1​.Since volume and temperature are directly proportional, an increase in one will result in an increase in the other at the same magnitude.In this case,T2=12T1T_2 = \frac{1}{2}  T_1T2​=21​T1​resulting inV2=12V1V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1V2​=21​V1​.Pressure is doubled, but since volume and pressure are inversely proportional, this results inV2=12V1V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1V2​=21​V1​.Compounding these effects results inV2=14V1V_2 = \frac{1}{4} V_1V2​=41​V1​.This question is categorized as medium because it requires an understanding of the ideal gas law and proportionalities based onPV=nRTPV = nRTPV=nRT.
